paragraphText: in aid of a peace officer or public officer, or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: Every one who is required or authorized by law to do anything in the administration or enforcement of the law
paragraphText: by virtue of his office,

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: Where a person is required or authorized by law to execute a process or to carry out a sentence, that person or any person who assists him is, if that person acts in good faith, justified in executing the process or in carrying out the sentence notwithstanding that the process or sentence is defective or that it was issued or imposed without jurisdiction or in excess of jurisdiction.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: Subject to subsections (4) and (5), a person is not justified for the purposes of subsection (1) in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm unless the person believes on reasonable grounds that it is necessary for the self-preservation of the person or the preservation of any one under that person’s protection from death or grievous bodily harm.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer, and every person lawfully assisting the peace officer, is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm to a person to be arrested, if
paragraphText: the peace officer is proceeding lawfully to arrest, with or without warrant, the person to be arrested;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer, and every person lawfully assisting the peace officer, is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm to a person to be arrested, if
paragraphText: the offence for which the person is to be arrested is one for which that person may be arrested without warrant;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer, and every person lawfully assisting the peace officer, is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm to a person to be arrested, if
paragraphText: the person to be arrested takes flight to avoid arrest;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer, and every person lawfully assisting the peace officer, is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm to a person to be arrested, if
paragraphText: the peace officer or other person using the force believes on reasonable grounds that the force is necessary for the purpose of protecting the peace officer, the person lawfully assisting the peace officer or any other person from imminent or future death or grievous bodily harm; and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer, and every person lawfully assisting the peace officer, is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm to a person to be arrested, if
paragraphText: the flight cannot be prevented by reasonable means in a less violent manner.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm against an inmate who is escaping from a penitentiary within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, if
marginalnotetext_y: Power in case of escape from penitentiary
paragraphText: the peace officer believes on reasonable grounds that any of the inmates of the penitentiary poses a threat of death or grievous bodily harm to the peace officer or any other person; and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Protection of persons acting under authority
subsectiontext: A peace officer is justified in using force that is intended or is likely to cause death or grievous bodily harm against an inmate who is escaping from a penitentiary within the meaning of subsection 2(1) of the Corrections and Conditional Release Act, if
marginalnotetext_y: Power in case of escape from penitentiary
paragraphText: the escape cannot be prevented by reasonable means in a less violent manner.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The following definitions apply in this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: It is in the public interest to ensure that public officers may effectively carry out their law enforcement duties in accordance with the rule of law and, to that end, to expressly recognize in law a justification for public officers and other persons acting at their direction to commit acts or omissions that would otherwise constitute offences.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A competent authority may designate public officers for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A competent authority referred to in paragraph (a) or (b) of the definition of that term in subsection (1) may not designate any public officer under subsection (3) unless there is a public authority composed of persons who are not peace officers that may review the public officer’s conduct.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The Governor in Council or the lieutenant governor in council of a province, as the case may be, may designate a person or body as a public authority for the purposes of subsection (3.1), and that designation is conclusive evidence that the person or body is a public authority described in that subsection.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The competent authority shall make designations under subsection (3) on the advice of a senior official and shall consider the nature of the duties performed by the public officer in relation to law enforcement generally, rather than in relation to any particular investigation or enforcement activity.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A competent authority may designate senior officials for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A senior official may designate a public officer for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4 for a period of not more than 48 hours if the senior official is of the opinion that
paragraphText: by reason of exigent circumstances, it is not feasible for the competent authority to designate a public officer under subsection (3); and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A senior official may designate a public officer for the purposes of this section and sections 25.2 to 25.4 for a period of not more than 48 hours if the senior official is of the opinion that
paragraphText: in the circumstances of the case, the public officer would be justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A designation under subsection (3) or (6) may be made subject to conditions, including conditions limiting
paragraphText: the duration of the designation;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A designation under subsection (3) or (6) may be made subject to conditions, including conditions limiting
paragraphText: the nature of the conduct in the investigation of which a public officer may be justified in committing, or directing another person to commit, acts or omissions that would otherwise constitute an offence; and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A designation under subsection (3) or (6) may be made subject to conditions, including conditions limiting
paragraphText: the acts or omissions that would otherwise constitute an offence and that a public officer may be justified in committing or directing another person to commit.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A public officer is justified in committing an act or omission — or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10) — that would otherwise constitute an offence if the public officer
paragraphText: is engaged in the investigation of an offence under, or the enforcement of, an Act of Parliament or in the investigation of criminal activity;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A public officer is justified in committing an act or omission — or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10) — that would otherwise constitute an offence if the public officer
paragraphText: is designated under subsection (3) or (6); and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A public officer is justified in committing an act or omission — or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10) — that would otherwise constitute an offence if the public officer
paragraphText: believes on reasonable grounds that the commission of the act or omission, as compared to the nature of the offence or criminal activity being investigated, is reasonable and proportional in the circumstances, having regard to such matters as the nature of the act or omission, the nature of the investigation and the reasonable availability of other means for carrying out the public officer’s law enforcement duties.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: No public officer is justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence and that would be likely to result in loss of or serious damage to property, or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10), unless, in addition to meeting the conditions set out in paragraphs (8)(a) to (c), he or she
paragraphText: is personally authorized in writing to commit the act or omission — or direct its commission — by a senior official who believes on reasonable grounds that committing the act or omission, as compared to the nature of the offence or criminal activity being investigated, is reasonable and proportional in the circumstances, having regard to such matters as the nature of the act or omission, the nature of the investigation and the reasonable availability of other means for carrying out the public officer’s law enforcement duties; or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: No public officer is justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence and that would be likely to result in loss of or serious damage to property, or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10), unless, in addition to meeting the conditions set out in paragraphs (8)(a) to (c), he or she
paragraphText: believes on reasonable grounds that the grounds for obtaining an authorization under paragraph (a) exist but it is not feasible in the circumstances to obtain the authorization and that the act or omission is necessary to
subparagraphText: preserve the life or safety of any person,

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: No public officer is justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence and that would be likely to result in loss of or serious damage to property, or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10), unless, in addition to meeting the conditions set out in paragraphs (8)(a) to (c), he or she
paragraphText: believes on reasonable grounds that the grounds for obtaining an authorization under paragraph (a) exist but it is not feasible in the circumstances to obtain the authorization and that the act or omission is necessary to
subparagraphText: prevent the compromise of the identity of a public officer acting in an undercover capacity, of a confidential informant or of a person acting covertly under the direction and control of a public officer, or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: No public officer is justified in committing an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence and that would be likely to result in loss of or serious damage to property, or in directing the commission of an act or omission under subsection (10), unless, in addition to meeting the conditions set out in paragraphs (8)(a) to (c), he or she
paragraphText: believes on reasonable grounds that the grounds for obtaining an authorization under paragraph (a) exist but it is not feasible in the circumstances to obtain the authorization and that the act or omission is necessary to
subparagraphText: prevent the imminent loss or destruction of evidence of an indictable offence.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A person who commits an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence is justified in committing it if
marginalnotetext_y: Person acting at direction of public officer
paragraphText: a public officer directs him or her to commit that act or omission and the person believes on reasonable grounds that the public officer has the authority to give that direction; and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: A person who commits an act or omission that would otherwise constitute an offence is justified in committing it if
marginalnotetext_y: Person acting at direction of public officer
paragraphText: he or she believes on reasonable grounds that the commission of that act or omission is for the purpose of assisting the public officer in the public officer’s law enforcement duties.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section justifies
paragraphText: the intentional or criminally negligent causing of death or bodily harm to another person;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section justifies
paragraphText: the wilful attempt in any manner to obstruct, pervert or defeat the course of justice; or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section justifies
paragraphText: conduct that would violate the sexual integrity of an individual.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section affects the protection, defences and immunities of peace officers and other persons recognized under the law of Canada.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section relieves a public officer of criminal liability for failing to comply with any other requirements that govern the collection of evidence.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section justifies a public officer or a person acting at his or her direction in committing an act or omission — or a public officer in directing the commission of an act or omission — that constitutes an offence under a provision of Part I of the Controlled Drugs and Substances Act or of the regulations made under it or a provision of Division 1 of Part 1 of the Cannabis Act.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
sectiontext: Every public officer who commits an act or omission — or directs the commission by another person of an act or omission — under paragraph 25.1(9)(a) or (b) shall, as soon as is feasible after the commission of the act or omission, file a written report with the appropriate senior official describing the act or omission.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every competent authority shall publish or otherwise make available to the public an annual report for the previous year that includes, in respect of public officers and senior officials designated by the competent authority,
paragraphText: the number of designations made under subsection 25.1(6) by the senior officials;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every competent authority shall publish or otherwise make available to the public an annual report for the previous year that includes, in respect of public officers and senior officials designated by the competent authority,
paragraphText: the number of authorizations made under paragraph 25.1(9)(a) by the senior officials;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every competent authority shall publish or otherwise make available to the public an annual report for the previous year that includes, in respect of public officers and senior officials designated by the competent authority,
paragraphText: the number of times that acts and omissions were committed in accordance with paragraph 25.1(9)(b) by the public officers;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every competent authority shall publish or otherwise make available to the public an annual report for the previous year that includes, in respect of public officers and senior officials designated by the competent authority,
paragraphText: the nature of the conduct being investigated when the designations referred to in paragraph (a) or the authorizations referred to in paragraph (b) were made or when the acts or omissions referred to in paragraph (c) were committed; and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every competent authority shall publish or otherwise make available to the public an annual report for the previous year that includes, in respect of public officers and senior officials designated by the competent authority,
paragraphText: the nature of the acts or omissions committed under the designations referred to in paragraph (a), under the authorizations referred to in paragraph (b) and in the manner described in paragraph (c).

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The annual report shall not contain any information the disclosure of which would
paragraphText: compromise or hinder an ongoing investigation of an offence under an Act of Parliament;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The annual report shall not contain any information the disclosure of which would
paragraphText: compromise the identity of a public officer acting in an undercover capacity, of a confidential informant or of a person acting covertly under the direction and control of a public officer;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The annual report shall not contain any information the disclosure of which would
paragraphText: endanger the life or safety of any person;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The annual report shall not contain any information the disclosure of which would
paragraphText: prejudice a legal proceeding; or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The annual report shall not contain any information the disclosure of which would
paragraphText: otherwise be contrary to the public interest.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: When a public officer commits an act or omission — or directs the commission by another person of an act or omission — under paragraph 25.1(9)(a) or (b), the senior official with whom the public officer files a written report under section 25.2 shall, as soon as is feasible after the report is filed, and no later than one year after the commission of the act or omission, notify in writing any person whose property was lost or seriously damaged as a result of the act or omission.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The competent authority may authorize the senior official not to notify the person under subsection (1) until the competent authority is of the opinion that notification would not
paragraphText: compromise or hinder an ongoing investigation of an offence under an Act of Parliament;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The competent authority may authorize the senior official not to notify the person under subsection (1) until the competent authority is of the opinion that notification would not
paragraphText: compromise the identity of a public officer acting in an undercover capacity, of a confidential informant or of a person acting covertly under the direction and control of a public officer;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The competent authority may authorize the senior official not to notify the person under subsection (1) until the competent authority is of the opinion that notification would not
paragraphText: endanger the life or safety of any person;

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The competent authority may authorize the senior official not to notify the person under subsection (1) until the competent authority is of the opinion that notification would not
paragraphText: prejudice a legal proceeding; or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: The competent authority may authorize the senior official not to notify the person under subsection (1) until the competent authority is of the opinion that notification would not
paragraphText: otherwise be contrary to the public interest.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
sectiontext: Every one who is authorized by law to use force is criminally responsible for any excess thereof according to the nature and quality of the act that constitutes the excess.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to prevent commission of offence
sectiontext: Every one is justified in using as much force as is reasonably necessary

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Use of force on board an aircraft
subsectiontext: Every person on an aircraft in flight is justified in using as much force as is reasonably necessary to prevent the commission of an offence against this Act or another Act of Parliament that the person believes on reasonable grounds, if it were committed, would be likely to cause immediate and serious injury to the aircraft or to any person or property therein.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
marginalnotetext_x: Use of force on board an aircraft
subsectiontext: This section applies in respect of any aircraft in flight in Canadian airspace and in respect of any aircraft registered in Canada in accordance with the regulations made under the Aeronautics Act in flight outside Canadian airspace.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Where a person who is authorized to execute a warrant to arrest believes, in good faith and on reasonable grounds, that the person whom he arrests is the person named in the warrant, he is protected from criminal responsibility in respect thereof to the same extent as if that person were the person named in the warrant.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Where a person is authorized to execute a warrant to arrest,
paragraphText: every one who, being called on to assist him, believes that the person in whose arrest he is called on to assist is the person named in the warrant, and

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Where a person is authorized to execute a warrant to arrest,
paragraphText: every keeper of a prison who is required to receive and detain a person who he believes has been arrested under the warrant,

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: It is the duty of every one who executes a process or warrant to have it with him, where it is feasible to do so, and to produce it when requested to do so.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: It is the duty of every one who arrests a person, whether with or without a warrant, to give notice to that person, where it is feasible to do so, of
paragraphText: the process or warrant under which he makes the arrest; or

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: It is the duty of every one who arrests a person, whether with or without a warrant, to give notice to that person, where it is feasible to do so, of
paragraphText: the reason for the arrest.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Failure to comply with subsection (1) or (2) does not of itself deprive a person who executes a process or warrant, or a person who makes an arrest, or those who assist them, of protection from criminal responsibility.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
sectiontext: Every one who witnesses a breach of the peace is justified in interfering to prevent the continuance or renewal thereof and may detain any person who commits or is about to join in or to renew the breach of the peace, for the purpose of giving him into the custody of a peace officer, if he uses no more force than is reasonably necessary to prevent the continuance or renewal of the breach of the peace or than is reasonably proportioned to the danger to be apprehended from the continuance or renewal of the breach of the peace.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every peace officer who witnesses a breach of the peace and every one who lawfully assists the peace officer is justified in arresting any person whom he finds committing the breach of the peace or who, on reasonable grounds, he believes is about to join in or renew the breach of the peace.

heading2titletext: Protection of Persons Administering and Enforcing the Law
subsectiontext: Every peace officer is justified in receiving into custody any person who is given into his charge as having been a party to a breach of the peace by one who has, or who on reasonable grounds the peace officer believes has, witnessed the breach of the peace.

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every peace officer is justified in using or in ordering the use of as much force as the peace officer believes, in good faith and on reasonable grounds,
paragraphText: is necessary to suppress a riot; and

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every peace officer is justified in using or in ordering the use of as much force as the peace officer believes, in good faith and on reasonable grounds,
paragraphText: is not excessive, having regard to the danger to be apprehended from the continuance of the riot.

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every one who is bound by military law to obey the command of his superior officer is justified in obeying any command given by his superior officer for the suppression of a riot unless the order is manifestly unlawful.

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every one is justified in obeying an order of a peace officer to use force to suppress a riot if
paragraphText: he acts in good faith; and

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every one is justified in obeying an order of a peace officer to use force to suppress a riot if
paragraphText: the order is not manifestly unlawful.

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every one who, in good faith and on reasonable grounds, believes that serious mischief will result from a riot before it is possible to secure the attendance of a peace officer is justified in using as much force as he believes in good faith and on reasonable grounds,
paragraphText: is necessary to suppress the riot; and

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: Every one who, in good faith and on reasonable grounds, believes that serious mischief will result from a riot before it is possible to secure the attendance of a peace officer is justified in using as much force as he believes in good faith and on reasonable grounds,
paragraphText: is not excessive, having regard to the danger to be apprehended from the continuance of the riot.

marginalnotetext_x: Use of force to suppress riot
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, the question whether an order is manifestly unlawful or not is a question of law.

marginalnotetext_x: Duty of officers if rioters do not disperse
subsectiontext: Where the proclamation referred to in section 67 has been made or an offence against paragraph 68(a) or (b) has been committed, it is the duty of a peace officer and of a person who is lawfully required by him to assist, to disperse or to arrest persons who do not comply with the proclamation.

marginalnotetext_x: Duty of officers if rioters do not disperse
subsectiontext: No civil or criminal proceedings lie against a peace officer or a person who is lawfully required by a peace officer to assist him in respect of any death or injury that by reason of resistance is caused as a result of the performance by the peace officer or that person of a duty that is imposed by subsection (1).

marginalnotetext_x: Duty of officers if rioters do not disperse
subsectiontext: Nothing in this section limits or affects any powers, duties or functions that are conferred or imposed by this Act with respect to the suppression of riots.

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: they believe on reasonable grounds that force is being used against them or another person or that a threat of force is being made against them or another person;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: the act that constitutes the offence is committed for the purpose of defending or protecting themselves or the other person from that use or threat of force; and

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances.

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: the nature of the force or threat;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: the extent to which the use of force was imminent and whether there were other means available to respond to the potential use of force;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: the person’s role in the incident;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: whether any party to the incident used or threatened to use a weapon;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: the size, age, gender and physical capabilities of the parties to the incident;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: the nature, duration and history of any relationship between the parties to the incident, including any prior use or threat of force and the nature of that force or threat;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: any history of interaction or communication between the parties to the incident;

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: the nature and proportionality of the person’s response to the use or threat of force; and

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: In determining whether the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances, the court shall consider the relevant circumstances of the person, the other parties and the act, including, but not limited to, the following factors:
paragraphText: whether the act committed was in response to a use or threat of force that the person knew was lawful.

marginalnotetext_x: Defence — use or threat of force
subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply if the force is used or threatened by another person for the purpose of doing something that they are required or authorized by law to do in the administration or enforcement of the law, unless the person who commits the act that constitutes the offence believes on reasonable grounds that the other person is acting unlawfully.
A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: they either believe on reasonable grounds that they are in peaceable possession of property or are acting under the authority of, or lawfully assisting, a person whom they believe on reasonable grounds is in peaceable possession of property;

subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: they believe on reasonable grounds that another person
subparagraphText: is about to enter, is entering or has entered the property without being entitled by law to do so,

subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: they believe on reasonable grounds that another person
subparagraphText: is about to take the property, is doing so or has just done so, or

subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: they believe on reasonable grounds that another person
subparagraphText: is about to damage or destroy the property, or make it inoperative, or is doing so;

subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: the act that constitutes the offence is committed for the purpose of
subparagraphText: preventing the other person from entering the property, or removing that person from the property, or

subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: the act that constitutes the offence is committed for the purpose of
subparagraphText: preventing the other person from taking, damaging or destroying the property or from making it inoperative, or retaking the property from that person; and

subsectiontext: A person is not guilty of an offence if
paragraphText: the act committed is reasonable in the circumstances.

subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply if the person who believes on reasonable grounds that they are, or who is believed on reasonable grounds to be, in peaceable possession of the property does not have a claim of right to it and the other person is entitled to its possession by law.

Subsection (1) does not apply if the other person is doing something that they are required or authorized by law to do in the administration or enforcement of the law, unless the person who commits the act that constitutes the offence believes on reasonable grounds that the other person is acting unlawfully.

sectiontext: [Repealed, 2012, c. 9, s. 2]

Every schoolteacher, parent or person standing in the place of a parent is justified in using force by way of correction toward a pupil or child, as the case may be, who is under his care, if the force does not exceed what is reasonable under the circumstances.
Every one is protected from criminal responsibility for performing a surgical operation on any person for the benefit of that person if

subsectiontext: A person who, by reason of self-induced extreme intoxication, lacks the general intent or voluntariness ordinarily required to commit an offence referred to in subsection (3), nonetheless commits the offence if
paragraphText: all the other elements of the offence are present; and

subsectiontext: A person who, by reason of self-induced extreme intoxication, lacks the general intent or voluntariness ordinarily required to commit an offence referred to in subsection (3), nonetheless commits the offence if
paragraphText: before they were in a state of extreme intoxication, they departed markedly from the standard of care expected of a reasonable person in the circumstances with respect to the consumption of intoxicating substances.

subsectiontext: For the purposes of determining whether the person departed markedly from the standard of care, the court must consider the objective foreseeability of the risk that the consumption of the intoxicating substances could cause extreme intoxication and lead the person to harm another person. The court must, in making the determination, also consider all relevant circumstances, including anything that the person did to avoid the risk.

This section applies in respect of an offence under this Act or any other Act of Parliament that includes as an element an assault or any other interference or threat of interference by a person with the bodily integrity of another person.
In this section, extreme intoxication means intoxication that renders a person unaware of, or incapable of consciously controlling, their behaviour.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits high treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: kills or attempts to kill Her Majesty, or does her any bodily harm tending to death or destruction, maims or wounds her, or imprisons or restrains her;

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits high treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: levies war against Canada or does any act preparatory thereto; or

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits high treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: assists an enemy at war with Canada, or any armed forces against whom Canadian Forces are engaged in hostilities, whether or not a state of war exists between Canada and the country whose forces they are.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: uses force or violence for the purpose of overthrowing the government of Canada or a province;

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: without lawful authority, communicates or makes available to an agent of a state other than Canada, military or scientific information or any sketch, plan, model, article, note or document of a military or scientific character that he knows or ought to know may be used by that state for a purpose prejudicial to the safety or defence of Canada;

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: conspires with any person to commit high treason or to do anything mentioned in paragraph (a);

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: forms an intention to do anything that is high treason or that is mentioned in paragraph (a) and manifests that intention by an overt act; or

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one commits treason who, in Canada,
paragraphText: conspires with any person to do anything mentioned in paragraph (b) or forms an intention to do anything mentioned in paragraph (b) and manifests that intention by an overt act.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding subsection (1) or (2), a Canadian citizen or a person who owes allegiance to Her Majesty in right of Canada,
paragraphText: commits high treason if, while in or out of Canada, he does anything mentioned in subsection (1); or

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding subsection (1) or (2), a Canadian citizen or a person who owes allegiance to Her Majesty in right of Canada,
paragraphText: commits treason if, while in or out of Canada, he does anything mentioned in subsection (2).

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Where it is treason to conspire with any person, the act of conspiring is an overt act of treason.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one who commits high treason is guilty of an indictable offence and shall be sentenced to imprisonment for life.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one who commits treason is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to be sentenced to imprisonment for life if he is guilty of an offence under paragraph 46(2)(a), (c) or (d);

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one who commits treason is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to be sentenced to imprisonment for life if he is guilty of an offence under paragraph 46(2)(b) or (e) committed while a state of war exists between Canada and another country; or

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: Every one who commits treason is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to be sentenced to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years if he is guilty of an offence under paragraph 46(2)(b) or (e) committed while no state of war exists between Canada and another country.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of high treason or treason on the evidence of only one witness, unless the evidence of that witness is corroborated in a material particular by evidence that implicates the accused.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: For the purposes of Part XXIII, the sentence of imprisonment for life prescribed by subsection (1) is a minimum punishment.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: No proceedings for an offence of treason as defined by paragraph 46(2)(a) shall be commenced more than three years after the time when the offence is alleged to have been committed.

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: No proceedings shall be commenced under section 47 in respect of an overt act of treason expressed or declared by open and considered speech unless
paragraphText: an information setting out the overt act and the words by which it was expressed or declared is laid under oath before a justice within six days after the time when the words are alleged to have been spoken; and

heading2titletext: Treason and other Offences against the Queen’s Authority and Person
subsectiontext: No proceedings shall be commenced under section 47 in respect of an overt act of treason expressed or declared by open and considered speech unless
paragraphText: a warrant for the arrest of the accused is issued within ten days after the time when the information is laid.

marginalnotetext_x: Assisting alien enemy to leave Canada, or omitting to prevent treason
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: incites or wilfully assists a subject of
subparagraphText: a state that is at war with Canada, or

marginalnotetext_x: Assisting alien enemy to leave Canada, or omitting to prevent treason
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: incites or wilfully assists a subject of
subparagraphText: a state against whose forces Canadian Forces are engaged in hostilities, whether or not a state of war exists between Canada and the state whose forces they are,

marginalnotetext_x: Assisting alien enemy to leave Canada, or omitting to prevent treason
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: knowing that a person is about to commit high treason or treason does not, with all reasonable dispatch, inform a justice of the peace or other peace officer thereof or make other reasonable efforts to prevent that person from committing high treason or treason.

marginalnotetext_x: Assisting alien enemy to leave Canada, or omitting to prevent treason
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

sectiontext: Every one who does an act of violence in order to intimidate Parliament or the legislature of a province is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who does a prohibited act for a purpose prejudicial to
paragraphText: the safety, security or defence of Canada, or

subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who does a prohibited act for a purpose prejudicial to
paragraphText: the safety or security of the naval, army or air forces of any state other than Canada that are lawfully present in Canada.

subsectiontext: In this section, prohibited act means an act or omission that
paragraphText: impairs the efficiency or impedes the working of any vessel, vehicle, aircraft, machinery, apparatus or other thing; or

subsectiontext: In this section, prohibited act means an act or omission that
paragraphText: causes property, by whomever it may be owned, to be lost, damaged or destroyed.

subsectiontext: No person does a prohibited act within the meaning of this section by reason only that
paragraphText: he stops work as a result of the failure of his employer and himself to agree on any matter relating to his employment;

subsectiontext: No person does a prohibited act within the meaning of this section by reason only that
paragraphText: he stops work as a result of the failure of his employer and a bargaining agent acting on his behalf to agree on any matter relating to his employment; or

subsectiontext: No person does a prohibited act within the meaning of this section by reason only that
paragraphText: he stops work as a result of his taking part in a combination of workmen or employees for their own reasonable protection as workmen or employees.

subsectiontext: No person does a prohibited act within the meaning of this section by reason only that he attends at or near or approaches a dwelling-house or place for the purpose only of obtaining or communicating information.

sectiontext: Every one who

Every one who aids, assists, harbours or conceals a person who he knows is a deserter or absentee without leave from the Canadian Forces is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction, but no proceedings shall be instituted under this section without the consent of the Attorney General of Canada.

In proceedings for an offence against any provision in section 47 or sections 50 to 53, evidence of an overt act is not admissible unless that overt act is set out in the indictment or unless the evidence is otherwise relevant as tending to prove an overt act that is set out in the indictment.

subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, without lawful excuse, procures to be made, possesses, transfers, sells or offers for sale an identity document that relates or purports to relate, in whole or in part, to another person.
For greater certainty, subsection (1) does not prohibit an act that is carried out
paragraphText: in good faith, in the ordinary course of the person’s business or employment or in the exercise of the duties of their office;

subsectiontext: For greater certainty, subsection (1) does not prohibit an act that is carried out
paragraphText: for genealogical purposes;

subsectiontext: For greater certainty, subsection (1) does not prohibit an act that is carried out
paragraphText: with the consent of the person to whom the identity document relates or of a person authorized to consent on behalf of the person to whom the document relates, or of the entity that issued the identity document; or

subsectiontext: For greater certainty, subsection (1) does not prohibit an act that is carried out
paragraphText: for a legitimate purpose related to the administration of justice.

subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, identity document means a Social Insurance Number card, a driver’s licence, a health insurance card, a birth certificate, a death certificate, a passport as defined in subsection 57(5), a document that simplifies the process of entry into Canada, a certificate of citizenship, a document indicating immigration status in Canada, a certificate of Indian status or an employee identity card that bears the employee’s photograph and signature, or any similar document, issued or purported to be issued by a department or agency of the federal government or of a provincial or foreign government.
Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1)
paragraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1)
paragraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

subsectiontext: Where a person is alleged to have committed, while out of Canada, an offence under this section, proceedings in respect of that offence may, whether or not that person is in Canada, be commenced in any territorial division in Canada and the accused may be tried and punished in respect of that offence in the same manner as if the offence had been committed in that territorial division.

subsectiontext: For greater certainty, the provisions of this Act relating to

subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who, while in or outside Canada,
paragraphText: uses a certificate of citizenship or a certificate of naturalization for a fraudulent purpose, or

subsectiontext: In this section, certificate of citizenship and certificate of naturalization, respectively, mean a certificate of citizenship and a certificate of naturalization as defined by the Citizenship Act.
Seditious words are words that express a seditious intention.
A seditious libel is a libel that expresses a seditious intention.
A seditious conspiracy is an agreement between two or more persons to carry out a seditious intention.
Without limiting the generality of the meaning of the expression seditious intention, every one shall be presumed to have a seditious intention who

marginalnotetext_x: Offences in relation to military forces

subsectiontext: An unlawful assembly is an assembly of three or more persons who, with intent to carry out any common purpose, assemble in such a manner or so conduct themselves when they are assembled as to cause persons in the neighbourhood of the assembly to fear, on reasonable grounds, that they
paragraphText: will disturb the peace tumultuously; or

subsectiontext: An unlawful assembly is an assembly of three or more persons who, with intent to carry out any common purpose, assemble in such a manner or so conduct themselves when they are assembled as to cause persons in the neighbourhood of the assembly to fear, on reasonable grounds, that they
paragraphText: will by that assembly needlessly and without reasonable cause provoke other persons to disturb the peace tumultuously.

subsectiontext: Persons who are lawfully assembled may become an unlawful assembly if they conduct themselves with a common purpose in a manner that would have made the assembly unlawful if they had assembled in that manner for that purpose.

Persons are not unlawfully assembled by reason only that they are assembled to protect the dwelling-house of any one of them against persons who are threatening to break and enter it for the purpose of committing an indictable offence therein.

sectiontext: A riot is an unlawful assembly that has begun to disturb the peace tumultuously.

subsectiontext: Every one who is a member of an unlawful assembly is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

subsectiontext: The Governor in Council may, by proclamation, make orders
paragraphText: to prohibit assemblies, without lawful authority, of persons for the purpose

subsectiontext: An order that is made under subsection (1) may be general or may be made applicable to particular places, districts or assemblies to be specified in the order.
Every person who contravenes an order made under this section is guilty of

sectiontext: [Repealed, 2018, c. 29, s. 4]

subsectiontext: A person commits forcible entry when that person enters real property that is in the actual and peaceable possession of another in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace.

For the purposes of subsection (1), it is immaterial whether or not a person is entitled to enter the real property or whether or not that person has any intention of taking possession of the real property.

A person commits forcible detainer when, being in actual possession of real property without colour of right, he detains it in a manner that is likely to cause a breach of the peace or reasonable apprehension of a breach of the peace, against a person who is entitled by law to possession of it.
The questions whether a person is in actual and peaceable possession or is in actual possession without colour of right are questions of law.

subsectiontext: Every one commits piracy who does any act that, by the law of nations, is piracy.
Every one who commits piracy while in or out of Canada is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

subsectiontext: In this section,

sectiontext: Every one who has an explosive substance in his possession or under his care or control is under a legal duty to use reasonable care to prevent bodily harm or death to persons or damage to property by that explosive substance.

Every one who, being under a legal duty within the meaning of section 79, fails without lawful excuse to perform that duty, is guilty of an indictable offence and, if as a result an explosion of an explosive substance occurs that

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: does anything with intent to cause an explosion of an explosive substance that is likely to cause serious bodily harm or death to persons or is likely to cause serious damage to property;

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: with intent to do bodily harm to any person
subparagraphText: causes an explosive substance to explode,

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: with intent to do bodily harm to any person
subparagraphText: sends or delivers to a person or causes a person to take or receive an explosive substance or any other dangerous substance or thing, or

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: with intent to do bodily harm to any person
subparagraphText: places or throws anywhere or at or on a person a corrosive fluid, explosive substance or any other dangerous substance or thing;

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: with intent to destroy or damage property without lawful excuse, places or throws an explosive substance anywhere; or

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: makes or has in his possession or has under his care or control any explosive substance with intent thereby
subparagraphText: to endanger life or to cause serious damage to property, or

subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: makes or has in his possession or has under his care or control any explosive substance with intent thereby
subparagraphText: to enable another person to endanger life or to cause serious damage to property.

subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: for an offence under paragraph (1)(a) or (b), to imprisonment for life; or

subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: for an offence under paragraph (1)(c) or (d), to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

subsectiontext: Every person who, without lawful excuse, makes or has in their possession or under their care or control any explosive substance for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years.
Every person who, without lawful excuse, makes or has in their possession or under their care or control any explosive substance is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

subsectiontext: Every person who, without lawful excuse, makes or has in their possession or under their care or control any explosive substance is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

sectiontext: A sentence imposed on a person for an offence under subsection 82(2) shall be served consecutively to any other punishment imposed on the person for an offence arising out of the same event or series of events and to any other sentence to which the person is subject at the time the sentence is imposed on the person for an offence under subsection 82(2).
For the purposes of sections 82.3 to 82.5, device means any of the following:

marginalnotetext_x: Possession, etc., of nuclear material, radioactive material or device
sectiontext: Everyone who, with intent to cause death, serious bodily harm or substantial damage to property or the environment, makes a device or possesses, uses, transfers, exports, imports, alters or disposes of nuclear material, radioactive material or a device or commits an act against a nuclear facility or an act that causes serious interference with or serious disruption of its operations, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

marginalnotetext_x: Use or alteration of nuclear material, radioactive material or device
sectiontext: Everyone who, with intent to compel a person, government or international organization to do or refrain from doing any act, uses or alters nuclear material, radioactive material or a device or commits an act against a nuclear facility or an act that causes serious interference with or serious disruption of its operations, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

marginalnotetext_x: Commission of indictable offence to obtain nuclear material, etc.
sectiontext: Everyone who commits an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament, with intent to obtain nuclear material, radioactive material or a device or to obtain access to a nuclear facility, is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for life.
Everyone who threatens to commit an offence under any of sections 82.3 to 82.5 is guilty of an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years.

For greater certainty, sections 82.3 to 82.6 do not apply to an act that is committed during an armed conflict and that, at the time and in the place of its commission, is in accordance with customary international law or conventional international law applicable to the conflict, or to activities undertaken by military forces of a state in the exercise of their official duties, to the extent that those activities are governed by other rules of international law.

subsectiontext: Every one who
paragraphText: engages as a principal in a prize fight,

subsectiontext: Every one who
paragraphText: advises, encourages or promotes a prize fight, or

subsectiontext: Every one who
paragraphText: is present at a prize fight as an aid, second, surgeon, umpire, backer or reporter,

subsectiontext: In this section, prize fight means an encounter or fight with fists, hands or feet between two persons who have met for that purpose by previous arrangement made by or for them, but does not include
paragraphText: a contest between amateur athletes in a combative sport with fists, hands or feet held in a province if the sport is on the programme of the International Olympic Committee or the International Paralympic Committee and, in the case where the province’s lieutenant governor in council or any other person or body specified by him or her requires it, the contest is held with their permission;

subsectiontext: In this section, prize fight means an encounter or fight with fists, hands or feet between two persons who have met for that purpose by previous arrangement made by or for them, but does not include
paragraphText: a contest between amateur athletes in a combative sport with fists, hands or feet held in a province if the sport has been designated by the province’s lieutenant governor in council or by any other person or body specified by him or her and, in the case where the lieutenant governor in council or other specified person or body requires it, the contest is held with their permission;

subsectiontext: In this section, prize fight means an encounter or fight with fists, hands or feet between two persons who have met for that purpose by previous arrangement made by or for them, but does not include
paragraphText: a contest between amateur athletes in a combative sport with fists, hands or feet held in a province with the permission of the province’s lieutenant governor in council or any other person or body specified by him or her; and

subsectiontext: In this section, prize fight means an encounter or fight with fists, hands or feet between two persons who have met for that purpose by previous arrangement made by or for them, but does not include
paragraphText: a boxing contest or mixed martial arts contest held in a province with the permission or under the authority of an athletic board, commission or similar body established by or under the authority of the province’s legislature for the control of sport within the province.

subsectiontext: The following definitions apply in this Part.

For greater certainty, the expression of a political, religious or ideological thought, belief or opinion does not come within paragraph (b) of the definition terrorist activity in subsection (1) unless it constitutes an act or omission that satisfies the criteria of that paragraph.
For greater certainty, a suicide bombing is an act that comes within paragraph (a) or (b) of the definition terrorist activity in subsection (1) if it satisfies the criteria of that paragraph.
For the purposes of this Part, facilitation shall be construed in accordance with subsection 83.19(2).

marginalnotetext_x: Providing or collecting property for certain activities
sectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years who, directly or indirectly, wilfully and without lawful justification or excuse, provides or collects property intending that it be used or knowing that it will be used, in whole or in part, in order to carry out

marginalnotetext_x: Providing, making available, etc., property or services for terrorist purposes
sectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years who, directly or indirectly, collects property, provides or invites a person to provide, or makes available property or financial or other related services

marginalnotetext_x: Using or possessing property for terrorist purposes
sectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years who

subsectiontext: The Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish a list on which the Governor in Council may place any entity if, on the recommendation of the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, the Governor in Council is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that
paragraphText: the entity has knowingly carried out, attempted to carry out, participated in or facilitated a terrorist activity; or

subsectiontext: The Governor in Council may, by regulation, establish a list on which the Governor in Council may place any entity if, on the recommendation of the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, the Governor in Council is satisfied that there are reasonable grounds to believe that
paragraphText: the entity has knowingly acted on behalf of, at the direction of or in association with an entity referred to in paragraph (a).

subsectiontext: The Minister may make a recommendation referred to in subsection (1) only if he or she has reasonable grounds to believe that the entity to which the recommendation relates is an entity referred to in paragraph (1)(a) or (b).
The Minister shall give notice without delay to the applicant of any decision taken or deemed to have been taken respecting the application referred to in subsection (2).
Within 60 days after the receipt of the notice of the decision referred to in subsection (4), the applicant may apply to a judge for judicial review of the decision.
When an application is made under subsection (5), the judge shall, without delay
paragraphText: provide the applicant with a statement summarizing the information available to the judge so as to enable the applicant to be reasonably informed of the reasons for the decision, without disclosing any information the disclosure of which would, in the judge’s opinion, injure national security or endanger the safety of any person;

subsectiontext: When an application is made under subsection (5), the judge shall, without delay
paragraphText: provide the applicant with a reasonable opportunity to be heard; and

subsectiontext: When an application is made under subsection (5), the judge shall, without delay
paragraphText: determine whether the decision is reasonable on the basis of the information available to the judge and, if found not to be reasonable, order that the applicant no longer be a listed entity.

subsectiontext: When an application is made under subsection (5), the judge shall, without delay
paragraphText: examine, in private, any security or criminal intelligence reports considered in the making of the decision on whether the applicant should remain a listed entity and hear any other evidence or information that may be presented by or on behalf of the Minister and may, at his or her request, hear all or part of that evidence or information in the absence of the applicant and any counsel representing the applicant, if the judge is of the opinion that the disclosure of the information would injure national security or endanger the safety of any person;

subsectiontext: The judge may receive into evidence anything that, in the opinion of the judge, is reliable and appropriate, even if it would not otherwise be admissible under Canadian law, and may base his or her decision on that evidence.
The Minister shall cause to be published, without delay, in the Canada Gazette notice of a final order of a court that the applicant no longer be a listed entity.
In this section, judge means the Chief Justice of the Federal Court or a judge of that Court designated by the Chief Justice.
The Minister may, by regulation,
marginalnotetext_y: Amendment to name of listed entity
paragraphText: change the name of a listed entity, or add to the list any other name by which a listed entity may also be or have been known, if the Minister has reasonable grounds to believe that the listed entity is using a name that is not on the list; and

subsectiontext: The Minister may, by regulation,
marginalnotetext_y: Amendment to name of listed entity
paragraphText: delete from the list any other name by which a listed entity may also have been known, if the entity is no longer using that name.

subsectiontext: On application in writing by a listed entity to be removed from the list, the Minister shall decide whether the applicant should remain a listed entity or whether the Minister should recommend to the Governor in Council that the applicant be removed from the list, taking into account the grounds set out in subsection (1).

If the Minister does not make a decision on the application referred to in subsection (2) within 90 days after receipt of the application, or within any longer period that may be agreed to in writing by the Minister and the applicant, the Minister is deemed to have decided that the applicant should remain a listed entity.
A listed entity may not make another application under subsection (2) except if, since the time when the entity made its last application,
paragraphText: there has been a material change in its circumstances; or

subsectiontext: A listed entity may not make another application under subsection (2) except if, since the time when the entity made its last application,
paragraphText: the Minister has completed a review under subsection (8.1) with respect to that entity.

subsectiontext: The Minister shall review whether there are still reasonable grounds, as set out in subsection (1), for an entity to be a listed entity and make a recommendation to the Governor in Council as to whether the entity should remain a listed entity
paragraphText: within five years after
subparagraphText: the day on which this subsection comes into force, if the entity is a listed entity on that day, or

subsectiontext: The Minister shall review whether there are still reasonable grounds, as set out in subsection (1), for an entity to be a listed entity and make a recommendation to the Governor in Council as to whether the entity should remain a listed entity
paragraphText: within five years after
subparagraphText: the day on which the entity is added to the list, if the entity is added to the list after the day on which this subsection comes into force; and

subsectiontext: The Minister shall review whether there are still reasonable grounds, as set out in subsection (1), for an entity to be a listed entity and make a recommendation to the Governor in Council as to whether the entity should remain a listed entity
paragraphText: subsequently, within five years after the most recent recommendation made under this subsection with respect to the entity.

subsectiontext: Reviews undertaken under subsection (8.1) do not affect the validity of the list.

The Minister shall cause notice of the results of every review of a listed entity undertaken under subsection (8.1) to be published in the Canada Gazette within five years after the review is completed.

marginalnotetext_x: Admission of foreign information obtained in confidence
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection 83.05(6), in private and in the absence of the applicant or any counsel representing it,
paragraphText: the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness may make an application to the judge for the admission of information obtained in confidence from a government, an institution or an agency of a foreign state, from an international organization of states or from an institution or an agency of an international organization of states; and

marginalnotetext_x: Admission of foreign information obtained in confidence
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection 83.05(6), in private and in the absence of the applicant or any counsel representing it,
paragraphText: the judge shall examine the information and provide counsel representing the Minister with a reasonable opportunity to be heard as to whether the information is relevant but should not be disclosed to the applicant or any counsel representing it because the disclosure would injure national security or endanger the safety of any person.

marginalnotetext_x: Admission of foreign information obtained in confidence
subsectiontext: The information shall be returned to counsel representing the Minister and shall not be considered by the judge in making the determination under paragraph 83.05(6)(d), if
paragraphText: the judge determines that the information is not relevant;

marginalnotetext_x: Admission of foreign information obtained in confidence
subsectiontext: The information shall be returned to counsel representing the Minister and shall not be considered by the judge in making the determination under paragraph 83.05(6)(d), if
paragraphText: the judge determines that the information is relevant but should be summarized in the statement to be provided under paragraph 83.05(6)(b); or

marginalnotetext_x: Admission of foreign information obtained in confidence
subsectiontext: The information shall be returned to counsel representing the Minister and shall not be considered by the judge in making the determination under paragraph 83.05(6)(d), if
paragraphText: the Minister withdraws the application.

marginalnotetext_x: Admission of foreign information obtained in confidence
subsectiontext: If the judge decides that the information is relevant but that its disclosure would injure national security or endanger the safety of persons, the information shall not be disclosed in the statement mentioned in paragraph 83.05(6)(b), but the judge may base the determination under paragraph 83.05(6)(d) on it.

An entity whose name is the same as or similar to a name, appearing on the list, of a listed entity and who claims not to be that listed entity may apply in writing to the Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness for a certificate stating that it is not that listed entity.
The Minister shall, within 30 days after receiving the application, issue a certificate if he or she is satisfied that the applicant is not that listed entity.
No person in Canada and no Canadian outside Canada shall knowingly
paragraphText: deal directly or indirectly in any property that is owned or controlled by or on behalf of a terrorist group;

subsectiontext: No person in Canada and no Canadian outside Canada shall knowingly
paragraphText: enter into or facilitate, directly or indirectly, any transaction in respect of property referred to in paragraph (a); or

subsectiontext: No person in Canada and no Canadian outside Canada shall knowingly
paragraphText: provide any financial or other related services in respect of property referred to in paragraph (a) to, for the benefit of or at the direction of a terrorist group.

subsectiontext: A person who acts reasonably in taking, or omitting to take, measures to comply with subsection (1) shall not be liable in any civil action arising from having taken or omitted to take the measures, if they took all reasonable steps to satisfy themselves that the relevant property was owned or controlled by or on behalf of a terrorist group.

The Minister of Public Safety and Emergency Preparedness, or a person designated by him or her, may authorize any person in Canada or any Canadian outside Canada to carry out a specified activity or transaction that is prohibited by section 83.08, or a class of such activities or transactions.
