subsectiontext: This section applies to the printing or publishing, or causing to be printed or published, of any advertisement, scheme, proposal or plan of any foreign lottery, and the sale or offer for sale of any ticket, chance or share, in any such lottery, or the advertisement for sale of such ticket, chance or share, and the conducting or managing of any such scheme, contrivance or operation for determining the winners in any such lottery.

marginalnotetext_x: Offence in relation to lotteries and games of chance
subsectiontext: This section does not apply to
paragraphText: the division by lot or chance of any property by joint tenants or tenants in common, or persons having joint interests in any such property; or

marginalnotetext_x: Offence in relation to lotteries and games of chance
subsectiontext: This section does not apply to

marginalnotetext_x: Offence in relation to lotteries and games of chance
subsectiontext: This section does not apply to
paragraphText: bonds, debentures, debenture stock or other securities recallable by drawing of lots and redeemable with interest and providing for payment of premiums on redemption or otherwise.

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for the government of a province, either alone or in conjunction with the government of another province, to conduct and manage a lottery scheme in that province, or in that and the other province, in accordance with any law enacted by the legislature of that province;

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for a charitable or religious organization, pursuant to a licence issued by the Lieutenant Governor in Council of a province or by such other person or authority in the province as may be specified by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof, to conduct and manage a lottery scheme in that province if the proceeds from the lottery scheme are used for a charitable or religious object or purpose;

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for the board of a fair or of an exhibition, or an operator of a concession leased by that board, to conduct and manage a lottery scheme in a province where the Lieutenant Governor in Council of the province or such other person or authority in the province as may be specified by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof has
subparagraphText: designated that fair or exhibition as a fair or exhibition where a lottery scheme may be conducted and managed, and

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for the board of a fair or of an exhibition, or an operator of a concession leased by that board, to conduct and manage a lottery scheme in a province where the Lieutenant Governor in Council of the province or such other person or authority in the province as may be specified by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof has
subparagraphText: issued a licence for the conduct and management of a lottery scheme to that board or operator;

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for any person, pursuant to a licence issued by the Lieutenant Governor in Council of a province or by such other person or authority in the province as may be specified by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof, to conduct and manage a lottery scheme at a public place of amusement in that province if
subparagraphText: the amount or value of each prize awarded does not exceed five hundred dollars, and

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for any person, pursuant to a licence issued by the Lieutenant Governor in Council of a province or by such other person or authority in the province as may be specified by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof, to conduct and manage a lottery scheme at a public place of amusement in that province if
subparagraphText: the money or other valuable consideration paid to secure a chance to win a prize does not exceed two dollars;

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for the government of a province to agree with the government of another province that lots, cards or tickets in relation to a lottery scheme that is by any of paragraphs (a) to (d) authorized to be conducted and managed in that other province may be sold in the province;

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for any person, pursuant to a licence issued by the Lieutenant Governor in Council of a province or such other person or authority in the province as may be designated by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof, to conduct and manage in the province a lottery scheme that is authorized to be conducted and managed in one or more other provinces where the authority by which the lottery scheme was first authorized to be conducted and managed consents thereto;

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for any person, for the purpose of a lottery scheme that is lawful in a province under any of paragraphs (a) to (f), to do anything in the province, in accordance with the applicable law or licence, that is required for the conduct, management or operation of the lottery scheme or for the person to participate in the scheme; and

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful
paragraphText: for any person to make or print anywhere in Canada or to cause to be made or printed anywhere in Canada anything relating to gaming and betting that is to be used in a place where it is or would, if certain conditions provided by law are met, be lawful to use such a thing, or to send, transmit, mail, ship, deliver or allow to be sent, transmitted, mailed, shipped or delivered or to accept for carriage or transport or convey any such thing where the destination thereof is such a place.

subsectiontext: Subject to this Act, a licence issued by or under the authority of the Lieutenant Governor in Council of a province as described in paragraph (1)(b), (c), (d) or (f) may contain such terms and conditions relating to the conduct, management and operation of or participation in the lottery scheme to which the licence relates as the Lieutenant Governor in Council of that province, the person or authority in the province designated by the Lieutenant Governor in Council thereof or any law enacted by the legislature of that province may prescribe.
Every one who, for the purposes of a lottery scheme, does anything that is not authorized by or pursuant to a provision of this section
paragraphText: in the case of the conduct, management or operation of that lottery scheme,
subparagraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or

subsectiontext: Every one who, for the purposes of a lottery scheme, does anything that is not authorized by or pursuant to a provision of this section
paragraphText: in the case of the conduct, management or operation of that lottery scheme,
subparagraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction; or

subsectiontext: Every one who, for the purposes of a lottery scheme, does anything that is not authorized by or pursuant to a provision of this section
paragraphText: in the case of participating in that lottery scheme, is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

subsectiontext: In this section, lottery scheme means a game or any proposal, scheme, plan, means, device, contrivance or operation described in any of paragraphs 206(1)(a) to (g), whether or not it involves betting, pool selling or a pool system of betting other than
paragraphText: three-card monte, punch board or coin table;

subsectiontext: In this section, lottery scheme means a game or any proposal, scheme, plan, means, device, contrivance or operation described in any of paragraphs 206(1)(a) to (g), whether or not it involves betting, pool selling or a pool system of betting other than
paragraphText: for the purposes of paragraphs (1)(b) to (f), a game or proposal, scheme, plan, means, device, contrivance or operation described in any of paragraphs 206(1)(a) to (g) that is operated on or through a computer, video device, slot machine or a dice game.

subsectiontext: In this section, lottery scheme means a game or any proposal, scheme, plan, means, device, contrivance or operation described in any of paragraphs 206(1)(a) to (g), whether or not it involves betting, pool selling or a pool system of betting other than
paragraphText: bookmaking, pool selling or the making or recording of bets, including bets made through the agency of a pool or pari-mutuel system, on any horse-race; or

subsectiontext: In paragraph 4(c), slot machine means any automatic machine or slot machine, other than any automatic machine or slot machine that dispenses as prizes only one or more free games on that machine, that
paragraphText: is used or intended to be used for any purpose other than selling merchandise or services; or

subsectiontext: In paragraph 4(c), slot machine means any automatic machine or slot machine, other than any automatic machine or slot machine that dispenses as prizes only one or more free games on that machine, that
paragraphText: is used or intended to be used for the purpose of selling merchandise or services if
subparagraphText: the result of one of any number of operations of the machine is a matter of chance or uncertainty to the operator,

subsectiontext: In paragraph 4(c), slot machine means any automatic machine or slot machine, other than any automatic machine or slot machine that dispenses as prizes only one or more free games on that machine, that
paragraphText: is used or intended to be used for the purpose of selling merchandise or services if
subparagraphText: as a result of a given number of successive operations by the operator, the machine produces different results, or

subsectiontext: In paragraph 4(c), slot machine means any automatic machine or slot machine, other than any automatic machine or slot machine that dispenses as prizes only one or more free games on that machine, that
paragraphText: is used or intended to be used for the purpose of selling merchandise or services if
subparagraphText: on any operation of the machine, it discharges or emits a slug or token.

subsectiontext: The use of a computer for the sale of a ticket, selection of a winner or the distribution of a prize in a raffle, including a 50/50 draw, is excluded from paragraph (4)(c) in so far as the raffle is authorized under paragraph (1)(b) and the proceeds are used for a charitable or religious object or purpose.

For greater certainty, nothing in this section shall be construed as authorizing the making or recording of bets on horse-races through the agency of a pari-mutuel system other than in accordance with section 204.

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Despite any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful for the owner or operator of an international cruise ship, or their agent, to conduct, manage or operate and for any person to participate in a lottery scheme during a voyage on an international cruise ship when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
paragraphText: all the people participating in the lottery scheme are located on the ship;

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Despite any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful for the owner or operator of an international cruise ship, or their agent, to conduct, manage or operate and for any person to participate in a lottery scheme during a voyage on an international cruise ship when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
paragraphText: the lottery scheme is not linked, by any means of communication, with any lottery scheme, betting, pool selling or pool system of betting located off the ship;

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Despite any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful for the owner or operator of an international cruise ship, or their agent, to conduct, manage or operate and for any person to participate in a lottery scheme during a voyage on an international cruise ship when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
paragraphText: the lottery scheme is not operated within five nautical miles of a Canadian port at which the ship calls or is scheduled to call; and

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Despite any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful for the owner or operator of an international cruise ship, or their agent, to conduct, manage or operate and for any person to participate in a lottery scheme during a voyage on an international cruise ship when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
paragraphText: the ship is registered
subparagraphText: in Canada and its entire voyage is scheduled to be outside Canada, or

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Despite any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful for the owner or operator of an international cruise ship, or their agent, to conduct, manage or operate and for any person to participate in a lottery scheme during a voyage on an international cruise ship when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
paragraphText: the ship is registered
subparagraphText: anywhere, including Canada, and its voyage includes some scheduled voyaging within Canada and the voyage
clauseText: is of at least forty-eight hours duration and includes some voyaging in international waters and at least one non-Canadian port of call including the port at which the voyage begins or ends, and

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Despite any of the provisions of this Part relating to gaming and betting, it is lawful for the owner or operator of an international cruise ship, or their agent, to conduct, manage or operate and for any person to participate in a lottery scheme during a voyage on an international cruise ship when all of the following conditions are satisfied:
paragraphText: the ship is registered
subparagraphText: anywhere, including Canada, and its voyage includes some scheduled voyaging within Canada and the voyage
clauseText: is not scheduled to disembark any passengers at a Canadian port who have embarked at another Canadian port, without calling on at least one non-Canadian port between the two Canadian ports.

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, paragraph 207(1)(h) and subsection 207(5) apply for the purposes of this section.

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Every one who, for the purpose of a lottery scheme, does anything that is not authorized by this section
paragraphText: in the case of the conduct, management or operation of the lottery scheme,
subparagraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years, or

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Every one who, for the purpose of a lottery scheme, does anything that is not authorized by this section
paragraphText: in the case of the conduct, management or operation of the lottery scheme,
subparagraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction; and

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: Every one who, for the purpose of a lottery scheme, does anything that is not authorized by this section
paragraphText: in the case of participating in the lottery scheme, is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

marginalnotetext_x: Exemption — lottery scheme on an international cruise ship
subsectiontext: The definitions in this subsection apply in this section.

sectiontext: Every person who, with intent to defraud any person, cheats while playing a game or in holding the stakes for a game or in betting is guilty of

[Repealed, 2019, c. 25, s. 73]

[Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 32]
[Repealed, 2014, c. 25, s. 13]

heading2titletext: Offences in Relation to Offering, Providing or Obtaining Sexual Services for Consideration
subsectiontext: Everyone is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who, in a public place or in any place open to public view, for the purpose of offering, providing or obtaining sexual services for consideration,
paragraphText: stops or attempts to stop any motor vehicle; or

heading2titletext: Offences in Relation to Offering, Providing or Obtaining Sexual Services for Consideration
subsectiontext: Everyone is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who, in a public place or in any place open to public view, for the purpose of offering, providing or obtaining sexual services for consideration,
paragraphText: impedes the free flow of pedestrian or vehicular traffic or ingress to or egress from premises adjacent to that place.

heading2titletext: Offences in Relation to Offering, Providing or Obtaining Sexual Services for Consideration
subsectiontext: Everyone is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who, in a public place or in any place open to public view, for the purpose of offering, providing or obtaining sexual services for consideration,
paragraphText: [Repealed, 2014, c. 25, s. 15]

heading2titletext: Offences in Relation to Offering, Providing or Obtaining Sexual Services for Consideration
subsectiontext: Everyone is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who communicates with any person — for the purpose of offering or providing sexual services for consideration  —  in a public place, or in any place open to public view, that is or is next to a school ground, playground or daycare centre.

heading2titletext: Offences in Relation to Offering, Providing or Obtaining Sexual Services for Consideration
subsectiontext: In this section, public place includes any place to which the public have access as of right or by invitation, express or implied, and any motor vehicle located in a public place or in any place open to public view.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: In this Part,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every one is under a legal duty
paragraphText: as a parent, foster parent, guardian or head of a family, to provide necessaries of life for a child under the age of sixteen years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every one is under a legal duty
paragraphText: to provide necessaries of life to their spouse or common-law partner; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every one is under a legal duty
paragraphText: to provide necessaries of life to a person under his charge if that person
subparagraphText: is unable, by reason of detention, age, illness, mental disorder or other cause, to withdraw himself from that charge, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every one is under a legal duty
paragraphText: to provide necessaries of life to a person under his charge if that person
subparagraphText: is unable to provide himself with necessaries of life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, being under a legal duty within the meaning of subsection (1), fails without lawful excuse to perform that duty, if
paragraphText: with respect to a duty imposed by paragraph (1)(a) or (b),
subparagraphText: the person to whom the duty is owed is in destitute or necessitous circumstances, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, being under a legal duty within the meaning of subsection (1), fails without lawful excuse to perform that duty, if
paragraphText: with respect to a duty imposed by paragraph (1)(a) or (b),
subparagraphText: the failure to perform the duty endangers the life of the person to whom the duty is owed, or causes or is likely to cause the health of that person to be endangered permanently; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, being under a legal duty within the meaning of subsection (1), fails without lawful excuse to perform that duty, if
paragraphText: with respect to a duty imposed by paragraph (1)(c), the failure to perform the duty endangers the life of the person to whom the duty is owed or causes or is likely to cause the health of that person to be injured permanently.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (2)
paragraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (2)
paragraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: For the purpose of proceedings under this section,
paragraphText: [Repealed, 2000, c. 12, s. 93]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: For the purpose of proceedings under this section,
paragraphText: evidence that a person has in any way recognized a child as being his child is, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, proof that the child is his child;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: For the purpose of proceedings under this section,
paragraphText: evidence that a person has failed for a period of one month to make provision for the maintenance of any child of theirs under the age of sixteen years is, in the absence of any evidence to the contrary, proof that the person has failed without lawful excuse to provide necessaries of life for the child; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons to provide necessaries
subsectiontext: For the purpose of proceedings under this section,
paragraphText: the fact that a spouse or common-law partner or child is receiving or has received necessaries of life from another person who is not under a legal duty to provide them is not a defence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
marginalnotetext_x: Duty of persons undertaking acts dangerous to life
sectiontext: Every one who undertakes to administer surgical or medical treatment to another person or to do any other lawful act that may endanger the life of another person is, except in cases of necessity, under a legal duty to have and to use reasonable knowledge, skill and care in so doing.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
sectiontext: Every one who undertakes to do an act is under a legal duty to do it if an omission to do the act is or may be dangerous to life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
sectiontext: Every one who undertakes, or has the authority, to direct how another person does work or performs a task is under a legal duty to take reasonable steps to prevent bodily harm to that person, or any other person, arising from that work or task.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Duties Tending to Preservation of Life
sectiontext: Every one who unlawfully abandons or exposes a child who is under the age of ten years, so that its life is or is likely to be endangered or its health is or is likely to be permanently injured,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one is criminally negligent who
paragraphText: in doing anything, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one is criminally negligent who
paragraphText: in omitting to do anything that it is his duty to do,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, duty means a duty imposed by law.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person who by criminal negligence causes death to another person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Causing bodily harm by criminal negligence
sectiontext: Every person who by criminal negligence causes bodily harm to another person is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits homicide when, directly or indirectly, by any means, he causes the death of a human being.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Homicide is culpable or not culpable.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Homicide that is not culpable is not an offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Culpable homicide is murder or manslaughter or infanticide.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits culpable homicide when he causes the death of a human being,
paragraphText: by means of an unlawful act;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits culpable homicide when he causes the death of a human being,
paragraphText: by criminal negligence;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits culpable homicide when he causes the death of a human being,
paragraphText: by causing that human being, by threats or fear of violence or by deception, to do anything that causes his death; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits culpable homicide when he causes the death of a human being,
paragraphText: by wilfully frightening that human being, in the case of a child or sick person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding anything in this section, a person does not commit homicide within the meaning of this Act by reason only that he causes the death of a human being by procuring, by false evidence, the conviction and death of that human being by sentence of the law.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A child becomes a human being within the meaning of this Act when it has completely proceeded, in a living state, from the body of its mother, whether or not
paragraphText: it has breathed;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A child becomes a human being within the meaning of this Act when it has completely proceeded, in a living state, from the body of its mother, whether or not
paragraphText: it has an independent circulation; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A child becomes a human being within the meaning of this Act when it has completely proceeded, in a living state, from the body of its mother, whether or not
paragraphText: the navel string is severed.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits homicide when he causes injury to a child before or during its birth as a result of which the child dies after becoming a human being.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Death that might have been prevented
sectiontext: Where a person, by an act or omission, does any thing that results in the death of a human being, he causes the death of that human being notwithstanding that death from that cause might have been prevented by resorting to proper means.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Where a person causes to a human being a bodily injury that is of itself of a dangerous nature and from which death results, he causes the death of that human being notwithstanding that the immediate cause of death is proper or improper treatment that is applied in good faith.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Where a person causes to a human being a bodily injury that results in death, he causes the death of that human being notwithstanding that the effect of the bodily injury is only to accelerate his death from a disease or disorder arising from some other cause.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Exemption for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: No medical practitioner or nurse practitioner commits culpable homicide if they provide a person with medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Exemption for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: No person is a party to culpable homicide if they do anything for the purpose of aiding a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner to provide a person with medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Exemption for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, the exemption set out in subsection (1) or (2) applies even if the person invoking it has a reasonable but mistaken belief about any fact that is an element of the exemption.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Exemption for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Section 14 does not apply with respect to a person who consents to have death inflicted on them by means of medical assistance in dying provided in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Exemption for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: In this section, medical assistance in dying, medical practitioner and nurse practitioner have the same meanings as in section 241.1.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Killing by influence on the mind
sectiontext: No person commits culpable homicide where he causes the death of a human being

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Culpable homicide is murder

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Murder is first degree murder or second degree murder.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Murder is first degree murder when it is planned and deliberate.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Without limiting the generality of subsection (2), murder is planned and deliberate when it is committed pursuant to an arrangement under which money or anything of value passes or is intended to pass from one person to another, or is promised by one person to another, as consideration for that other’s causing or assisting in causing the death of anyone or counselling another person to do any act causing or assisting in causing that death.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder when the victim is
paragraphText: a police officer, police constable, constable, sheriff, deputy sheriff, sheriff’s officer or other person employed for the preservation and maintenance of the public peace, acting in the course of his duties;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder when the victim is
paragraphText: a warden, deputy warden, instructor, keeper, jailer, guard or other officer or a permanent employee of a prison, acting in the course of his duties; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder when the victim is
paragraphText: a person working in a prison with the permission of the prison authorities and acting in the course of his work therein.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder in respect of a person when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under one of the following sections:
paragraphText: section 76 (hijacking an aircraft);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder in respect of a person when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under one of the following sections:
paragraphText: section 271 (sexual assault);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder in respect of a person when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under one of the following sections:
paragraphText: section 272 (sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder in respect of a person when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under one of the following sections:
paragraphText: section 273 (aggravated sexual assault);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder in respect of a person when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under one of the following sections:
paragraphText: section 279 (kidnapping and forcible confinement); or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder in respect of a person when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under one of the following sections:
paragraphText: section 279.1 (hostage taking).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of any person, murder is first degree murder when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under section 264 and the person committing that offence intended to cause the person murdered to fear for the safety of the person murdered or the safety of anyone known to the person murdered.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of a person, murder is first degree murder when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament if the act or omission constituting the offence also constitutes a terrorist activity.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of a person, murder is first degree murder when
paragraphText: the death is caused by that person for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of a person, murder is first degree murder when
paragraphText: the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an indictable offence under this or any other Act of Parliament for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Irrespective of whether a murder is planned and deliberate on the part of a person, murder is first degree murder when the death is caused by that person while committing or attempting to commit an offence under section 423.1.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: All murder that is not first degree murder is second degree murder.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Culpable homicide that otherwise would be murder may be reduced to manslaughter if the person who committed it did so in the heat of passion caused by sudden provocation.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Conduct of the victim that would constitute an indictable offence under this Act that is punishable by five or more years of imprisonment and that is of such a nature as to be sufficient to deprive an ordinary person of the power of self-control is provocation for the purposes of this section, if the accused acted on it on the sudden and before there was time for their passion to cool.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, the questions
paragraphText: whether the conduct of the victim amounted to provocation under subsection (2), and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, the questions
paragraphText: whether the accused was deprived of the power of self-control by the provocation that he alleges he received,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Culpable homicide that otherwise would be murder is not necessarily manslaughter by reason only that it was committed by a person who was being arrested illegally, but the fact that the illegality of the arrest was known to the accused may be evidence of provocation for the purpose of this section.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: A female person commits infanticide when by a wilful act or omission she causes the death of her newly-born child, if at the time of the act or omission she is not fully recovered from the effects of giving birth to the child and by reason thereof or of the effect of lactation consequent on the birth of the child her mind is then disturbed.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Culpable homicide that is not murder or infanticide is manslaughter.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits first degree murder or second degree murder is guilty of an indictable offence and shall be sentenced to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of Part XXIII, the sentence of imprisonment for life prescribed by this section is a minimum punishment.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person who commits manslaughter is guilty of an indictable offence and liable

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Killing unborn child in act of birth
subsectiontext: Every one who causes the death, in the act of birth, of any child that has not become a human being, in such a manner that, if the child were a human being, he would be guilty of murder, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Killing unborn child in act of birth
subsectiontext: This section does not apply to a person who, by means that, in good faith, he considers necessary to preserve the life of the mother of a child, causes the death of that child.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who attempts by any means to commit murder is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a first offence, five years, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who attempts by any means to commit murder is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a second or subsequent offence, seven years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who attempts by any means to commit murder is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who attempts by any means to commit murder is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case, to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (1)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under this section;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (1)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244 or 244.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (1)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 272 or 273, subsection 279(1) or section 279.1, 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (2), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every one who is an accessory after the fact to murder is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every female person who commits infanticide is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: [Repealed, 2019, c. 25, s. 78]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years who, whether suicide ensues or not,
paragraphText: counsels a person to die by suicide or abets a person in dying by suicide; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years who, whether suicide ensues or not,
paragraphText: aids a person to die by suicide.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No medical practitioner or nurse practitioner commits an offence under paragraph (1)(b) if they provide a person with medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person is a party to an offence under paragraph (1)(b) if they do anything for the purpose of aiding a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner to provide a person with medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No pharmacist who dispenses a substance to a person other than a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner commits an offence under paragraph (1)(b) if the pharmacist dispenses the substance further to a prescription that is written by such a practitioner in providing medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person commits an offence under paragraph (1)(b) if they do anything, at another person’s explicit request, for the purpose of aiding that other person to self-administer a substance that has been prescribed for that other person as part of the provision of medical assist­ance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, no social worker, psychologist, psychiatrist, therapist, medical practitioner, nurse practitioner or other health care professional commits an offence if they provide information to a person on the lawful provision of medical assistance in dying.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, the exemption set out in any of subsections (2) to (5) applies even if the person invoking the exemption has a reasonable but mistaken belief about any fact that is an element of the exemption.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In this section, medical assistance in dying, medical practitioner, nurse practitioner and pharmacist have the same meanings as in section 241.1.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: The following definitions apply in this section and in sections 241.2 to 241.4.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person may receive medical assistance in dying only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they are eligible — or, but for any applicable minimum period of residence or waiting period, would be eligible — for health services funded by a government in Canada;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person may receive medical assistance in dying only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they are at least 18 years of age and capable of making decisions with respect to their health;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person may receive medical assistance in dying only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they have a grievous and irremediable medical condition;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person may receive medical assistance in dying only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they have made a voluntary request for medical assistance in dying that, in particular, was not made as a result of external pressure; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person may receive medical assistance in dying only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they give informed consent to receive medical assistance in dying after having been informed of the means that are available to relieve their suffering, including palliative care.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person has a grievous and irremediable medical condition only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they have a serious and incurable illness, disease or disability;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person has a grievous and irremediable medical condition only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: they are in an advanced state of irreversible decline in capability; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person has a grievous and irremediable medical condition only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: that illness, disease or disability or that state of decline causes them enduring physical or psychological suffering that is intolerable to them and that cannot be relieved under conditions that they consider acceptable.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: A person has a grievous and irremediable medical condition only if they meet all of the following criteria:
paragraphText: [Repealed, 2021, c. 2, s. 1]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: be of the opinion that the person meets all of the criteria set out in subsection (1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person’s request for medical assist­ance in dying was
subparagraphText: made in writing and signed and dated by the person or by another person under subsection (4), and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person’s request for medical assist­ance in dying was
subparagraphText: signed and dated after the person was informed by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner that the person has a grievous and irremediable medical condition;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person has been informed that they may, at any time and in any manner, withdraw their request;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that another medical practitioner or nurse practitioner has provided a written opinion confirming that the person meets all of the criteria set out in subsection (1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: be satisfied that they and the other medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) are independent;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: be satisfied that the request was signed and dated by the person — or by another person under subsection (4) — before an independent witness who then also signed and dated the request;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: if the person has difficulty communicating, take all necessary measures to provide a reliable means by which the person may understand the information that is provided to them and communicate their decision; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: immediately before providing the medical assist­ance in dying, give the person an opportunity to withdraw their request and ensure that the person gives express consent to receive medical assistance in dying.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3.2), before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, without a prognosis necessarily having been made as to the specific length of time that they have remaining, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: [Repealed, 2021, c. 2, s. 1]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: If the person requesting medical assistance in dying is unable to sign and date the request, another person — who is at least 18 years of age, who understands the nature of the request for medical assistance in dying and who does not know or believe that they are a beneficiary under the will of the person making the request, or a recipient, in any other way, of a financial or other material benefit resulting from that person’s death — may do so in the person’s presence, on the person’s behalf and under the person’s express direction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Any person who is at least 18 years of age and who understands the nature of the request for medical assist­ance in dying may act as an independent witness, except if they
paragraphText: know or believe that they are a beneficiary under the will of the person making the request, or a recipient, in any other way, of a financial or other material benefit resulting from that person’s death;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Any person who is at least 18 years of age and who understands the nature of the request for medical assist­ance in dying may act as an independent witness, except if they
paragraphText: are an owner or operator of any health care facility at which the person making the request is being treated or any facility in which that person resides;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Any person who is at least 18 years of age and who understands the nature of the request for medical assist­ance in dying may act as an independent witness, except if they
paragraphText: are directly involved in providing health care serv­ices to the person making the request; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Any person who is at least 18 years of age and who understands the nature of the request for medical assist­ance in dying may act as an independent witness, except if they
paragraphText: directly provide personal care to the person making the request.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: The medical practitioner or nurse practitioner providing medical assistance in dying and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who provides the opinion referred to in paragraph (3)(e) or (3.1)(e) are independent if they
marginalnotetext_y: Independence — medical practitioners and nurse practitioners
paragraphText: are not a mentor to the other practitioner or responsible for supervising their work;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: The medical practitioner or nurse practitioner providing medical assistance in dying and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who provides the opinion referred to in paragraph (3)(e) or (3.1)(e) are independent if they
marginalnotetext_y: Independence — medical practitioners and nurse practitioners
paragraphText: do not know or believe that they are connected to the other practitioner or to the person making the request in any other way that would affect their objectivity.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: The medical practitioner or nurse practitioner providing medical assistance in dying and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who provides the opinion referred to in paragraph (3)(e) or (3.1)(e) are independent if they
marginalnotetext_y: Independence — medical practitioners and nurse practitioners
paragraphText: do not know or believe that they are a beneficiary under the will of the person making the request, or a recipient, in any other way, of a financial or other material benefit resulting from that person’s death, other than standard compensation for their services relating to the request; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Medical assistance in dying must be provided with reasonable knowledge, care and skill and in accordance with any applicable provincial laws, rules or standards.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: The medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who, in providing medical assistance in dying, prescribes or obtains a substance for that purpose must, before any pharmacist dispenses the substance, inform the pharmacist that the substance is intended for that purpose.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, nothing in this section compels an individual to provide or assist in providing medical assistance in dying.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of paragraph (2)(a), a mental illness is not considered to be an illness, disease or disability.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: be of the opinion that the person meets all of the criteria set out in subsection (1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person’s request for medical assistance in dying was
subparagraphText: made in writing and signed and dated by the person or by another person under subsection (4), and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person’s request for medical assistance in dying was
subparagraphText: signed and dated after the person was informed by a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner that the person has a grievous and irremediable medical condition;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: be satisfied that the request was signed and dated by the person — or by another person under subsection (4) — before an independent witness who then also signed and dated the request;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person has been informed that the person may, at any time and in any manner, withdraw their request;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that another medical practitioner or nurse practitioner has provided a written opinion confirming that the person meets all of the criteria set out in subsection (1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: if neither they nor the other medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) has expertise in the condition that is causing the person’s suffering, ensure that they or the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) consult with a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who has that expertise and share the results of that consultation with the other practitioner;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: be satisfied that they and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) are independent;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that the person has been informed of the means available to relieve their suffering, including, where appropriate, counselling services, mental health and disability support services, community services and palliative care and has been offered consultations with relevant professionals who provide those services or that care;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that they and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) have discussed with the person the reasonable and available means to relieve the person’s suffering and they and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) agree with the person that the person has given serious consideration to those means;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: ensure that there are at least 90 clear days between the day on which the first assessment under this subsection of whether the person meets the criteria set out in subsection (1) begins and the day on which medical assistance in dying is provided to them or — if the assessments have been completed and they and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner referred to in paragraph (e) are both of the opinion that the loss of the person’s capacity to provide consent to receive medical assistance in dying is imminent — any shorter period that the first medical practitioner or nurse practitioner considers appropriate in the circumstances;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: if the person has difficulty communicating, take all necessary measures to provide a reliable means by which the person may understand the information that is provided to them and communicate their decision; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Before a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner provides medical assistance in dying to a person whose natural death is not reasonably foreseeable, taking into account all of their medical circumstances, the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner must
paragraphText: immediately before providing the medical assistance in dying, give the person an opportunity to withdraw their request and ensure that the person gives express consent to receive medical assistance in dying.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: before the person loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying,
subparagraphText: they met all of the criteria set out in subsection (1) and all other safeguards set out in subsection (3) were met,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: before the person loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying,
subparagraphText: they entered into an arrangement in writing with the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner that the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner would administer a substance to cause their death on a specified day,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: before the person loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying,
subparagraphText: they were informed by the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner of the risk of losing the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying prior to the day specified in the arrangement, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: before the person loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying,
subparagraphText: in the written arrangement, they consented to the administration by the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner of a substance to cause their death on or before the day specified in the arrangement if they lost their capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying prior to that day;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: the person has lost the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: the person does not demonstrate, by words, sounds or gestures, refusal to have the substance administered or resistance to its administration; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to a person to cause their death without meeting the requirement set out in paragraph (3)(h) if
paragraphText: the substance is administered to the person in accordance with the terms of the arrangement.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, involuntary words, sounds or gestures made in response to contact do not constitute a demonstration of refusal or resistance for the purposes of paragraph (3.2)(c).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Once a person demonstrates, by words, sounds or gestures, in accordance with subsection (3.2), refusal to have the substance administered or resistance to its administration, medical assistance in dying can no longer be provided to them on the basis of the consent given by them under subparagraph (3.2)(a)(iv).
