heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: In the case of a person who loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying after self-administering a substance, provided to them under this section, so as to cause their own death, a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to cause the death of that person if
paragraphText: before the person loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying, they and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner entered into an arrangement in writing providing that the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner would
subparagraphText: be present at the time the person self-administered the first substance, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: In the case of a person who loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying after self-administering a substance, provided to them under this section, so as to cause their own death, a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to cause the death of that person if
paragraphText: before the person loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying, they and the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner entered into an arrangement in writing providing that the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner would
subparagraphText: administer a second substance to cause the person’s death if, after self-administering the first substance, the person lost the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying and did not die within a specified period;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: In the case of a person who loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying after self-administering a substance, provided to them under this section, so as to cause their own death, a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to cause the death of that person if
paragraphText: the person self-administers the first substance, does not die within the period specified in the arrangement and loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: In the case of a person who loses the capacity to consent to receiving medical assistance in dying after self-administering a substance, provided to them under this section, so as to cause their own death, a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner may administer a substance to cause the death of that person if
paragraphText: the second substance is administered to the person in accordance with the terms of the arrangement.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Despite paragraphs (5)(c) and (d), a person who provides health care services or personal care as their primary occupation and who is paid to provide that care to the person requesting medical assistance in dying is permitted to act as an independent witness, except for
paragraphText: the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who will provide medical assistance in dying to the person; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Eligibility for medical assistance in dying
subsectiontext: Despite paragraphs (5)(c) and (d), a person who provides health care services or personal care as their primary occupation and who is paid to provide that care to the person requesting medical assistance in dying is permitted to act as an independent witness, except for
paragraphText: the medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who provided an opinion under paragraph (3)(e) or (3.1)(e), as the case may be, in respect of the person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the provision and collection, for the purpose of monitoring medical assistance in dying, of information relating to requests for, and the provision of, medical assistance in dying, including
subparagraphText: the form, manner and time in which the information must be provided,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the provision and collection, for the purpose of monitoring medical assistance in dying, of information relating to requests for, and the provision of, medical assistance in dying, including
subparagraphText: the designation of a person as the recipient of the information, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the provision and collection, for the purpose of monitoring medical assistance in dying, of information relating to requests for, and the provision of, medical assistance in dying, including
subparagraphText: the collection of information from coroners and medical examiners;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the provision and collection, for the purpose of monitoring medical assistance in dying, of information relating to requests for, and the provision of, medical assistance in dying, including
subparagraphText: the information to be provided, at various stages, by medical practitioners, nurse practitioners, persons referred to in subsection (1.1) who have the responsibility to carry out preliminary assessments, pharmacists and pharmacy technicians, or by a class of any of them, including
clauseText: the elements considered in the course of the assessments — preliminary or otherwise — of whether a person meets the criteria set out in subsection 241.2(1),

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the provision and collection, for the purpose of monitoring medical assistance in dying, of information relating to requests for, and the provision of, medical assistance in dying, including
subparagraphText: the information to be provided, at various stages, by medical practitioners, nurse practitioners, persons referred to in subsection (1.1) who have the responsibility to carry out preliminary assessments, pharmacists and pharmacy technicians, or by a class of any of them, including
clauseText: information respecting the race or indigenous identity of a person who requests or receives medical assistance in dying, if the person consents to providing this information, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the provision and collection, for the purpose of monitoring medical assistance in dying, of information relating to requests for, and the provision of, medical assistance in dying, including
subparagraphText: the information to be provided, at various stages, by medical practitioners, nurse practitioners, persons referred to in subsection (1.1) who have the responsibility to carry out preliminary assessments, pharmacists and pharmacy technicians, or by a class of any of them, including
clauseText: information — other than information that must be provided in relation to the assessment of eligibility to receive medical assistance in dying and the application of safeguards — respecting any disability, as defined in section 2 of the Accessible Canada Act, of a person who requests or receives medical assistance in dying, if the person consents to providing that information,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the disposal of that information; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the protection, publication, and disclosure of that information;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: respecting the use, analysis and interpretation of that information, including for the purposes of determining the presence of any inequality — including systemic inequality — or disadvantage based on race, Indigenous identity, disability or other characteristics, in medical assistance in dying;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health must make regulations that he or she considers necessary
paragraphText: exempting, on any terms that may be specified, a class of persons from the requirements set out in subsections (1) to (2).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The Minister of Health, after consultation with representatives of the provincial governments responsible for health, must establish guidelines on the information to be included on death certificates in cases where medical assistance in dying has been provided, which may include the way in which to clearly identify medical assist­ance in dying as the manner of death, as well as the illness, disease or disability that prompted the request for medical assistance in dying.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who knowingly fails to comply with subsection (1), a person having the responsibility to carry out preliminary assessments who knowingly fails to comply with subsection (1.1) or a pharmacist or pharmacy technician who knowingly fails to comply with subsection (2),
paragraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to a term of imprisonment of not more than two years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who knowingly fails to comply with subsection (1), a person having the responsibility to carry out preliminary assessments who knowingly fails to comply with subsection (1.1) or a pharmacist or pharmacy technician who knowingly fails to comply with subsection (2),
paragraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who knowingly contravenes the regulations made under subsection (3)
paragraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to a term of imprisonment of not more than two years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who knowingly contravenes the regulations made under subsection (3)
paragraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Unless they are exempted under regulations made under subsection (3), a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who carries out an assessment of whether a person meets the criteria set out in subsection 241.2(1) or who receives a written request for medical assistance in dying must, in accordance with those regulations, provide the information required by those regulations to the recipient designated in those regulations.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Unless they are exempted under regulations made under subsection (3), any person who has the responsibility to carry out preliminary assessments of whether a person meets the criteria set out in subsection 241.2(1) must, in accordance with those regulations, provide the information required by those regulations to the recipient designated in those regulations.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Unless they are exempted under regulations made under subsection (3), a pharmacist who dispenses a substance in connection with the provision of medical assistance in dying, or the person permitted to act as a pharmacy technician under the laws of a province who dispenses a substance to aid a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner in providing a person with medical assistance in dying, must, in accordance with those regulations, provide the information required by those regulations to the recipient designated in those regulations.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In performing his or her functions or duties under subsection (3), the Minister of Health must, when appropriate, consult with the minister responsible for the status of persons with disabilities.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who commits forgery in relation to a request for medical assistance in dying.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who destroys a document that relates to a request for medical assistance in dying with intent to interfere with
paragraphText: another person’s access to medical assistance in dying;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who destroys a document that relates to a request for medical assistance in dying with intent to interfere with
paragraphText: the lawful assessment of a request for medical assistance in dying;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who destroys a document that relates to a request for medical assistance in dying with intent to interfere with
paragraphText: another person invoking an exemption under any of subsections 227(1) or (2), 241(2) to (5) or 245(2); or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who destroys a document that relates to a request for medical assistance in dying with intent to interfere with
paragraphText: the provision by a person of information under section 241.31.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In subsection (2), document has the same meaning as in section 321.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: A medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who, in providing medical assistance in dying, knowingly fails to comply, subject to subsection 241.2(3.2), with all of the requirements set out in paragraphs 241.2(3)(b) to (h) or paragraphs 241.2(3.1)(b) to (k), as the case may be, and with subsection 241.2(8) is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Neglect in Child-birth and Concealing Dead Body
marginalnotetext_x: Neglect to obtain assistance in childbirth
sectiontext: A female person who, being pregnant and about to be delivered, with intent that the child shall not live or with intent to conceal the birth of the child, fails to make provision for reasonable assistance in respect of her delivery is, if the child is permanently injured as a result of the failure or dies immediately before, during or in a short time after birth, as a result of the failure, guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Neglect in Child-birth and Concealing Dead Body
sectiontext: Every person who in any manner disposes of the dead body of a child, with intent to conceal the fact that its mother has been delivered of it, whether the child died before, during or after birth, is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who discharges a firearm at a person with intent to wound, maim or disfigure, to endanger the life of or to prevent the arrest or detention of any person — whether or not that person is the one at whom the firearm is discharged.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a first offence, five years, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a second or subsequent offence, seven years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under this section;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 239, 272 or 273, subsection 279(1) or section 279.1, 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Causing bodily harm with intent — air gun or pistol
sectiontext: Every person who, with intent

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence
paragraphText: who intentionally discharges a firearm into or at a place, knowing that or being reckless as to whether another person is present in the place; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence
paragraphText: who intentionally discharges a firearm while being reckless as to the life or safety of another person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: For the purpose of paragraph (1)(a), place means any building or structure — or part of one — or any motor vehicle, vessel, aircraft, railway vehicle, container or trailer.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization, is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: five years, in the case of a first offence, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization, is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: seven years, in the case of a second or subsequent offence; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and
paragraphText: in any other case, is liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (3)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under this section;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (3)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (3)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 239, 272 or 273, subsection 279(1) or section 279.1, 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (4), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply to
paragraphText: a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner who provides medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Subsection (1) does not apply to
paragraphText: a person who does anything for the purpose of aiding a medical practitioner or nurse practitioner to provide medical assistance in dying in accordance with section 241.2.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: In subsection (2), medical assistance in dying, medical practitioner and nurse practitioner have the same meanings as in section 241.1.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who administers or causes to be administered to any other person or causes any other person to take poison or any other destructive or noxious thing is guilty
paragraphText: of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years, if they did so with intent to endanger the life of or to cause bodily harm to that person; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who administers or causes to be administered to any other person or causes any other person to take poison or any other destructive or noxious thing is guilty
paragraphText: of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years or of an offence punishable on summary conviction, if they did so with intent to aggrieve or annoy that person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Overcoming resistance to commission of offence
sectiontext: Every one who, with intent to enable or assist himself or another person to commit an indictable offence,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who with intent to cause death or bodily harm to a person, whether ascertained or not,
paragraphText: sets or places a trap, device or other thing that is likely to cause death or bodily harm to a person; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who with intent to cause death or bodily harm to a person, whether ascertained or not,
paragraphText: being in occupation or possession of a place, knowingly permits such a trap, device or other thing to remain in that place.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1), in a place kept or used for the purpose of committing another indictable offence, and thereby causes bodily harm to a person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to a term of imprisonment not exceeding fourteen years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) and thereby causes the death of any other person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1), and by doing so causes bodily harm to any other person, is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1), and by doing so causes bodily harm to any other person, is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1), in a place kept or used for the purpose of committing another indictable offence, is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Traps likely to cause bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1), in a place kept or used for the purpose of committing another indictable offence, is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
sectiontext: Every one who, with intent to endanger the safety of any person, places anything on or does anything to any property that is used for or in connection with the transportation of persons or goods by land, water or air that is likely to cause death or bodily harm to persons is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
sectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Duty to safeguard opening in ice
subsectiontext: Every one who makes or causes to be made an opening in ice that is open to or frequented by the public is under a legal duty to guard it in a manner that is adequate to prevent persons from falling in by accident and is adequate to warn them that the opening exists.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Duty to safeguard opening in ice
subsectiontext: Every one who leaves an excavation on land that he owns or of which he has charge or supervision is under a legal duty to guard it in a manner that is adequate to prevent persons from falling in by accident and is adequate to warn them that the excavation exists.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Duty to safeguard opening in ice
subsectiontext: Every one who fails to perform a duty imposed by subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of
paragraphText: manslaughter, if the death of any person results therefrom;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Duty to safeguard opening in ice
subsectiontext: Every one who fails to perform a duty imposed by subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence under section 269, if bodily harm to any person results therefrom; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
marginalnotetext_x: Duty to safeguard opening in ice
subsectiontext: Every one who fails to perform a duty imposed by subsection (1) or (2) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: No person shall, without lawful authority and knowing that another person is harassed or recklessly as to whether the other person is harassed, engage in conduct referred to in subsection (2) that causes that other person reasonably, in all the circumstances, to fear for their safety or the safety of anyone known to them.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: The conduct mentioned in subsection (1) consists of
paragraphText: repeatedly following from place to place the other person or anyone known to them;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: The conduct mentioned in subsection (1) consists of
paragraphText: repeatedly communicating with, either directly or indirectly, the other person or anyone known to them;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: The conduct mentioned in subsection (1) consists of
paragraphText: besetting or watching the dwelling-house, or place where the other person, or anyone known to them, resides, works, carries on business or happens to be; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: The conduct mentioned in subsection (1) consists of
paragraphText: engaging in threatening conduct directed at the other person or any member of their family.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who contravenes this section is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Every person who contravenes this section is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Where a person is convicted of an offence under this section, the court imposing the sentence on the person shall consider as an aggravating factor that, at the time the offence was committed, the person contravened
paragraphText: the terms or conditions of an order made pursuant to section 161 or a recognizance entered into pursuant to section 810, 810.1 or 810.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Where a person is convicted of an offence under this section, the court imposing the sentence on the person shall consider as an aggravating factor that, at the time the offence was committed, the person contravened
paragraphText: the terms or conditions of any other order or recognizance, or of an undertaking, made or entered into under the common law, this Act or any other Act of Parliament or of a provincial legislature that is similar in effect to an order or recognizance referred to in paragraph (a).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
subsectiontext: Where the court is satisfied of the existence of an aggravating factor referred to in subsection (4), but decides not to give effect to it for sentencing purposes, the court shall give reasons for its decision.

heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person

heading2titletext: Bodily Harm and Acts and Omissions Causing Danger to the Person
