heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: If an accused is charged with an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1, 155, 160, 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272, 273, 286.1, 286.2 or 286.3, no corroboration is required for a conviction and the judge shall not instruct the jury that it is unsafe to find the accused guilty in the absence of corroboration.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: The rules relating to evidence of recent complaint are hereby abrogated with respect to offences under sections 151, 152, 153, 153.1 and 155, subsections 160(2) and (3) and sections 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 and 273.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, evidence of sexual reputation, whether general or specific, is not admissible for the purpose of challenging or supporting the credibility of the complainant.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, in any manner, knowingly utters, conveys or causes any person to receive a threat
paragraphText: to cause death or bodily harm to any person;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, in any manner, knowingly utters, conveys or causes any person to receive a threat
paragraphText: to burn, destroy or damage real or personal property; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, in any manner, knowingly utters, conveys or causes any person to receive a threat
paragraphText: to kill, poison or injure an animal or bird that is the property of any person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under paragraph (1)(a) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under paragraph (1)(a) is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under paragraph (1)(b) or (c)
paragraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under paragraph (1)(b) or (c)
paragraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits an assault when
paragraphText: without the consent of another person, he applies force intentionally to that other person, directly or indirectly;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits an assault when
paragraphText: he attempts or threatens, by an act or a gesture, to apply force to another person, if he has, or causes that other person to believe on reasonable grounds that he has, present ability to effect his purpose; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person commits an assault when
paragraphText: while openly wearing or carrying a weapon or an imitation thereof, he accosts or impedes another person or begs.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: This section applies to all forms of assault, including sexual assault, sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm and aggravated sexual assault.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, no consent is obtained where the complainant submits or does not resist by reason of
paragraphText: the application of force to the complainant or to a person other than the complainant;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, no consent is obtained where the complainant submits or does not resist by reason of
paragraphText: threats or fear of the application of force to the complainant or to a person other than the complainant;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, no consent is obtained where the complainant submits or does not resist by reason of
paragraphText: fraud; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, no consent is obtained where the complainant submits or does not resist by reason of
paragraphText: the exercise of authority.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where an accused alleges that he believed that the complainant consented to the conduct that is the subject-matter of the charge, a judge, if satisfied that there is sufficient evidence and that, if believed by the jury, the evidence would constitute a defence, shall instruct the jury, when reviewing all the evidence relating to the determination of the honesty of the accused’s belief, to consider the presence or absence of reasonable grounds for that belief.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every one who commits an assault is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Assault with a weapon or causing bodily harm
sectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who, in committing an assault,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an aggravated assault who wounds, maims, disfigures or endangers the life of the complainant.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an aggravated assault is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, in this section, “wounds” or “maims” includes to excise, infibulate or mutilate, in whole or in part, the labia majora, labia minora or clitoris of a person, except where
paragraphText: a surgical procedure is performed, by a person duly qualified by provincial law to practise medicine, for the benefit of the physical health of the person or for the purpose of that person having normal reproductive functions or normal sexual appearance or function; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, in this section, “wounds” or “maims” includes to excise, infibulate or mutilate, in whole or in part, the labia majora, labia minora or clitoris of a person, except where
paragraphText: the person is at least eighteen years of age and there is no resulting bodily harm.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section and section 265, no consent to the excision, infibulation or mutilation, in whole or in part, of the labia majora, labia minora or clitoris of a person is valid, except in the cases described in paragraphs (3)(a) and (b).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every one who unlawfully causes bodily harm to any person is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Aggravating circumstance — assault against a public transit operator
subsectiontext: When a court imposes a sentence for an offence referred to in paragraph 264.1(1)(a) or any of sections 266 to 269, it shall consider as an aggravating circumstance the fact that the victim of the offence was, at the time of the commission of the offence, a public transit operator engaged in the performance of his or her duty.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Aggravating circumstance — assault against a public transit operator
subsectiontext: The following definitions apply in this section.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every official, or every person acting at the instigation of or with the consent or acquiescence of an official, who inflicts torture on any other person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: It is no defence to a charge under this section that the accused was ordered by a superior or a public authority to perform the act or omission that forms the subject-matter of the charge or that the act or omission is alleged to have been justified by exceptional circumstances, including a state of war, a threat of war, internal political instability or any other public emergency.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In any proceedings over which Parliament has jurisdiction, any statement obtained as a result of the commission of an offence under this section is inadmissible in evidence, except as evidence that the statement was so obtained.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: assaults a public officer or peace officer engaged in the execution of his duty or a person acting in aid of such an officer;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: assaults a person with intent to resist or prevent the lawful arrest or detention of himself or another person; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: assaults a person
subparagraphText: who is engaged in the lawful execution of a process against lands or goods or in making a lawful distress or seizure, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who
paragraphText: assaults a person
subparagraphText: with intent to rescue anything taken under lawful process, distress or seizure.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Assaulting peace officer with weapon or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who, in committing an assault referred to in section 270,
paragraphText: carries, uses or threatens to use a weapon or an imitation of one; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Assaulting peace officer with weapon or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Everyone commits an offence who, in committing an assault referred to in section 270,
paragraphText: causes bodily harm to the complainant.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Assaulting peace officer with weapon or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Everyone who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Assaulting peace officer with weapon or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Everyone who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Everyone who, in committing an assault referred to in section 270, wounds, maims, disfigures or endangers the life of the complainant is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: A sentence imposed on a person for an offence under subsection 270(1) or 270.01(1) or section 270.02 committed against a law enforcement officer, as defined in subsection 445.01(4), shall be served consecutively to any other punishment imposed on the person for an offence arising out of the same event or series of events.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, without the consent of a peace officer, takes or attempts to take a weapon that is in the possession of the peace officer when the peace officer is engaged in the execution of his or her duty.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), weapon means any thing that is designed to be used to cause injury or death to, or to temporarily incapacitate, a person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Everyone who commits a sexual assault is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, in committing a sexual assault,
paragraphText: causes bodily harm to the complainant;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, in committing a sexual assault,
paragraphText: chokes, suffocates or strangles the complainant; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, in committing a sexual assault,
paragraphText: carries, uses or threatens to use a weapon or an imitation of a weapon;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, in committing a sexual assault,
paragraphText: threatens to cause bodily harm to a person other than the complainant;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who, in committing a sexual assault,
paragraphText: is a party to the offence with any other person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a first offence, five years, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a second or subsequent offence, seven years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if the complainant is under the age of 16 years, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of five years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding fourteen years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under this section;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244 or 244.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 239 or 273, subsection 279(1) or section 279.1, 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily harm
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an aggravated sexual assault who, in committing a sexual assault, wounds, maims, disfigures or endangers the life of the complainant.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an aggravated sexual assault is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a first offence, five years, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an aggravated sexual assault is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a second or subsequent offence, seven years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an aggravated sexual assault is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an aggravated sexual assault is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if the complainant is under the age of 16 years, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of five years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an aggravated sexual assault is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case, to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under this section;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244 or 244.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 239 or 272, subsection 279(1) or section 279.1, 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (3), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2) and subsection 265(3), consent means, for the purposes of sections 271, 272 and 273, the voluntary agreement of the complainant to engage in the sexual activity in question.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Consent must be present at the time the sexual activity in question takes place.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The question of whether no consent is obtained under subsection 265(3) or subsection (2) or (3) is a question of law.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), no consent is obtained if
paragraphText: the agreement is expressed by the words or conduct of a person other than the complainant;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), no consent is obtained if
paragraphText: the complainant is unconscious;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), no consent is obtained if
paragraphText: the complainant is incapable of consenting to the activity for any reason other than the one referred to in paragraph (a.1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), no consent is obtained if
paragraphText: the accused induces the complainant to engage in the activity by abusing a position of trust, power or authority;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), no consent is obtained if
paragraphText: the complainant expresses, by words or conduct, a lack of agreement to engage in the activity; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of subsection (1), no consent is obtained if
paragraphText: the complainant, having consented to engage in sexual activity, expresses, by words or conduct, a lack of agreement to continue to engage in the activity.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Nothing in subsection (2) shall be construed as limiting the circumstances in which no consent is obtained.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Where belief in consent not a defence
sectiontext: It is not a defence to a charge under section 271, 272 or 273 that the accused believed that the complainant consented to the activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge, where

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall do anything for the purpose of removing from Canada a person who is ordinarily resident in Canada and who is
paragraphText: under the age of 16 years, with the intention that an act be committed outside Canada that if it were committed in Canada would be an offence against section 151 or 152 or subsection 160(3) or 173(2) in respect of that person;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall do anything for the purpose of removing from Canada a person who is ordinarily resident in Canada and who is
paragraphText: 16 years of age or more but under the age of eighteen years, with the intention that an act be committed outside Canada that if it were committed in Canada would be an offence against section 153 in respect of that person;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall do anything for the purpose of removing from Canada a person who is ordinarily resident in Canada and who is
paragraphText: under the age of 18 years, with the intention that an act be committed outside Canada that, if it were committed in Canada, would be an offence against section 293.1 in respect of that person or under the age of 16 years, with the intention that an act be committed outside Canada that, if it were committed in Canada, would be an offence against section 293.2 in respect of that person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall do anything for the purpose of removing from Canada a person who is ordinarily resident in Canada and who is
paragraphText: under the age of 18 years, with the intention that an act be committed outside Canada that if it were committed in Canada would be an offence against section 155, subsection 160(2) or section 170, 171, 267, 268, 269, 271, 272, 273 or 320.102 in respect of that person; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who contravenes this section is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who contravenes this section is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, evidence that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity, whether with the accused or with any other person, is not admissible to support an inference that, by reason of the sexual nature of that activity, the complainant
paragraphText: is more likely to have consented to the sexual activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, evidence that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity, whether with the accused or with any other person, is not admissible to support an inference that, by reason of the sexual nature of that activity, the complainant
paragraphText: is less worthy of belief.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in subsection (1), evidence shall not be adduced by or on behalf of the accused that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity other than the sexual activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge, whether with the accused or with any other person, unless the judge, provincial court judge or justice determines, in accordance with the procedures set out in sections 278.93 and 278.94, that the evidence
paragraphText: is not being adduced for the purpose of supporting an inference described in subsection (1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in subsection (1), evidence shall not be adduced by or on behalf of the accused that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity other than the sexual activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge, whether with the accused or with any other person, unless the judge, provincial court judge or justice determines, in accordance with the procedures set out in sections 278.93 and 278.94, that the evidence
paragraphText: is relevant to an issue at trial; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in subsection (1), evidence shall not be adduced by or on behalf of the accused that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity other than the sexual activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge, whether with the accused or with any other person, unless the judge, provincial court judge or justice determines, in accordance with the procedures set out in sections 278.93 and 278.94, that the evidence
paragraphText: is of specific instances of sexual activity; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in subsection (1), evidence shall not be adduced by or on behalf of the accused that the complainant has engaged in sexual activity other than the sexual activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge, whether with the accused or with any other person, unless the judge, provincial court judge or justice determines, in accordance with the procedures set out in sections 278.93 and 278.94, that the evidence
paragraphText: has significant probative value that is not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice to the proper administration of justice.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the interests of justice, including the right of the accused to make a full answer and defence;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of sexual assault offences;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: whether there is a reasonable prospect that the evidence will assist in arriving at a just determination in the case;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the need to remove from the fact-finding process any discriminatory belief or bias;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the risk that the evidence may unduly arouse sentiments of prejudice, sympathy or hostility in the jury;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the potential prejudice to the complainant’s personal dignity and right of privacy;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the right of the complainant and of every individual to personal security and to the full protection and benefit of the law; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge, provincial court judge or justice considers relevant.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purpose of this section, sexual activity includes any communication made for a sexual purpose or whose content is of a sexual nature.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: A husband or wife may be charged with an offence under section 271, 272 or 273 in respect of his or her spouse, whether or not the spouses were living together at the time the activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge occurred.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: For the purposes of sections 278.2 to 278.92, record means any form of record that contains personal information for which there is a reasonable expectation of privacy and includes medical, psychiatric, therapeutic, counselling, education, employment, child welfare, adoption and social services records, personal journals and diaries, and records containing personal information the production or disclosure of which is protected by any other Act of Parliament or a provincial legislature, but does not include records made by persons responsible for the investigation or prosecution of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Except in accordance with sections 278.3 to 278.91, no record relating to a complainant or a witness shall be produced to an accused in any proceedings in respect of any of the following offences or in any proceedings in respect of two or more offences at least one of which is any of the following offences:

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Except in accordance with sections 278.3 to 278.91, no record relating to a complainant or a witness shall be produced to an accused in any proceedings in respect of any of the following offences or in any proceedings in respect of two or more offences at least one of which is any of the following offences:
paragraphText: any offence under this Act, as it read from time to time before the day on which this paragraph comes into force, if the conduct alleged would be an offence referred to in paragraph (a) if it occurred on or after that day.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Section 278.1, this section and sections 278.3 to 278.91 apply where a record is in the possession or control of any person, including the prosecutor in the proceedings, unless, in the case of a record in the possession or control of the prosecutor, the complainant or witness to whom the record relates has expressly waived the application of those sections.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In the case of a record in respect of which this section applies that is in the possession or control of the prosecutor, the prosecutor shall notify the accused that the record is in the prosecutor’s possession but, in doing so, the prosecutor shall not disclose the record’s contents.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An accused who seeks production of a record referred to in subsection 278.2(1) must make an application to the judge before whom the accused is to be, or is being, tried.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, an application under subsection (1) may not be made to a judge or justice presiding at any other proceedings, including a preliminary inquiry.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An application must be made in writing and set out
paragraphText: particulars identifying the record that the accused seeks to have produced and the name of the person who has possession or control of the record; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An application must be made in writing and set out
paragraphText: the grounds on which the accused relies to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record exists;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record relates to medical or psychiatric treatment, therapy or counselling that the complainant or witness has received or is receiving;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record relates to the incident that is the subject-matter of the proceedings;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record may disclose a prior inconsistent statement of the complainant or witness;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record may relate to the credibility of the complainant or witness;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record may relate to the reliability of the testimony of the complainant or witness merely because the complainant or witness has received or is receiving psychiatric treatment, therapy or counselling;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record may reveal allegations of sexual abuse of the complainant by a person other than the accused;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record relates to the sexual activity of the complainant with any person, including the accused;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record relates to the presence or absence of a recent complaint;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record relates to the complainant’s sexual reputation; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Any one or more of the following assertions by the accused are not sufficient on their own to establish that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify:
paragraphText: that the record was made close in time to a complaint or to the activity that forms the subject-matter of the charge against the accused.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The accused shall serve the application on the prosecutor, on the person who has possession or control of the record, on the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and on any other person to whom, to the knowledge of the accused, the record relates, at least 60 days before the hearing referred to in subsection 278.4(1) or any shorter interval that the judge may allow in the interests of justice. The accused shall also serve a subpoena issued under Part XXII in Form 16.1 on the person who has possession or control of the record at the same time as the application is served.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge may at any time order that the application be served on any person to whom the judge considers the record may relate.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge shall hold a hearing in camera to determine whether to order the person who has possession or control of the record to produce it to the court for review by the judge.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The person who has possession or control of the record, the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and any other person to whom the record relates may appear and make submissions at the hearing, but they are not compellable as witnesses at the hearing.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge shall, as soon as feasible, inform any person referred to in subsection (2) who participates in the hearing of their right to be represented by counsel.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No order for costs may be made against a person referred to in subsection (2) in respect of their participation in the hearing.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: The judge may order the person who has possession or control of the record to produce the record or part of the record to the court for review by the judge if, after the hearing referred to in subsection 278.4(1), the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: the application was made in accordance with subsections 278.3(2) to (6);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: The judge may order the person who has possession or control of the record to produce the record or part of the record to the court for review by the judge if, after the hearing referred to in subsection 278.4(1), the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: the accused has established that the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: The judge may order the person who has possession or control of the record to produce the record or part of the record to the court for review by the judge if, after the hearing referred to in subsection 278.4(1), the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: the production of the record is necessary in the interests of justice.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: the extent to which the record is necessary for the accused to make a full answer and defence;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: the probative value of the record;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: the nature and extent of the reasonable expectation of privacy with respect to the record;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: whether production of the record is based on a discriminatory belief or bias;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: the potential prejudice to the personal dignity and right to privacy of any person to whom the record relates;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of sexual offences;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the obtaining of treatment by complainants of sexual offences; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record for review
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record for review pursuant to subsection (1), the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates. In particular, the judge shall take the following factors into account:
paragraphText: the effect of the determination on the integrity of the trial process.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where the judge has ordered the production of the record or part of the record for review, the judge shall review it in the absence of the parties in order to determine whether the record or part of the record should be produced to the accused.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge may hold a hearing in camera if the judge considers that it will assist in making the determination.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsections 278.4(2) to (3) apply in the case of a hearing under subsection (2).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: Where the judge is satisfied that the record or part of the record is likely relevant to an issue at trial or to the competence of a witness to testify and its production is necessary in the interests of justice, the judge may order that the record or part of the record that is likely relevant be produced to the accused, subject to any conditions that may be imposed pursuant to subsection (3).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: In determining whether to order the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge shall consider the salutary and deleterious effects of the determination on the accused’s right to make a full answer and defence and on the right to privacy, personal security and equality of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates and, in particular, shall take the factors specified in paragraphs 278.5(2)(a) to (h) into account.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: If the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge may impose conditions on the production to protect the interests of justice and, to the greatest extent possible, the privacy, personal security and equality interests of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates, including, for example, the following conditions:
paragraphText: that the record be edited as directed by the judge;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: If the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge may impose conditions on the production to protect the interests of justice and, to the greatest extent possible, the privacy, personal security and equality interests of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates, including, for example, the following conditions:
paragraphText: that a copy of the record, rather than the original, be produced;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: If the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge may impose conditions on the production to protect the interests of justice and, to the greatest extent possible, the privacy, personal security and equality interests of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates, including, for example, the following conditions:
paragraphText: that the accused and counsel for the accused not disclose the contents of the record to any other person, except with the approval of the court;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: If the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge may impose conditions on the production to protect the interests of justice and, to the greatest extent possible, the privacy, personal security and equality interests of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates, including, for example, the following conditions:
paragraphText: that the record be viewed only at the offices of the court;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: If the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge may impose conditions on the production to protect the interests of justice and, to the greatest extent possible, the privacy, personal security and equality interests of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates, including, for example, the following conditions:
paragraphText: that no copies of the record be made or that restrictions be imposed on the number of copies of the record that may be made; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: If the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge may impose conditions on the production to protect the interests of justice and, to the greatest extent possible, the privacy, personal security and equality interests of the complainant or witness, as the case may be, and of any other person to whom the record relates, including, for example, the following conditions:
paragraphText: that information regarding any person named in the record, such as their address, telephone number and place of employment, be severed from the record.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: Where the judge orders the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the judge shall direct that a copy of the record or part of the record be provided to the prosecutor, unless the judge determines that it is not in the interests of justice to do so.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: The record or part of the record that is produced to the accused pursuant to an order under subsection (1) shall not be used in any other proceedings.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge may order production of record to accused
subsectiontext: Where the judge refuses to order the production of the record or part of the record to the accused, the record or part of the record shall, unless a court orders otherwise, be kept in a sealed package by the court until the later of the expiration of the time for any appeal and the completion of any appeal in the proceedings against the accused, whereupon the record or part of the record shall be returned to the person lawfully entitled to possession or control of it.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge shall provide reasons for ordering or refusing to order the production of the record or part of the record pursuant to subsection 278.5(1) or 278.7(1).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The reasons referred to in subsection (1) shall be entered in the record of the proceedings or, where the proceedings are not recorded, shall be provided in writing.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: the contents of an application made under section 278.3;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: any evidence taken, information given or submissions made at a hearing under subsection 278.4(1) or 278.6(2); or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: the determination of the judge pursuant to subsection 278.5(1) or 278.7(1) and the reasons provided pursuant to section 278.8, unless the judge, after taking into account the interests of justice and the right to privacy of the person to whom the record relates, orders that the determination may be published.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who contravenes subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: For the purposes of sections 675 and 676, a determination to make or refuse to make an order pursuant to subsection 278.5(1) or 278.7(1) is deemed to be a question of law.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: Except in accordance with this section, no record relating to a complainant that is in the possession or control of the accused — and which the accused intends to adduce — shall be admitted in evidence in any proceedings in respect of any of the following offences or in any proceedings in respect of two or more offences at least one of which is any of the following offences:

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: Except in accordance with this section, no record relating to a complainant that is in the possession or control of the accused — and which the accused intends to adduce — shall be admitted in evidence in any proceedings in respect of any of the following offences or in any proceedings in respect of two or more offences at least one of which is any of the following offences:
paragraphText: any offence under this Act, as it read from time to time before the day on which this paragraph comes into force, if the conduct alleged would be an offence referred to in paragraph (a) if it occurred on or after that day.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: The evidence is inadmissible unless the judge, provincial court judge or justice determines, in accordance with the procedures set out in sections 278.93 and 278.94,
paragraphText: if the admissibility of the evidence is subject to section 276, that the evidence meets the conditions set out in subsection 276(2) while taking into account the factors set out in subsection (3); or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: The evidence is inadmissible unless the judge, provincial court judge or justice determines, in accordance with the procedures set out in sections 278.93 and 278.94,
paragraphText: in any other case, that the evidence is relevant to an issue at trial and has significant probative value that is not substantially outweighed by the danger of prejudice to the proper administration of justice.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the interests of justice, including the right of the accused to make a full answer and defence;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of sexual assault offences;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the obtaining of treatment by complainants of sexual offences;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: whether there is a reasonable prospect that the evidence will assist in arriving at a just determination in the case;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the need to remove from the fact-finding process any discriminatory belief or bias;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the risk that the evidence may unduly arouse sentiments of prejudice, sympathy or hostility in the jury;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the potential prejudice to the complainant’s personal dignity and right of privacy;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: the right of the complainant and of every individual to personal security and to the full protection and benefit of the law; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Admissibility — accused in possession of records relating to complainant
subsectiontext: In determining whether evidence is admissible under subsection (2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall take into account
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge, provincial court judge or justice considers relevant.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Application may be made to the judge, provincial court judge or justice by or on behalf of the accused for a hearing under section 278.94 to determine whether evidence is admissible under subsection 276(2) or 278.92(2).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An application referred to in subsection (1) must be made in writing, setting out detailed particulars of the evidence that the accused seeks to adduce and the relevance of that evidence to an issue at trial, and a copy of the application must be given to the prosecutor and to the clerk of the court.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge, provincial court judge or justice shall consider the application with the jury and the public excluded.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If the judge, provincial court judge or justice is satisfied that the application was made in accordance with subsection (2), that a copy of the application was given to the prosecutor and to the clerk of the court at least seven days previously, or any shorter interval that the judge, provincial court judge or justice may allow in the interests of justice and that the evidence sought to be adduced is capable of being admissible under subsection 276(2), the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall grant the application and hold a hearing under section 278.94 to determine whether the evidence is admissible under subsection 276(2) or 278.92(2).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The jury and the public shall be excluded from a hearing to determine whether evidence is admissible under subsection 276(2) or 278.92(2).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The complainant is not a compellable witness at the hearing but may appear and make submissions.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The judge shall, as soon as feasible, inform the complainant who participates in the hearing of their right to be represented by counsel.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall determine whether the evidence, or any part of it, is admissible under subsection 276(2) or 278.92(2) and shall provide reasons for that determination, and
paragraphText: if not all of the evidence is to be admitted, the reasons must state the part of the evidence that is to be admitted;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall determine whether the evidence, or any part of it, is admissible under subsection 276(2) or 278.92(2) and shall provide reasons for that determination, and
paragraphText: the reasons must state the factors referred to in subsection 276(3) or 278.92(3) that affected the determination; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: At the conclusion of the hearing, the judge, provincial court judge or justice shall determine whether the evidence, or any part of it, is admissible under subsection 276(2) or 278.92(2) and shall provide reasons for that determination, and
paragraphText: if all or any part of the evidence is to be admitted, the reasons must state the manner in which that evidence is expected to be relevant to an issue at trial.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The reasons provided under subsection (4) shall be entered in the record of the proceedings or, if the proceedings are not recorded, shall be provided in writing.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person shall not publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: the contents of an application made under subsection 278.93;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person shall not publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: any evidence taken, the information given and the representations made at an application under section 278.93 or at a hearing under section 278.94;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person shall not publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: the decision of a judge or justice under subsection 278.93(4), unless the judge or justice, after taking into account the complainant’s right of privacy and the interests of justice, orders that the decision may be published, broadcast or transmitted; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person shall not publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: the determination made and the reasons provided under subsection 278.94(4), unless
subparagraphText: that determination is that evidence is admissible, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A person shall not publish in any document, or broadcast or transmit in any way, any of the following:
paragraphText: the determination made and the reasons provided under subsection 278.94(4), unless
subparagraphText: the judge or justice, after taking into account the complainant’s right of privacy and the interests of justice, orders that the determination and reasons may be published, broadcast or transmitted.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who contravenes subsection (1) is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Judge to instruct jury — re use of evidence
sectiontext: If evidence is admitted at trial on the basis of a determination made under subsection 278.94(4), the judge shall instruct the jury as to the uses that the jury may and may not make of that evidence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: For the purposes of sections 675 and 676, a determination made under subsection 278.94(4) shall be deemed to be a question of law.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, the judge shall provide reasons for a decision that a person is
paragraphText: acquitted;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, the judge shall provide reasons for a decision that a person is
paragraphText: found guilty;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, the judge shall provide reasons for a decision that a person is
paragraphText: discharged, after having been found guilty;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, the judge shall provide reasons for a decision that a person is
paragraphText: found not criminally responsible on account of mental disorder; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 170, 171, 172, 173, 271, 272 or 273, the judge shall provide reasons for a decision that a person is
paragraphText: found unfit to stand trial.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsection (1) also applies in proceedings for any offence under this Act, as it read from time to time before the day on which this section comes into force, if the conduct alleged would be an offence referred to in subsection (1) if it occurred on or after that day.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The reasons shall be entered in the record of the proceedings or, if the proceedings are not recorded, shall be provided in writing.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: This section applies only in proceedings before a judge without a jury.
