heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction in contravention of custody or parenting order
subsectiontext: Every one who, being the parent, guardian or person having the lawful care or charge of a child under the age of 14 years, takes, entices away, conceals, detains, receives or harbours that child, in contravention of a custody order or a parenting order made by a court anywhere in Canada, with intent to deprive a parent or guardian, or any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that child, of the possession of that child is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction in contravention of custody or parenting order
subsectiontext: Every one who, being the parent, guardian or person having the lawful care or charge of a child under the age of 14 years, takes, entices away, conceals, detains, receives or harbours that child, in contravention of a custody order or a parenting order made by a court anywhere in Canada, with intent to deprive a parent or guardian, or any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that child, of the possession of that child is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction in contravention of custody or parenting order
subsectiontext: If a count charges an offence under subsection (1) and the offence is not proven only because the accused did not believe that there was a valid custody order or parenting order but the evidence does prove an offence under section 283, the accused may be convicted of an offence under that section.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction of person under age of 14
sectiontext: Every person who, not being the parent, guardian or person having the lawful care or charge of a person under the age of 14 years, unlawfully takes, entices away, conceals, detains, receives or harbours that person with intent to deprive a parent or guardian, or any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that person, of the possession of that person is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who kidnaps a person with intent
paragraphText: to cause the person to be confined or imprisoned against the person’s will;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who kidnaps a person with intent
paragraphText: to cause the person to be unlawfully sent or transported out of Canada against the person’s will; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person commits an offence who kidnaps a person with intent
paragraphText: to hold the person for ransom or to service against the person’s will.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a first offence, five years, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a second or subsequent offence, seven years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if the person referred to in paragraph (1)(a), (b) or (c) is under 16 years of age, to imprisonment for life and, unless the person who commits the offence is a parent, guardian or person having the lawful care or charge of the person referred to in that paragraph, to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of five years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under subsection (1) is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case, to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (1.1)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection (1);

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (1.1)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244 or 244.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (1.1)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 239, 272, 273, 279.1, 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In imposing a sentence under paragraph (1.1)(a.2), the court shall take into account the age and vulnerability of the victim.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (1.2), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every one who, without lawful authority, confines, imprisons or forcibly seizes another person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every one who, without lawful authority, confines, imprisons or forcibly seizes another person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: [Repealed, 2018, c. 29, s. 26]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsections (1) and 279.011(1), evidence that a person who is not exploited lives with or is habitually in the company of a person who is exploited is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, proof that the person exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of that person for the purpose of exploiting them or facilitating their exploitation.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who recruits, transports, transfers, receives, holds, conceals or harbours a person, or exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of a person, for the purpose of exploiting them or facilitating their exploitation is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of five years if they kidnap, commit an aggravated assault or aggravated sexual assault against, or cause death to, the victim during the commission of the offence; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who recruits, transports, transfers, receives, holds, conceals or harbours a person, or exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of a person, for the purpose of exploiting them or facilitating their exploitation is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years in any other case.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: No consent to the activity that forms the subject-matter of a charge under subsection (1) is valid.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Trafficking of a person under the age of eighteen years
subsectiontext: Every person who recruits, transports, transfers, receives, holds, conceals or harbours a person under the age of eighteen years, or exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of a person under the age of eighteen years, for the purpose of exploiting them or facilitating their exploitation is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of six years if they kidnap, commit an aggravated assault or aggravated sexual assault against, or cause death to, the victim during the commission of the offence; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Trafficking of a person under the age of eighteen years
subsectiontext: Every person who recruits, transports, transfers, receives, holds, conceals or harbours a person under the age of eighteen years, or exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of a person under the age of eighteen years, for the purpose of exploiting them or facilitating their exploitation is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: to imprisonment for a term of not more than fourteen years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of five years, in any other case.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Trafficking of a person under the age of eighteen years
subsectiontext: No consent to the activity that forms the subject-matter of a charge under subsection (1) is valid.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained by or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an offence under subsection 279.01(1), is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained by or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an offence under subsection 279.01(1), is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Everyone who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained by or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an offence under subsection 279.011(1), is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of two years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who, for the purpose of committing or facilitating an offence under subsection 279.01(1), conceals, removes, withholds or destroys any travel document that belongs to another person or any document that establishes or purports to establish another person’s identity or immigration status  — whether or not the document is of Canadian origin or is authentic  —  is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who, for the purpose of committing or facilitating an offence under subsection 279.01(1), conceals, removes, withholds or destroys any travel document that belongs to another person or any document that establishes or purports to establish another person’s identity or immigration status  — whether or not the document is of Canadian origin or is authentic  —  is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Everyone who, for the purpose of committing or facilitating an offence under subsection 279.011(1), conceals, removes, withholds or destroys any travel document that belongs to another person or any document that establishes or purports to establish another person’s identity or immigration status  — whether or not the document is of Canadian origin or is authentic  —  is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of one year.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: For the purposes of sections 279.01 to 279.03, a person exploits another person if they cause them to provide, or offer to provide, labour or a service by engaging in conduct that, in all the circumstances, could reasonably be expected to cause the other person to believe that their safety or the safety of a person known to them would be threatened if they failed to provide, or offer to provide, the labour or service.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining whether an accused exploits another person under subsection (1), the Court may consider, among other factors, whether the accused
paragraphText: used or threatened to use force or another form of coercion;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining whether an accused exploits another person under subsection (1), the Court may consider, among other factors, whether the accused
paragraphText: used deception; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining whether an accused exploits another person under subsection (1), the Court may consider, among other factors, whether the accused
paragraphText: abused a position of trust, power or authority.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: For the purposes of sections 279.01 to 279.03, a person exploits another person if they cause them, by means of deception or the use or threat of force or of any other form of coercion, to have an organ or tissue removed.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Everyone takes a person hostage who — with intent to induce any person, other than the hostage, or any group of persons or any state or international or intergovernmental organization to commit or cause to be committed any act or omission as a condition, whether express or implied, of the release of the hostage —
paragraphText: confines, imprisons, forcibly seizes or detains that person; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Everyone takes a person hostage who — with intent to induce any person, other than the hostage, or any group of persons or any state or international or intergovernmental organization to commit or cause to be committed any act or omission as a condition, whether express or implied, of the release of the hostage —
paragraphText: in any manner utters, conveys or causes any person to receive a threat that the death of, or bodily harm to, the hostage will be caused or that the confinement, imprisonment or detention of the hostage will be continued.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who takes a person hostage is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a first offence, five years, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who takes a person hostage is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: if a restricted firearm or prohibited firearm is used in the commission of the offence or if any firearm is used in the commission of the offence and the offence is committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
subparagraphText: in the case of a second or subsequent offence, seven years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who takes a person hostage is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case where a firearm is used in the commission of the offence, to imprisonment for life and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of four years; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Every person who takes a person hostage is guilty of an indictable offence and liable
paragraphText: in any other case, to imprisonment for life.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under this section;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 85(1) or (2) or section 244 or 244.2; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of paragraph (2)(a), whether a convicted person has committed a second or subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under section 220, 236, 239, 272 or 273, subsection 279(1) or section 344 or 346 if a firearm was used in the commission of the offence.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsection (2.1), the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences or whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction of person under age of 16
subsectiontext: Every person who, without lawful authority, takes or causes to be taken a person under the age of 16 years out of the possession of and against the will of the parent or guardian of that person or of any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction of person under age of 16
subsectiontext: Every person who, without lawful authority, takes or causes to be taken a person under the age of 16 years out of the possession of and against the will of the parent or guardian of that person or of any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
marginalnotetext_x: Abduction of person under age of 16
subsectiontext: In this section and sections 281 to 283, guardian includes any person who has in law or in fact the custody or control of another person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Everyone who, being the parent, guardian or person having the lawful care or charge of a child under the age of 14 years, takes, entices away, conceals, detains, receives or harbours that child, whether or not there is an order referred to in subsection 282(1) in respect of the child , with intent to deprive a parent, guardian or any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that child, of the possession of that child, is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding ten years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: Everyone who, being the parent, guardian or person having the lawful care or charge of a child under the age of 14 years, takes, entices away, conceals, detains, receives or harbours that child, whether or not there is an order referred to in subsection 282(1) in respect of the child , with intent to deprive a parent, guardian or any other person who has the lawful care or charge of that child, of the possession of that child, is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
subsectiontext: No proceedings may be commenced under subsection (1) without the consent of the Attorney General or counsel instructed by him for that purpose.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
sectiontext: No one shall be found guilty of an offence under sections 281 to 283 if he establishes that the taking, enticing away, concealing, detaining, receiving or harbouring of any young person was done with the consent of the parent, guardian or other person having the lawful possession, care or charge of that young person.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
sectiontext: No one shall be found guilty of an offence under sections 280 to 283 if the court is satisfied that the taking, enticing away, concealing, detaining, receiving or harbouring of any young person was necessary to protect the young person from danger of imminent harm or if the person charged with the offence was escaping from danger of imminent harm.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
heading2titletext: Kidnapping, Trafficking in Persons, Hostage Taking and Abduction
sectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under sections 280 to 283, it is not a defence to any charge that a young person consented to or suggested any conduct of the accused.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years and a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in the case where the offence is committed in a public place, or in any place open to public view, that is or is next to a park or the grounds of a school or religious institution or that is or is next to any other place where persons under the age of 18 can reasonably be expected to be present,
clauseText: for a first offence, a fine of  $2,000, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years and a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in the case where the offence is committed in a public place, or in any place open to public view, that is or is next to a park or the grounds of a school or religious institution or that is or is next to any other place where persons under the age of 18 can reasonably be expected to be present,
clauseText: for each subsequent offence, a fine of  $4,000, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years and a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in any other case,
clauseText: for a first offence, a fine of  $1,000, and

subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years and a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in any other case,
clauseText: for each subsequent offence, a fine of  $2,000; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction and liable to a fine of not more than $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years less a day, or to both, and to a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in the case referred to in subparagraph (a)(i),
clauseText: for a first offence, a fine of  $1,000, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction and liable to a fine of not more than $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years less a day, or to both, and to a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in the case referred to in subparagraph (a)(i),
clauseText: for each subsequent offence, a fine of  $2,000, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction and liable to a fine of not more than $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years less a day, or to both, and to a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in any other case,
clauseText: for a first offence, a fine of  $500, and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction and liable to a fine of not more than $5,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years less a day, or to both, and to a minimum punishment of,
subparagraphText: in any other case,
clauseText: for each subsequent offence, a fine of  $1,000.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person under the age of 18 years is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
marginalnotetext_y: Obtaining sexual services for consideration from person under 18 years
paragraphText: for a first offence, six months; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, in any place, obtains for consideration, or communicates with anyone for the purpose of obtaining for consideration, the sexual services of a person under the age of 18 years is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of
marginalnotetext_y: Obtaining sexual services for consideration from person under 18 years
paragraphText: for each subsequent offence, one year.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of subsection (2), whether a convicted person has committed a subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under that subsection; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purpose of subsection (2), whether a convicted person has committed a subsequent offence, if the person was earlier convicted of any of the following offences, that offence is to be considered as an earlier offence:
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 212(4) of this Act, as it read from time to time before the day on which this subsection comes into force.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In determining, for the purposes of this section, whether a convicted person has committed a subsequent offence, the only question to be considered is the sequence of convictions and no consideration shall be given to the sequence of commission of offences, whether any offence occurred before or after any conviction or whether offences were prosecuted by indictment or by way of summary conviction proceedings.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, place and public place have the same meaning as in subsection 197(1).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained by or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an offence under subsection 286.1(1), is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 10 years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained by or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an offence under subsection 286.1(1), is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained by or derived directly or indirectly from the commission of an offence under subsection 286.1(2), is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of two years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of subsections (1) and (2), evidence that a person lives with or is habitually in the company of a person who offers or provides sexual services for consideration is, in the absence of evidence to the contrary, proof that the person received a financial or other material benefit from those services.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (5), subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a person who receives the benefit
paragraphText: in the context of a legitimate living arrangement with the person from whose sexual services the benefit is derived;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (5), subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a person who receives the benefit
paragraphText: as a result of a legal or moral obligation of the person from whose sexual services the benefit is derived;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (5), subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a person who receives the benefit
paragraphText: in consideration for a service or good that they offer, on the same terms and conditions, to the general public; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (5), subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to a person who receives the benefit
paragraphText: in consideration for a service or good that they do not offer to the general public but that they offered or provided to the person from whose sexual services the benefit is derived, if they did not counsel or encourage that person to provide sexual services and the benefit is proportionate to the value of the service or good.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) if that person
paragraphText: used, threatened to use or attempted to use violence, intimidation or coercion in relation to the person from whose sexual services the benefit is derived;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) if that person
paragraphText: abused a position of trust, power or authority in relation to the person from whose sexual services the benefit is derived;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) if that person
paragraphText: provided a drug, alcohol or any other intoxicating substance to the person from whose sexual services the benefit is derived for the purpose of aiding or abetting that person to offer or provide sexual services for consideration;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) if that person
paragraphText: engaged in conduct, in relation to any person, that would constitute an offence under section 286.3; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsection (4) does not apply to a person who commits an offence under subsection (1) or (2) if that person
paragraphText: received the benefit in the context of a commercial enterprise that offers sexual services for consideration.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If a person is convicted of an offence under this section, the court that imposes the sentence shall consider as an aggravating factor the fact that that person received the benefit in the context of a commercial enterprise that offers sexual services for consideration.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who procures a person to offer or provide sexual services for consideration or, for the purpose of facilitating an offence under subsection 286.1(1), recruits, holds, conceals or harbours a person who offers or provides sexual services for consideration, or exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of that person, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who procures a person under the age of 18 years to offer or provide sexual services for consideration or, for the purpose of facilitating an offence under subsection 286.1(2), recruits, holds, conceals or harbours a person under the age of 18 who offers or provides sexual services for consideration, or exercises control, direction or influence over the movements of that person, is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than 14 years and to a minimum punishment of imprisonment for a term of five years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Everyone who knowingly advertises an offer to provide sexual services for consideration is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be prosecuted for
paragraphText: an offence under section 286.2 if the benefit is derived from the provision of their own sexual services; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be prosecuted for
paragraphText: an offence under section 286.4 in relation to the advertisement of their own sexual services.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be prosecuted for aiding, abetting, conspiring or attempting to commit an offence under any of sections 286.1 to 286.4 or being an accessory after the fact or counselling a person to be a party to such an offence, if the offence relates to the offering or provision of their own sexual services.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: [Repealed, 2018, c. 29, s. 28]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: [Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 41]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person who celebrates, aids or participates in a marriage rite or ceremony knowing that one of the persons being married is marrying against their will is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person who celebrates, aids or participates in a marriage rite or ceremony knowing that one of the persons being married is under the age of 16 years is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits bigamy who
paragraphText: in Canada,
subparagraphText: being married, goes through a form of marriage with another person,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits bigamy who
paragraphText: in Canada,
subparagraphText: knowing that another person is married, goes through a form of marriage with that person, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits bigamy who
paragraphText: in Canada,
subparagraphText: on the same day or simultaneously, goes through a form of marriage with more than one person; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits bigamy who
paragraphText: being a Canadian citizen resident in Canada leaves Canada with intent to do anything mentioned in subparagraphs (a)(i) to (iii) and, pursuant thereto, does outside Canada anything mentioned in those subparagraphs in circumstances mentioned therein.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person commits bigamy by going through a form of marriage if
paragraphText: that person in good faith and on reasonable grounds believes that his spouse is dead;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person commits bigamy by going through a form of marriage if
paragraphText: the spouse of that person has been continuously absent from him for seven years immediately preceding the time when he goes through the form of marriage, unless he knew that his spouse was alive at any time during those seven years;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person commits bigamy by going through a form of marriage if
paragraphText: that person has been divorced from the bond of the first marriage; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person commits bigamy by going through a form of marriage if
paragraphText: the former marriage has been declared void by a court of competent jurisdiction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where a person is alleged to have committed bigamy, it is not a defence that the parties would, if unmarried, have been incompetent to contract marriage under the law of the place where the offence is alleged to have been committed.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every marriage or form of marriage shall, for the purpose of this section, be deemed to be valid unless the accused establishes that it was invalid.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No act or omission on the part of an accused who is charged with bigamy invalidates a marriage or form of marriage that is otherwise valid.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits bigamy is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits bigamy is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, a certificate of marriage issued under the authority of law is evidence of the marriage or form of marriage to which it relates without proof of the signature or official character of the person by whom it purports to be signed.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who procures or knowingly aids in procuring a feigned marriage between themselves and another person is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who procures or knowingly aids in procuring a feigned marriage between themselves and another person is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under this section on the evidence of only one witness unless the evidence of that witness is corroborated in a material particular by evidence that implicates the accused.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who
paragraphText: practises or enters into or in any manner agrees or consents to practise or enter into any form of polygamy or any kind of conjugal union with more than one person at the same time, whether or not it is by law recognized as a binding form of marriage; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who
paragraphText: celebrates, assists or is a party to a rite, ceremony, contract or consent that purports to sanction a relationship mentioned in paragraph (a).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where an accused is charged with an offence under this section, no averment or proof of the method by which the alleged relationship was entered into, agreed to or consented to is necessary in the indictment or on the trial of the accused, nor is it necessary on the trial to prove that the persons who are alleged to have entered into the relationship had or intended to have sexual intercourse.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person who, being lawfully authorized to solemnize marriage, knowingly solemnizes a marriage in contravention of federal law or the laws of the province in which the marriage is solemnized is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years or is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction who

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: [Repealed, 2018, c. 29, s. 30]

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Punishment of libel known to be false
sectiontext: Every person who publishes a defamatory libel that they know is false is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Every person who publishes a defamatory libel is guilty of

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: In sections 303, 304 and 308, newspaper means any paper, magazine or periodical containing public news, intelligence or reports of events, or any remarks or observations thereon, printed for sale and published periodically or in parts or numbers, at intervals not exceeding thirty-one days between the publication of any two such papers, parts or numbers, and any paper, magazine or periodical printed in order to be dispersed and made public, weekly or more often, or at intervals not exceeding thirty-one days, that contains advertisements, exclusively or principally.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A defamatory libel is matter published, without lawful justification or excuse, that is likely to injure the reputation of any person by exposing him to hatred, contempt or ridicule, or that is designed to insult the person of or concerning whom it is published.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A defamatory libel may be expressed directly or by insinuation or irony
paragraphText: in words legibly marked on any substance; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A defamatory libel may be expressed directly or by insinuation or irony
paragraphText: by any object signifying a defamatory libel otherwise than by words.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: A person publishes a libel when he

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under this section is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who commits an offence under this section is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, with intent
paragraphText: to extort money from any person, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, with intent
paragraphText: to induce a person to confer on or procure for another person an appointment or office of profit or trust,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one commits an offence who, as the result of the refusal of any person to permit money to be extorted or to confer or procure an appointment or office of profit or trust, publishes or threatens to publish a defamatory libel.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The proprietor of a newspaper shall be deemed to publish defamatory matter that is inserted and published therein, unless he proves that the defamatory matter was inserted in the newspaper without his knowledge and without negligence on his part.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where the proprietor of a newspaper gives to a person general authority to manage or conduct the newspaper as editor or otherwise, the insertion by that person of defamatory matter in the newspaper shall, for the purposes of subsection (1), be deemed not to be negligence on the part of the proprietor unless it is proved that
marginalnotetext_y: General authority to manager when negligence
paragraphText: he intended the general authority to include authority to insert defamatory matter in the newspaper; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where the proprietor of a newspaper gives to a person general authority to manage or conduct the newspaper as editor or otherwise, the insertion by that person of defamatory matter in the newspaper shall, for the purposes of subsection (1), be deemed not to be negligence on the part of the proprietor unless it is proved that
marginalnotetext_y: General authority to manager when negligence
paragraphText: he continued to confer general authority after he knew that it had been exercised by the insertion of defamatory matter in the newspaper.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he sells a number or part of a newspaper that contains a defamatory libel, unless he knows that the number or part contains defamatory matter or that defamatory matter is habitually contained in the newspaper.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he sells a book, magazine, pamphlet or other thing, other than a newspaper that contains defamatory matter, if, at the time of the sale, he does not know that it contains the defamatory matter.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where a servant, in the course of his employment, sells a book, magazine, pamphlet or other thing, other than a newspaper, the employer shall be deemed not to publish any defamatory matter contained therein unless it is proved that the employer authorized the sale knowing that
paragraphText: defamatory matter was contained therein; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Where a servant, in the course of his employment, sells a book, magazine, pamphlet or other thing, other than a newspaper, the employer shall be deemed not to publish any defamatory matter contained therein unless it is proved that the employer authorized the sale knowing that
paragraphText: defamatory matter was habitually contained therein, in the case of a periodical.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Publishing proceedings of courts of justice
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes defamatory matter

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Fair reports of parliamentary or judicial proceedings
subsectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes in good faith, for the information of the public, a fair report of the proceedings of the Senate or House of Commons or the legislature of a province, or a committee thereof, or of the public proceedings before a court exercising judicial authority, or publishes, in good faith, any fair comment on any such proceedings.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Fair reports of parliamentary or judicial proceedings
subsectiontext: This section does not apply to a person who publishes a report of evidence taken or offered in any proceeding before the Senate or House of Commons or any committee thereof, on a petition or bill relating to any matter of marriage or divorce, if the report is published without authority from or leave of the House in which the proceeding is held or is contrary to any rule, order or practice of that House.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes in good faith, in a newspaper, a fair report of the proceedings of any public meeting if

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes defamatory matter that, on reasonable grounds, he believes is true, and that is relevant to any subject of public interest, the public discussion of which is for the public benefit.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Fair comment on public person or work of art
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes fair comments

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel where he proves that the publication of the defamatory matter in the manner in which it was published was for the public benefit at the time when it was published and that the matter itself was true.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes defamatory matter

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes, in answer to inquiries made to him, defamatory matter relating to a subject-matter in respect of which the person by whom or on whose behalf the inquiries are made has an interest in knowing the truth or who, on reasonable grounds, the person who publishes the defamatory matter believes has such an interest, if

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes to another person defamatory matter for the purpose of giving information to that person with respect to a subject-matter in which the person to whom the information is given has, or is believed on reasonable grounds by the person who gives it to have, an interest in knowing the truth with respect to that subject-matter if

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Publication in good faith for redress of wrong
sectiontext: No person shall be deemed to publish a defamatory libel by reason only that he publishes defamatory matter in good faith for the purpose of seeking remedy or redress for a private or public wrong or grievance from a person who has, or who on reasonable grounds he believes has, the right or is under an obligation to remedy or redress the wrong or grievance, if

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Proving publication by order of legislature
subsectiontext: An accused who is alleged to have published a defamatory libel may, at any stage of the proceedings, adduce evidence to prove that the matter that is alleged to be defamatory was contained in a paper published by order or under the authority of the Senate or House of Commons or the legislature of a province.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Proving publication by order of legislature
subsectiontext: Where at any stage in proceedings referred to in subsection (1) the court, judge, justice or provincial court judge is satisfied that the matter alleged to be defamatory was contained in a paper published by order or under the authority of the Senate or House of Commons or the legislature of a province, he shall direct a verdict of not guilty to be entered and shall discharge the accused.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Proving publication by order of legislature
subsectiontext: For the purposes of this section, a certificate under the hand of the Speaker or clerk of the Senate or House of Commons or the legislature of a province to the effect that the matter that is alleged to be defamatory was contained in a paper published by order or under the authority of the Senate, House of Commons or the legislature of a province, as the case may be, is conclusive evidence thereof.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
marginalnotetext_x: Verdicts in cases of defamatory libel
sectiontext: Where, on the trial of an indictment for publishing a defamatory libel, a plea of not guilty is pleaded, the jury that is sworn to try the issue may give a general verdict of guilty or not guilty on the whole matter put in issue on the indictment, and shall not be required or directed by the judge to find the defendant guilty merely on proof of publication by the defendant of the alleged defamatory libel, and of the sense ascribed thereto in the indictment, but the judge may, in his discretion, give a direction or opinion to the jury on the matter in issue as in other criminal proceedings, and the jury may, on the issue, find a special verdict.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every person who advocates or promotes genocide is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term of not more than five years.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In this section, genocide means any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy in whole or in part any identifiable group, namely,
paragraphText: killing members of the group; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In this section, genocide means any of the following acts committed with intent to destroy in whole or in part any identifiable group, namely,
paragraphText: deliberately inflicting on the group conditions of life calculated to bring about its physical destruction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No proceeding for an offence under this section shall be instituted without the consent of the Attorney General.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In this section, identifiable group means any section of the public distinguished by colour, race, religion, national or ethnic origin, age, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity or expression, or mental or physical disability.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who, by communicating statements in any public place, incites hatred against any identifiable group where such incitement is likely to lead to a breach of the peace is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who, by communicating statements in any public place, incites hatred against any identifiable group where such incitement is likely to lead to a breach of the peace is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who, by communicating statements, other than in private conversation, wilfully promotes hatred against any identifiable group is guilty of
paragraphText: an indictable offence and is liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Every one who, by communicating statements, other than in private conversation, wilfully promotes hatred against any identifiable group is guilty of
paragraphText: an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2)
paragraphText: if he establishes that the statements communicated were true;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2)
paragraphText: if, in good faith, the person expressed or attempted to establish by an argument an opinion on a religious subject or an opinion based on a belief in a religious text;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2)
paragraphText: if the statements were relevant to any subject of public interest, the discussion of which was for the public benefit, and if on reasonable grounds he believed them to be true; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2)
paragraphText: if, in good faith, he intended to point out, for the purpose of removal, matters producing or tending to produce feelings of hatred toward an identifiable group in Canada.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In this section,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, by communicating statements, other than in private conversation, wilfully promotes antisemitism by condoning, denying or downplaying the Holocaust
paragraphText: is guilty of an indictable offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Everyone who, by communicating statements, other than in private conversation, wilfully promotes antisemitism by condoning, denying or downplaying the Holocaust
paragraphText: is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2.1)
paragraphText: if they establish that the statements communicated were true;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2.1)
paragraphText: if, in good faith, they expressed or attempted to establish by an argument an opinion on a religious subject or an opinion based on a belief in a religious text;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2.1)
paragraphText: if the statements were relevant to any subject of public interest, the discussion of which was for the public benefit, and if on reasonable grounds they believed them to be true; or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No person shall be convicted of an offence under subsection (2.1)
paragraphText: if, in good faith, they intended to point out, for the purpose of removal, matters producing or tending to produce feelings of antisemitism toward Jews.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If a person is convicted of an offence under subsection (1), (2) or (2.1) or section 318, anything by means of or in relation to which the offence was committed, on such conviction, may, in addition to any other punishment imposed, be ordered by the presiding provincial court judge or judge to be forfeited to Her Majesty in right of the province in which that person is convicted, for disposal as the Attorney General may direct.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsections 199(6) and (7) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to subsection (1), (2) or (2.1) or section 318.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No proceeding for an offence under subsection (2) or (2.1) shall be instituted without the consent of the Attorney General.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: A judge who is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds for believing that any publication, copies of which are kept for sale or distribution in premises within the jurisdiction of the court, is hate propaganda shall issue a warrant under his hand authorizing seizure of the copies.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Within seven days of the issue of a warrant under subsection (1), the judge shall issue a summons to the occupier of the premises requiring him to appear before the court and show cause why the matter seized should not be forfeited to Her Majesty.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The owner and the author of the matter seized under subsection (1) and alleged to be hate propaganda may appear and be represented in the proceedings in order to oppose the making of an order for the forfeiture of the matter.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If the court is satisfied that the publication referred to in subsection (1) is hate propaganda, it shall make an order declaring the matter forfeited to Her Majesty in right of the province in which the proceedings take place, for disposal as the Attorney General may direct.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If the court is not satisfied that the publication referred to in subsection (1) is hate propaganda, it shall order that the matter be restored to the person from whom it was seized forthwith after the time for final appeal has expired.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An appeal lies from an order made under subsection (4) or (5) by any person who appeared in the proceedings
paragraphText: on any ground of appeal that involves a question of law alone,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An appeal lies from an order made under subsection (4) or (5) by any person who appeared in the proceedings
paragraphText: on any ground of appeal that involves a question of fact alone, or

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: An appeal lies from an order made under subsection (4) or (5) by any person who appeared in the proceedings
paragraphText: on any ground of appeal that involves a question of mixed law and fact,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No proceeding under this section shall be instituted without the consent of the Attorney General.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: In this section,

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If a judge is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is material that is hate propaganda within the meaning of subsection 320(8) or computer data within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that makes hate propaganda available, that is stored on and made available to the public through a computer system within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that is within the jurisdiction of the court, the judge may order the custodian of the computer system to
paragraphText: give an electronic copy of the material to the court;

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If a judge is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is material that is hate propaganda within the meaning of subsection 320(8) or computer data within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that makes hate propaganda available, that is stored on and made available to the public through a computer system within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that is within the jurisdiction of the court, the judge may order the custodian of the computer system to
paragraphText: ensure that the material is no longer stored on and made available through the computer system; and

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If a judge is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is material that is hate propaganda within the meaning of subsection 320(8) or computer data within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that makes hate propaganda available, that is stored on and made available to the public through a computer system within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that is within the jurisdiction of the court, the judge may order the custodian of the computer system to
paragraphText: provide the information necessary to identify and locate the person who posted the material.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Within a reasonable time after receiving the information referred to in paragraph (1)(c), the judge shall cause notice to be given to the person who posted the material, giving that person the opportunity to appear and be represented before the court and show cause why the material should not be deleted. If the person cannot be identified or located or does not reside in Canada, the judge may order the custodian of the computer system to post the text of the notice at the location where the material was previously stored and made available, until the time set for the appearance.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: The person who posted the material may appear and be represented in the proceedings in order to oppose the making of an order under subsection (5).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If the person who posted the material does not appear for the proceedings, the court may proceed ex parte to hear and determine the proceedings in the absence of the person as fully and effectually as if the person had appeared.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If the court is satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, that the material is available to the public and is hate propaganda within the meaning of subsection 320(8) or computer data within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that makes hate propaganda available, it may order the custodian of the computer system to delete the material.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: When the court makes the order for the deletion of the material, it may order the destruction of the electronic copy in the court’s possession.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: If the court is not satisfied that the material is available to the public and is hate propaganda within the meaning of subsection 320(8) or computer data within the meaning of subsection 342.1(2) that makes hate propaganda available, the court shall order that the electronic copy be returned to the custodian and terminate the order under paragraph (1)(b).

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: Subsections 320(6) to (8) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to this section.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
subsectiontext: No order made under subsections (5) to (7) takes effect until the time for final appeal has expired.

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: In sections 320.102 to 320.104, conversion therapy means a practice, treatment or service designed to

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Everyone who knowingly causes another person to undergo conversion therapy — including by providing conversion therapy to that other person — is

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Everyone who knowingly promotes or advertises conversion therapy is

heading1titletext: Offences Against the Person and Reputation
sectiontext: Everyone who receives a financial or other material benefit, knowing that it is obtained or derived directly or indirectly from the provision of conversion therapy, is
Except as otherwise provided in this Act, a person who appears at, participates in or presides at a proceeding shall do so personally.

marginalnotetext_x: Provisions providing for audioconference or videoconference
sectiontext: The purpose of the provisions of this Act that allow a person to appear at, participate in or preside at a proceeding by audioconference or videoconference, in accordance with the rules of court, is to serve the proper administration of justice, including by ensuring fair and efficient proceedings and enhancing access to justice.

subsectiontext: Except as otherwise provided in this Act, the court may order an accused to appear by audioconference or videoconference, if the court is of the opinion that it would be appropriate having regard to all the circumstances, including
