subparagraphText: for keeping writings, exhibits or other things connected with the proceedings on the trial,

subsectiontext: Rules under subsection (1) or (2) may be made
paragraphText: to carry out the provisions of this Act relating to appeals from conviction, acquittal or sentence and, without restricting the generality of this paragraph,
subparagraphText: for securing the safe custody of property during the period in which the operation of an order with respect to that property is suspended under subsection 689(1), and

subsectiontext: Rules under subsection (1) or (2) may be made
paragraphText: to carry out the provisions of this Act relating to appeals from conviction, acquittal or sentence and, without restricting the generality of this paragraph,
subparagraphText: for providing that the Attorney General and counsel who acted for the Attorney General at the trial be supplied with certified copies of writings, exhibits and things connected with the proceedings that are required for the purposes of their duties.

subsectiontext: Notwithstanding anything in this section, the Governor in Council may make such provision as he considers proper to secure uniformity in the rules of court in criminal matters, and all uniform rules made under the authority of this subsection prevail and have effect as if enacted by this Act.

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: Subsections 482(4) and (5) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to rules made under subsection (1).

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: Sections 512 and 512.3 apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to the issuance of a summons or a warrant under subsection (3).

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: A court referred to in subsection 482(1) or (2) may make rules for case management, including rules
paragraphText: for the determination of any matter that would assist the court in effective and efficient case management;

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: A court referred to in subsection 482(1) or (2) may make rules for case management, including rules
paragraphText: permitting personnel of the court to deal with administrative matters relating to proceedings out of court if the accused is represented by counsel; and

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: A court referred to in subsection 482(1) or (2) may make rules for case management, including rules
paragraphText: establishing case management schedules.

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: The parties to a case shall comply with any direction made in accordance with a rule made under subsection (1).

marginalnotetext_x: Power to make rules respecting case management
subsectiontext: If rules are made under subsection (1), a court, justice or judge may issue a summons or warrant to compel the presence of the accused at case management proceedings.

sectiontext: A person, financial institution or entity that contravenes an order made under any of sections 487.013 to 487.018 without lawful excuse is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction and liable to a fine of not more than $250,000 or to imprisonment for a term of not more than two years less a day, or to both.

If an authorization is given under section 184.2, 184.3, 186 or 188 or a warrant is issued under this Act, the judge or justice who gives the authorization or issues the warrant may order a person to provide assistance, if the person’s assistance may reasonably be considered to be required to give effect to the authorization or warrant. The order has effect throughout Canada.

marginalnotetext_x: Officials with powers of two justices
sectiontext: Every judge or provincial court judge authorized by the law of the province in which he is appointed to do anything that is required to be done by two or more justices may do alone anything that this Act or any other Act of Parliament authorizes two or more justices to do.

Every judge or provincial court judge has the same power and authority to preserve order in a court over which he presides as may be exercised by the superior court of criminal jurisdiction of the province during the sittings thereof.

subsectiontext: Jurisdiction over an accused is not lost by reason of the failure of the accused to appear personally, so long as the provisions of this Act or a rule made under section 482 or 482.1 permitting the accused not to appear personally apply.

Jurisdiction over an offence is not lost by reason of the failure of any court, judge, provincial court judge or justice to act in the exercise of that jurisdiction at any particular time, or by reason of a failure to comply with any of the provisions of this Act respecting adjournments or remands.

Where jurisdiction over an accused or a defendant is lost and has not been regained, a court, judge, provincial court judge or justice may, within three months after the loss of jurisdiction, issue a summons, or if it or he considers it necessary in the public interest, a warrant for the arrest of the accused or defendant.

Where no summons or warrant is issued under subsection (2) within the period provided therein, the proceedings shall be deemed to be dismissed for want of prosecution and shall not be recommenced except in accordance with section 485.1.

Where, in the opinion of the court, judge, provincial court judge or justice, an accused or a defendant who appears at a proceeding has been misled or prejudiced by reason of any matter referred to in subsection (1), the court, judge, provincial court judge or justice may adjourn the proceeding and may make such order as it or he considers appropriate.
The provisions of Part XVI apply with such modifications as the circumstances require where a summons or warrant is issued under subsection (2).

marginalnotetext_x: Recommencement where dismissal for want of prosecution
sectiontext: Where an indictment in respect of a transaction is dismissed or deemed by any provision of this Act to be dismissed for want of prosecution, a new information shall not be laid and a new indictment shall not be preferred before any court in respect of the same transaction without

subsectiontext: If an accused is charged with an offence under section 151, 152, 153, 153.1 or 155, subsection 160(2) or (3) or section 163.1, 170, 171, 171.1, 172, 172.1, 172.2, 173, 271, 272, 273, 279.01, 279.011, 279.02, 279.03, 286.1, 286.2 or 286.3 and the prosecutor or the accused applies for an order under subsection (1), the judge or justice shall, if no such order is made, state, by reference to the circumstances of the case, the reason for not making an order.

Any proceedings against an accused shall be held in open court, but the presiding judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor or a witness or on his or her own motion, order the exclusion of all or any members of the public from the court room for all or part of the proceedings, or order that the witness testify behind a screen or other device that would allow the witness not to be seen by members of the public, if the judge or justice is of the opinion that such an order is in the interest of public morals, the maintenance of order or the proper administration of justice or is necessary to prevent injury to international relations or national defence or national security.

The application may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process;

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the safeguarding of the interests of witnesses under the age of 18 years in all proceedings;

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the ability of the witness to give a full and candid account of the acts complained of if the order were not made;

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the protection of justice system participants who are involved in the proceedings;

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether effective alternatives to the making of the proposed order are available in the circumstances;

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order; and

subsectiontext: In determining whether the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

subsectiontext: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is under the age of 18 years or who has a mental or physical disability, or on application of such a witness, order that a support person of the witness’ choice be permitted to be present and to be close to the witness while the witness testifies, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would interfere with the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness, or on application of a witness, order that a support person of the witness’ choice be permitted to be present and to be close to the witness while the witness testifies if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would facilitate the giving of a full and candid account by the witness of the acts complained of or would otherwise be in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: An application referred to in subsection (1) or (2) may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the age of the witness;

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the witness’ mental or physical disabilities, if any;

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of the offence;

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of any relationship between the witness and the accused;

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process; and

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: The judge or justice shall not permit a witness to be a support person unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that doing so is necessary for the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: The judge or justice may order that the support person and the witness not communicate with each other while the witness testifies.

marginalnotetext_x: Support person — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: Despite section 650, in any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is under the age of 18 years or who is able to communicate evidence but may have difficulty doing so by reason of a mental or physical disability, or on application of such a witness, order that the witness testify outside the court room or behind a screen or other device that would allow the witness not to see the accused, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would interfere with the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: Despite section 650, in any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness, or on application of a witness, order that the witness testify outside the court room or behind a screen or other device that would allow the witness not to see the accused if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would facilitate the giving of a full and candid account by the witness of the acts complained of or would otherwise be in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: An application referred to in subsection (1) or (2) may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the age of the witness;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the witness’ mental or physical disabilities, if any;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of the offence;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of any relationship between the witness and the accused;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the order is needed to protect the identity of a peace officer who has acted, is acting or will be acting in an undercover capacity, or of a person who has acted, is acting or will be acting covertly under the direction of a peace officer;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the order is needed to protect the witness’s identity if they have had, have or will have responsibilities relating to national security or intelligence;

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process; and

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (2), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: If the judge or justice is of the opinion that it is necessary for a witness to testify in order to determine whether an order under subsection (2) should be made in respect of that witness, the judge or justice shall order that the witness testify in accordance with that subsection.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: A witness shall not testify outside the court room in accordance with an order made under subsection (1) or (2) unless arrangements are made for the accused, the judge or justice and the jury to watch the testimony of the witness by means of closed-circuit television or otherwise and the accused is permitted to communicate with counsel while watching the testimony.

marginalnotetext_x: Testimony outside court room — witnesses under 18 or who have a disability
subsectiontext: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under subsection (1) or (2).

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is under the age of 18 years, or on application of such a witness, order that the accused not personally cross-examine the witness, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the proper administration of justice requires the accused to personally conduct the cross-examination. If such an order is made, the judge or justice shall appoint counsel to conduct the cross-examination.

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In any proceedings against an accused in respect of an offence under any of sections 264, 271, 272 and 273, the judge or justice shall, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is a victim, or on application of such a witness, order that the accused not personally cross-examine the witness, unless the judge or justice is of the opinion that the proper administration of justice requires the accused to personally conduct the cross-examination. If such an order is made, the judge or justice shall appoint counsel to conduct the cross-examination.

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness who is not entitled to make an application under subsection (1) or (2), or on application of such a witness, order that the accused not personally cross-examine the witness if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order would allow the giving of a full and candid account from the witness of the acts complained of or would otherwise be in the interest of the proper administration of justice. If the order is made, the judge or justice shall appoint counsel to conduct the cross-examination.

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the age of the witness;

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the witness’ mental or physical disabilities, if any;

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of the offence;

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of any relationship between the witness and the accused;

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process; and

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order under subsection (3), the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: An application referred to in any of subsections (1) to (3) may be made during the proceedings to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.

marginalnotetext_x: Accused not to cross-examine witness under 18
subsectiontext: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that counsel is, or is not, appointed under this section.

In any proceedings against an accused, the judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a witness, or on application of a witness, make an order directing that any information that could identify the witness not be disclosed in the course of the proceedings if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice.
The judge or justice may hold a hearing to determine whether the order should be made, and the hearing may be in private.
In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the right to a fair and public hearing;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of the offence;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the witness needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the order is needed to protect the security of anyone known to the witness;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the order is needed to protect the identity of a peace officer who has acted, is acting or will be acting in an undercover capacity, or of a person who has acted, is acting or will be acting covertly under the direction of a peace officer;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the order is needed to protect the witness’s identity if they have had, have or will have responsibilities relating to national security or intelligence;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the importance of the witness’ testimony to the case;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether effective alternatives to the making of the proposed order are available in the circumstances;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order; and

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

subsectiontext: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

Subject to subsection (2), the presiding judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim or a witness shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way, in proceedings in respect of
paragraphText: any of the following offences:

subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), the presiding judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim or a witness shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way, in proceedings in respect of
paragraphText: any of the following offences:
subparagraphText: any offence under this Act, as it read from time to time before the day on which this subparagraph comes into force, if the conduct alleged would be an offence referred to in subparagraph (i) if it occurred on or after that day; or

subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), the presiding judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim or a witness shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way, in proceedings in respect of
paragraphText: two or more offences being dealt with in the same proceeding, at least one of which is an offence referred to in paragraph (a).

subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of the offences referred to in paragraph (1)(a) or (b), the presiding judge or justice shall
paragraphText: at the first reasonable opportunity, inform any witness under the age of eighteen years and the victim of the right to make an application for the order; and

subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of the offences referred to in paragraph (1)(a) or (b), the presiding judge or justice shall
paragraphText: on application made by the victim, the prosecutor or any such witness, make the order.

subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2.2), in proceedings in respect of an offence other than an offence referred to in subsection (1), if the victim is under the age of 18 years, the presiding judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way.
In proceedings in respect of an offence other than an offence referred to in subsection (1), if the victim is under the age of 18 years, the presiding judge or justice shall
paragraphText: as soon as feasible, inform the victim of their right to make an application for the order; and

subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence other than an offence referred to in subsection (1), if the victim is under the age of 18 years, the presiding judge or justice shall
paragraphText: on application of the victim or the prosecutor, make the order.

subsectiontext: In proceedings in respect of an offence under section 163.1, a judge or justice shall make an order directing that any information that could identify a witness who is under the age of eighteen years, or any person who is the subject of a representation, written material or a recording that constitutes child pornography within the meaning of that section, shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way.

An order made under this section does not apply in respect of the disclosure of information in the course of the administration of justice when it is not the purpose of the disclosure to make the information known in the community.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: Unless an order is made under section 486.4, on application of the prosecutor in respect of a victim or a witness, or on application of a victim or a witness, a judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the victim or witness shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: On application of the prosecutor in respect of a justice system participant who is involved in proceedings in respect of an offence referred to in subsection (2.1), or on application of such a justice system participant, a judge or justice may make an order directing that any information that could identify the justice system participant shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: The offences for the purposes of subsection (2) are
paragraphText: an offence under section 423.1, 467.11, 467.111, 467.12 or 467.13, or a serious offence committed for the benefit of, at the direction of, or in association with, a criminal organization;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: The offences for the purposes of subsection (2) are
paragraphText: a terrorism offence;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: The offences for the purposes of subsection (2) are
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 16(1) or (2), 17(1), 19(1), 20(1) or 22(1) of the Security of Information Act; or

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: The offences for the purposes of subsection (2) are
paragraphText: an offence under subsection 21(1) or section 23 of the Security of Information Act that is committed in relation to an offence referred to in paragraph (c).

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: An order made under this section does not apply in respect of the disclosure of information in the course of the administration of justice if it is not the purpose of the disclosure to make the information known in the community.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: An applicant for an order shall
paragraphText: apply in writing to the presiding judge or justice or, if the judge or justice has not been determined, to a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place; and

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: An applicant for an order shall
paragraphText: provide notice of the application to the prosecutor, the accused and any other person affected by the order that the judge or justice specifies.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: An applicant for an order shall set out the grounds on which the applicant relies to establish that the order is necessary for the proper administration of justice.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: The judge or justice may hold a hearing to determine whether an order should be made, and the hearing may be in private.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the right to a fair and public hearing;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether there is a real and substantial risk that the victim, witness or justice system participant would suffer harm if their identity were disclosed;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the victim, witness or justice system participant needs the order for their security or to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims, witnesses and justice system participants in the criminal justice process;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether effective alternatives are available to protect the identity of the victim, witness or justice system participant;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the impact of the proposed order on the freedom of expression of those affected by it; and

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: In determining whether to make an order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: An order may be subject to any conditions that the judge or justice thinks fit.

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: Unless the judge or justice refuses to make an order, no person shall publish in any document or broadcast or transmit in any way
paragraphText: the contents of an application;

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: Unless the judge or justice refuses to make an order, no person shall publish in any document or broadcast or transmit in any way
paragraphText: any evidence taken, information given or submissions made at a hearing under subsection (6); or

marginalnotetext_x: Order restricting publication — victims and witnesses
subsectiontext: Unless the judge or justice refuses to make an order, no person shall publish in any document or broadcast or transmit in any way
paragraphText: any other information that could identify the person to whom the application relates as a victim, witness or justice system participant in the proceedings.

subsectiontext: Every person who fails to comply with an order made under any of subsections 486.4(1) to (3) or subsection 486.5(1) or (2) is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

For greater certainty, an order referred to in subsection (1) applies to prohibit, in relation to proceedings taken against any person who fails to comply with the order, the publication in any document or the broadcasting or transmission in any way of information that could identify a victim, witness or justice system participant whose identity is protected by the order.

In any proceedings against an accused, the presiding judge or justice may, on application of the prosecutor or a witness or on his or her own motion, make any order, other than one that may be made under any of sections 486 to 486.5, if the judge or justice is of the opinion that the order is necessary to protect the security of any witness and is otherwise in the interest of the proper administration of justice.

The application may be made, during the proceedings, to the presiding judge or justice or, before the proceedings begin, to the judge or justice who will preside at the proceedings or, if that judge or justice has not been determined, to any judge or justice having jurisdiction in the judicial district where the proceedings will take place.
In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the age of the witness;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the witness’s mental or physical disabilities, if any;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the right to a fair and public hearing;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the nature of the offence;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the witness needs the order to protect them from intimidation or retaliation;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether the order is needed to protect the security of anyone known to the witness;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: society’s interest in encouraging the reporting of offences and the participation of victims and witnesses in the criminal justice process;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the importance of the witness’s testimony to the case;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: whether effective alternatives to the making of the proposed order are available in the circumstances;

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: the salutary and deleterious effects of the proposed order; and

subsectiontext: In determining whether to make the order, the judge or justice shall consider
paragraphText: any other factor that the judge or justice considers relevant.

subsectiontext: No adverse inference may be drawn from the fact that an order is, or is not, made under this section.

A warrant issued under subsection (1) may be executed at any place in Canada. A public officer named in the warrant, or any peace officer, who executes the warrant must have authority to act in that capacity in the place where the warrant is executed.
A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place
paragraphText: anything on or in respect of which any offence against this Act or any other Act of Parliament has been or is suspected to have been committed,

subsectiontext: A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place
paragraphText: anything that there are reasonable grounds to believe will afford evidence with respect to the commission of an offence, or will reveal the whereabouts of a person who is believed to have committed an offence, against this Act or any other Act of Parliament,

subsectiontext: A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place
paragraphText: anything that there are reasonable grounds to believe is intended to be used for the purpose of committing any offence against the person for which a person may be arrested without warrant, or

subsectiontext: A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place
paragraphText: any offence-related property,

subsectiontext: A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place
paragraphText: to search the building, receptacle or place for any such thing and to seize it, and

subsectiontext: A justice who is satisfied by information on oath in Form 1 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is in a building, receptacle or place
paragraphText: subject to any other Act of Parliament, to, as soon as practicable, bring the thing seized before, or make a report in respect thereof to, the justice or some other justice for the same territorial division in accordance with section 489.1.

subsectiontext: A person authorized under this section to search a computer system in a building or place for data may
marginalnotetext_y: Operation of computer system and copying equipment
paragraphText: use or cause to be used any computer system at the building or place to search any data contained in or available to the computer system;

subsectiontext: A person authorized under this section to search a computer system in a building or place for data may
marginalnotetext_y: Operation of computer system and copying equipment
paragraphText: reproduce or cause to be reproduced any data in the form of a print-out or other intelligible output;

subsectiontext: A person authorized under this section to search a computer system in a building or place for data may
marginalnotetext_y: Operation of computer system and copying equipment
paragraphText: seize the print-out or other output for examination or copying; and

subsectiontext: A person authorized under this section to search a computer system in a building or place for data may
marginalnotetext_y: Operation of computer system and copying equipment
paragraphText: use or cause to be used any copying equipment at the place to make copies of the data.

subsectiontext: Every person who is in possession or control of any building or place in respect of which a search is carried out under this section shall, on presentation of the warrant, permit the person carrying out the search
marginalnotetext_y: Duty of person in possession or control
paragraphText: to use or cause to be used any computer system at the building or place in order to search any data contained in or available to the computer system for data that the person is authorized by this section to search for;

subsectiontext: Every person who is in possession or control of any building or place in respect of which a search is carried out under this section shall, on presentation of the warrant, permit the person carrying out the search
marginalnotetext_y: Duty of person in possession or control
paragraphText: to obtain a hard copy of the data and to seize it; and

subsectiontext: Every person who is in possession or control of any building or place in respect of which a search is carried out under this section shall, on presentation of the warrant, permit the person carrying out the search
marginalnotetext_y: Duty of person in possession or control
paragraphText: to use or cause to be used any copying equipment at the place to make copies of the data.

subsectiontext: A search warrant issued under this section may be in the form set out as Form 5 in Part XXVIII, varied to suit the case.

A warrant issued under subsection (1) may be executed at any place in Canada. Any peace officer who executes the warrant must have authority to act as a peace officer in the place where it is executed.

A provincial court judge, a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552 may issue a warrant in writing authorizing a peace officer to, subject to this section, use any device or investigative technique or procedure or do any thing described in the warrant that would, if not authorized, constitute an unreasonable search or seizure in respect of a person or a person’s property if
paragraphText: the judge is satisfied by information on oath in writing that there are reasonable grounds to believe that an offence against this or any other Act of Parliament has been or will be committed and that information concerning the offence will be obtained through the use of the technique, procedure or device or the doing of the thing;

subsectiontext: A provincial court judge, a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552 may issue a warrant in writing authorizing a peace officer to, subject to this section, use any device or investigative technique or procedure or do any thing described in the warrant that would, if not authorized, constitute an unreasonable search or seizure in respect of a person or a person’s property if
paragraphText: the judge is satisfied that it is in the best interests of the administration of justice to issue the warrant; and

subsectiontext: A provincial court judge, a judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552 may issue a warrant in writing authorizing a peace officer to, subject to this section, use any device or investigative technique or procedure or do any thing described in the warrant that would, if not authorized, constitute an unreasonable search or seizure in respect of a person or a person’s property if
paragraphText: there is no other provision in this or any other Act of Parliament that would provide for a warrant, authorization or order permitting the technique, procedure or device to be used or the thing to be done.

subsectiontext: Nothing in subsection (1) shall be construed as to permit interference with the bodily integrity of any person.

A warrant issued under subsection (1) shall contain such terms and conditions as the judge considers advisable to ensure that any search or seizure authorized by the warrant is reasonable in the circumstances.

A warrant issued under subsection (1) that authorizes a peace officer to observe, by means of a television camera or other similar electronic device, any person who is engaged in activity in circumstances in which the person has a reasonable expectation of privacy shall contain such terms and conditions as the judge considers advisable to ensure that the privacy of the person or of any other person is respected as much as possible.

The definition offence in section 183 and sections 183.1, 184.2, 184.3 and 185 to 188.2, subsection 189(5), and sections 190, 193 and 194 to 196 apply, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to a warrant referred to in subsection (4) as though references in those provisions to interceptions of private communications were read as references to observations by peace officers by means of television cameras or similar electronic devices of activities in circumstances in which persons had reasonable expectations of privacy.

A warrant issued under subsection (1) that authorizes a peace officer to enter and search a place covertly shall require, as part of the terms and conditions referred to in subsection (3), that notice of the entry and search be given within any time after the execution of the warrant that the judge considers reasonable in the circumstances.

Where the judge who issues a warrant under subsection (1) or any other judge having jurisdiction to issue such a warrant is, on the basis of an affidavit submitted in support of an application to vary the period within which the notice referred to in subsection (5.1) is to be given, is satisfied that the interests of justice warrant the granting of the application, the judge may grant an extension, or a subsequent extension, of the period, but no extension may exceed three years.

Where a peace officer believes that it would be impracticable to appear personally before a judge to make an application for a warrant under this section, a warrant may be issued under this section on an information submitted by telephone or other means of telecommunication and, for that purpose, section 487.1 applies, with such modifications as the circumstances require, to the warrant.

sectiontext: The following definitions apply in this section and in sections 487.012 to 487.0199.

subsectiontext: A peace officer or public officer may make a demand to a person in Form 5.001 requiring them to preserve computer data that is in their possession or control when the demand is made.
The peace officer or public officer may make the demand only if they have reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament or has been committed under a law of a foreign state;

subsectiontext: The peace officer or public officer may make the demand only if they have reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: in the case of an offence committed under a law of a foreign state, an investigation is being conducted by a person or authority with responsibility in that state for the investigation of such offences; and

subsectiontext: The peace officer or public officer may make the demand only if they have reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: the computer data is in the person’s possession or control and will assist in the investigation of the offence.

subsectiontext: A demand may not be made to a person who is under investigation for the offence referred to in paragraph (2)(a).
A peace officer or public officer may revoke the demand by notice given to the person at any time. Unless the demand is revoked earlier, the demand expires
paragraphText: in the case of an offence that has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament, 21 days after the day on which it is made; and

subsectiontext: A peace officer or public officer may revoke the demand by notice given to the person at any time. Unless the demand is revoked earlier, the demand expires
paragraphText: in the case of an offence committed under a law of a foreign state, 90 days after the day on which it is made.

subsectiontext: The peace officer or public officer who makes the demand may impose any conditions in the demand that they consider appropriate  — including conditions prohibiting the disclosure of its existence or some or all of its contents  — and may revoke a condition at any time by notice given to the person.
A peace officer or public officer may not make another demand requiring the person to preserve the same computer data in connection with the investigation.
On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a person to preserve computer data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order.
Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.002
paragraphText: that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament or has been committed under a law of a foreign state, that the computer data is in the person’s possession or control and that it will assist in the investigation of the offence; and

subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.002
paragraphText: that a peace officer or public officer intends to apply or has applied for a warrant or an order in connection with the investigation to obtain a document that contains the computer data.

subsectiontext: If an offence has been committed under a law of a foreign state, the justice or judge must also be satisfied that a person or authority with responsibility in that state for the investigation of such offences is conducting the investigation.
The order is to be in Form 5.003.
A person who is under investigation for an offence referred to in paragraph (2)(a) may not be made subject to an order.
Unless the order is revoked earlier, it expires 90 days after the day on which it is made.

Subject to sections 487.015 to 487.018, on ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a person to produce a document that is a copy of a document that is in their possession or control when they receive the order, or to prepare and produce a document containing data that is in their possession or control at that time.
Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that
paragraphText: an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament; and

subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that
paragraphText: the document or data is in the person’s possession or control and will afford evidence respecting the commission of the offence.

subsectiontext: The order is to be in Form 5.005.
A person who is under investigation for the offence referred to in subsection (2) may not be made subject to an order.

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer for the purpose of identifying a device or person involved in the transmission of a communication, a justice or judge may order a person to prepare and produce a document containing transmission data that is related to that purpose and that is, when they are served with the order, in their possession or control.

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament;

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: the identification of a device or person involved in the transmission of a communication will assist in the investigation of the offence; and

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: transmission data that is in the possession or control of one or more persons whose identity is unknown when the application is made will enable that identification.

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: The order is to be in Form 5.006.

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: A peace officer or public officer may serve the order on any person who was involved in the transmission of the communication and whose identity was unknown when the application was made
paragraphText: within 60 days after the day on which the order is made; or

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: A peace officer or public officer may serve the order on any person who was involved in the transmission of the communication and whose identity was unknown when the application was made
paragraphText: within one year after the day on which the order is made, in the case of an offence under section 467.11, 467.12 or 467.13, an offence committed for the benefit of, at the direction of or in association with a criminal organization, or a terrorism offence.

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: A person who is under investigation for the offence referred to in subsection (2) may not be made subject to an order.

marginalnotetext_x: Production order to trace specified communication
subsectiontext: A peace officer or public officer named in the order must provide a written report to the justice or judge who made the order as soon as feasible after the person from whom the communication originated is identified or after the expiry of the period referred to in subsection (4), whichever occurs first. The report must state the name and address of each person on whom the order was served, and the date of service.

On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a person to prepare and produce a document containing transmission data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order.
Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament; and

subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: the transmission data is in the person’s possession or control and will assist in the investigation of the offence.

subsectiontext: The order is to be in Form 5.007.
A person who is under investigation for the offence referred to in subsection (2) may not be made subject to an order.

On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a person to prepare and produce a document containing tracking data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order.
Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament; and

subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: the tracking data is in the person’s possession or control and will assist in the investigation of the offence.

subsectiontext: The order is to be in Form 5.007.
A person who is under investigation for the offence referred to in subsection (2) may not be made subject to an order.

On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a financial institution, as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act, or a person or entity referred to in section 5 of the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act, to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order:
paragraphText: either the account number of a person named in the order or the name of a person whose account number is specified in the order;

subsectiontext: On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a financial institution, as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act, or a person or entity referred to in section 5 of the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act, to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order:
paragraphText: the type of account;

subsectiontext: On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a financial institution, as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act, or a person or entity referred to in section 5 of the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act, to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order:
paragraphText: the status of the account; and

subsectiontext: On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may order a financial institution, as defined in section 2 of the Bank Act, or a person or entity referred to in section 5 of the Proceeds of Crime (Money Laundering) and Terrorist Financing Act, to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control when they receive the order:
paragraphText: the date on which it was opened or closed.

subsectiontext: For the purpose of confirming the identity of a person who is named or whose account number is specified in the order, the order may also require the institution, person or entity to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control:
paragraphText: the date of birth of a person who is named or whose account number is specified in the order;

subsectiontext: For the purpose of confirming the identity of a person who is named or whose account number is specified in the order, the order may also require the institution, person or entity to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control:
paragraphText: that person’s current address; and

subsectiontext: For the purpose of confirming the identity of a person who is named or whose account number is specified in the order, the order may also require the institution, person or entity to prepare and produce a document setting out the following data that is in their possession or control:
paragraphText: any previous addresses of that person.

subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: an offence has been or will be committed under this or any other Act of Parliament; and

subsectiontext: Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.004 that there are reasonable grounds to suspect that
paragraphText: the data is in the possession or control of the institution, person or entity and will assist in the investigation of the offence.

subsectiontext: The order is to be in Form 5.008.
A financial institution, person or entity that is under investigation for the offence referred to in subsection (3) may not be made subject to an order.

marginalnotetext_x: Conditions in preservation and production orders
subsectiontext: The order has effect throughout Canada.

marginalnotetext_x: Conditions in preservation and production orders
subsectiontext: An order made under any of sections 487.013 to 487.018 may contain any conditions that the justice or judge considers appropriate including, in the case of an order made under section 487.014, conditions to protect a privileged communication between a person who is qualified to give legal advice and their client.

marginalnotetext_x: Conditions in preservation and production orders
subsectiontext: On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, the justice or judge who made the order  —  or a judge in the judicial district where the order was made  —  may, on the basis of an information on oath in Form 5.0081, revoke or vary the order. The peace officer or public officer must give notice of the revocation or variation to the person who is subject to the order as soon as feasible.

On ex parte application made by a peace officer or public officer, a justice or judge may make an order prohibiting a person from disclosing the existence or some or all of the contents of a preservation demand made under section 487.012 or a preservation or production order made under any of sections 487.013 to 487.018 during the period set out in the order.

Before making the order, the justice or judge must be satisfied by information on oath in Form 5.009 that there are reasonable grounds to believe that the disclosure during that period would jeopardize the conduct of the investigation of the offence to which the preservation demand or the preservation or production order relates.
The order is to be in Form 5.0091.

A peace officer or a public officer or a person, financial institution or entity that is subject to an order made under subsection (1) may apply in writing to the justice or judge who made the order  —  or to a judge in the judicial district where the order was made  —  to revoke or vary the order.

An order made under any of sections 487.014 and 487.016 to 487.018 must require a person, financial institution or entity to produce the document to a peace officer or public officer named in the order within the time, at the place and in the form specified in the order.

An order made under section 487.015 must require a person to produce the document to a peace officer or public officer named in the order as soon as feasible after they are served with the order at the place and in the form specified in the order.
For greater certainty, an order under any of sections 487.014 to 487.018 may specify that a document may be produced on or through an electro-magnetic medium.
For greater certainty, sections 489.1 and 490 do not apply to a document that is produced under an order under any of sections 487.014 to 487.018.

Every copy of a document produced under section 487.014 is admissible in evidence in proceedings under this or any other Act of Parliament on proof by affidavit that it is a true copy and has the same probative force as the document would have if it were proved in the ordinary way.
A document that is prepared for the purpose of production is considered to be original for the purposes of the Canada Evidence Act.

marginalnotetext_x: Application for review of production order
subsectiontext: Before they are required by an order made under any of sections 487.014 to 487.018 to produce a document, a person, financial institution or entity may apply in writing to the justice or judge who made the order  —  or to a judge in the judicial district where the order was made  —  to revoke or vary the order.

marginalnotetext_x: Application for review of production order
subsectiontext: The person, institution or entity may make the application only if they give notice of their intention to do so to a peace officer or public officer named in the order within 30 days after the day on which the order is made.

marginalnotetext_x: Application for review of production order
subsectiontext: The person, institution or entity is not required to prepare or produce the document until a final decision is made with respect to the application.

marginalnotetext_x: Application for review of production order
subsectiontext: The justice or judge may revoke or vary the order if satisfied that
paragraphText: it is unreasonable in the circumstances to require the applicant to prepare or produce the document; or

marginalnotetext_x: Application for review of production order
subsectiontext: The justice or judge may revoke or vary the order if satisfied that
paragraphText: production of the document would disclose information that is privileged or otherwise protected from disclosure by law.

marginalnotetext_x: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — preservation demand
subsectiontext: A person to whom a preservation demand is made under section 487.012 shall destroy the computer data that would not be retained in the ordinary course of business and any document that is prepared for the purpose of preserving computer data under that section as soon as feasible after the demand expires or is revoked, unless they are subject to an order made under any of sections 487.013 to 487.017 with respect to the computer data.

marginalnotetext_x: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — preservation demand
subsectiontext: A person who is subject to a preservation order made under section 487.013 shall destroy the computer data that would not be retained in the ordinary course of business and any document that is prepared for the purpose of preserving computer data under that section as soon as feasible after the order expires or is revoked, unless they are subject to a new preservation order or to a production order made under any of sections 487.014 to 487.017 with respect to the computer data.

marginalnotetext_x: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — preservation demand
subsectiontext: A person who is subject to a production order made under any of sections 487.014 to 487.017 with respect to computer data that they preserved under a preservation demand or order made under section 487.012 or 487.013 shall destroy the computer data that would not be retained in the ordinary course of business and any document that is prepared for the purpose of preserving computer data under that section as soon as feasible after the earlier of
marginalnotetext_y: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — production order
paragraphText: the day on which the production order is revoked, and

marginalnotetext_x: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — preservation demand
subsectiontext: A person who is subject to a production order made under any of sections 487.014 to 487.017 with respect to computer data that they preserved under a preservation demand or order made under section 487.012 or 487.013 shall destroy the computer data that would not be retained in the ordinary course of business and any document that is prepared for the purpose of preserving computer data under that section as soon as feasible after the earlier of
marginalnotetext_y: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — production order
paragraphText: the day on which a document that contains the computer data is produced under the production order.

marginalnotetext_x: Destruction of preserved computer data and documents — preservation demand
subsectiontext: Despite subsections (1) to (3), a person who preserved computer data under a preservation demand or order made under section 487.012 or 487.013 shall destroy the computer data that would not be retained in the ordinary course of business and any document that is prepared for the purpose of preserving computer data under that section when a document that contains the computer data is obtained under a warrant.

For greater certainty, no preservation demand, preservation order or production order is necessary for a peace officer or public officer to ask a person to voluntarily preserve data that the person is not prohibited by law from preserving or to voluntarily provide a document to the officer that the person is not prohibited by law from disclosing.
A person who preserves data or provides a document in those circumstances does not incur any criminal or civil liability for doing so.

sectiontext: No one is excused from complying with an order made under any of sections 487.014 to 487.018 on the ground that the document that they are required to produce may tend to incriminate them or subject them to a proceeding or penalty. However, no document that an individual is required to prepare may be used or received in evidence against them in a criminal proceeding that is subsequently instituted against them, other than a prosecution for an offence under section 132, 136 or 137.

A person who contravenes a preservation demand made under section 487.012 without lawful excuse is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction and is liable to a fine of not more than $5,000.
A person who contravenes section 487.0194 without lawful excuse is guilty of an offence punishable on summary conviction.

subsectiontext: Within seven years after the coming into force of this section, a comprehensive review of the provisions and operation of sections 487.011 to 487.02 shall be undertaken by such committee of the House of Commons as may be designated or established by the House for that purpose.

The committee referred to in subsection (1) shall, within a year after a review is undertaken pursuant to that subsection or within such further time as the House may authorize, submit a report on the review to the Speaker of the House, including a statement of any changes the committee recommends.

sectiontext: In this section and in sections 487.05 to 487.0911,

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A warrant issued under subsection (1) may be executed at any place in Canada. Any peace officer who executes the warrant must have authority to act as a peace officer in the place where it is executed.

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that a designated offence has been committed,

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that a bodily substance has been found or obtained
subparagraphText: at the place where the offence was committed,

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that a bodily substance has been found or obtained
subparagraphText: on or within the body of the victim of the offence,

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that a bodily substance has been found or obtained
subparagraphText: on anything worn or carried by the victim at the time when the offence was committed, or

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that a bodily substance has been found or obtained
subparagraphText: on or within the body of any person or thing or at any place associated with the commission of the offence,

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that a person was a party to the offence, and

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: A provincial court judge who on ex parte application made in Form 5.01 is satisfied by information on oath that there are reasonable grounds to believe
paragraphText: that forensic DNA analysis of a bodily substance from the person will provide evidence about whether the bodily substance referred to in paragraph (b) was from that person

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: In considering whether to issue the warrant, the provincial court judge shall have regard to all relevant matters, including
paragraphText: the nature of the designated offence and the circumstances of its commission; and

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: In considering whether to issue the warrant, the provincial court judge shall have regard to all relevant matters, including
paragraphText: whether there is
subparagraphText: a peace officer who is able, by virtue of training or experience, to take samples of bodily substances from the person, by means of the investigative procedures described in subsection 487.06(1), or

marginalnotetext_x: Information for warrant to take bodily substances for forensic DNA analysis
subsectiontext: In considering whether to issue the warrant, the provincial court judge shall have regard to all relevant matters, including
paragraphText: whether there is
subparagraphText: another person who is able, by virtue of training or experience, to take, under the direction of a peace officer, samples of bodily substances from the person, by means of those investigative procedures.
