subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(b), that the judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice
subparagraphText: discharged the accused when there was some evidence adduced on which a properly instructed jury acting reasonably could convict;

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(c) or (d), that the judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice erred in law;

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(e), that
subparagraphText: the information or indictment failed to give the accused notice of the charge,

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(e), that
subparagraphText: the judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice did not have jurisdiction to try the offence, or

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(e), that
subparagraphText: the provision creating the offence alleged to have been committed by the accused is unconstitutional; or

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(f), that
subparagraphText: the judge failed to comply with a statutory requirement for the making of the decision or order,

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(f), that
subparagraphText: the decision or order was made in the absence of any evidence that a statutory requirement for the making of the decision or order was met, or

subsectiontext: The judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may grant relief under subsection (4) only if the judge is satisfied that
paragraphText: in the case of a decision or order mentioned in paragraph (1)(f), that
subparagraphText: the decision or order was made as a result of reckless disregard for the truth, fraud, intentional misrepresentation of material facts or intentional omission to state material facts.

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: order a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice to do any act or thing that the judge or any other judge of that court failed or refused to do or has delayed in doing;

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: prohibit or restrain a decision, order or proceeding of a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice;

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: declare invalid or unlawful, quash or set aside, in whole or in part, a decision, order or proceeding of a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice;

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: refer back for determination in accordance with any directions that the judge considers to be appropriate, a decision, order or proceeding of a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice;

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: grant any remedy under subsection 24(1) of the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms;

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: refuse to grant any relief if the judge is of the opinion that no substantial wrong or miscarriage of justice has occurred or that the subject-matter of the application should be determined at trial or on appeal; and

subsectiontext: On the hearing of the application for review, the judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may do one or more of the following:
paragraphText: dismiss the application.

subsectiontext: If an application for review is made, a judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may make any interim order that the judge considers appropriate pending the final disposition of the application for review.

A person who proposes to make an application for review shall do so in the manner and within the period that may be directed by rules of court, except that a judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut may at any time extend any period specified in the rules.

An appeal lies to the Court of Appeal of Nunavut against a decision or order made under subsection (4). The provisions of Part XXI apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to the appeal.
Habeas corpus proceedings may be brought before a judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut in respect of an order made or warrant issued by a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice, except where
paragraphText: the order or warrant is of a kind that could only be made or issued in a province or a territory other than Nunavut by a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a judge as defined in section 552; or

subsectiontext: Habeas corpus proceedings may be brought before a judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut in respect of an order made or warrant issued by a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice, except where
paragraphText: another statutory right of review or appeal is available.

subsectiontext: Despite subsection (1), habeas corpus proceedings may be brought before a judge of the Court of Appeal of Nunavut with respect to an order or warrant of a judge of the Nunavut Court of Justice if the proceedings are brought to challenge the constitutionality of a person’s detention or confinement.
Subsections 784(2) to (6) apply in respect of any proceedings brought under subsection (1) or (2).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The Attorney General or counsel instructed by him or her for that purpose shall, at any time after proceedings in relation to an act or omission of a preclearance officer, as defined in section 5 of the Preclearance Act, 2016, are commenced and before judgment, direct the clerk or other proper officer of the court to make an entry on the record that the proceedings are stayed by direction of the Attorney General if the Government of the United States has provided notice of the exercise of primary criminal jurisdiction under paragraph 14 of Article X of the Agreement.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The clerk or other officer of the court shall make the entry immediately after being so directed, and on the entry being made the proceedings are stayed and any recognizance relating to the proceedings is vacated.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The proceedings may be recommenced without laying a new information or preferring a new indictment, if the Attorney General or counsel instructed by him or her gives notice to the clerk or other officer of the court that
paragraphText: the Government of the United States has provided notice of waiver under paragraph 15 of Article X of the Agreement; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The proceedings may be recommenced without laying a new information or preferring a new indictment, if the Attorney General or counsel instructed by him or her gives notice to the clerk or other officer of the court that
paragraphText: the Government of the United States has declined, or is unable, to prosecute the accused and the accused has returned to Canada.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: However, if the Attorney General or counsel does not give notice under subsection (3) on or before the first anniversary of the day on which the stay of proceedings was entered, the proceedings are deemed never to have been commenced.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: In this section, Agreement means the Agreement on Land, Rail, Marine, and Air Transport Preclearance between the Government of Canada and the Government of the United States of America, done at Washington on March 16, 2015.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If a person has not requested a preliminary inquiry under subsection 536(4) or 536.1(3) into the charge or was not entitled to make such a request, the prosecutor may, subject to subsection (3), prefer an indictment against a person in respect of a charge set out in an information or informations, or any included charge, at any time after the person has made an election, re-election or deemed election on the information or informations.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3), the prosecutor may, whether the charges were included in one information or not, prefer an indictment against any person who has been ordered to stand trial in respect of
paragraphText: any charge on which that person was ordered to stand trial; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (3), the prosecutor may, whether the charges were included in one information or not, prefer an indictment against any person who has been ordered to stand trial in respect of
paragraphText: any charge founded on the facts disclosed by the evidence taken on the preliminary inquiry, in addition to or in substitution for any charge on which that person was ordered to stand trial.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If indictments may be preferred under both subsections (1) and (1.1), the prosecutor may prefer a single indictment in respect of one or more charges referred to in subsection (1) combined with one or more charges or included charges referred to in subsection (1.1).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An indictment preferred under any of subsections (1) to (1.2) may, if the accused consents, include a charge that is not referred to in those subsections, and the offence charged may be dealt with, tried and determined and punished in all respects as if it were an offence in respect of which the accused had been ordered to stand trial. However, if the offence was committed wholly in a province other than that in which the accused is before the court, subsection 478(3) applies.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: In a prosecution conducted by a prosecutor other than the Attorney General and in which the Attorney General does not intervene, an indictment may not be preferred under any of subsections (1) to (1.2) before a court without the written order of a judge of that court.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Except as provided in this Act, no indictment shall be preferred.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: No criminal information shall be laid or granted and no bill of indictment shall be preferred before a grand jury.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: No person shall be tried on a coroner’s inquisition.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Despite section 574, an indictment may be preferred even if the accused has not been given the opportunity to request a preliminary inquiry, a preliminary inquiry has been commenced but not concluded or a preliminary inquiry has been held and the accused has been discharged, if

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where notice of the recommencement of proceedings has been given pursuant to subsection 579(2) or an indictment has been filed with the court before which the proceedings are to commence or recommence, the court, if it considers it necessary, may issue
paragraphText: a summons addressed to, or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where notice of the recommencement of proceedings has been given pursuant to subsection 579(2) or an indictment has been filed with the court before which the proceedings are to commence or recommence, the court, if it considers it necessary, may issue
paragraphText: a warrant for the arrest of,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The provisions of Part XVI apply with such modifications as the circumstances require where a summons or warrant is issued under subsection (1).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The Attorney General or counsel instructed by the Attorney General for that purpose may, at any time after any proceedings in relation to an accused or a defendant are commenced and before judgment, direct the clerk or other proper officer of the court to make an entry on the record that the proceedings are stayed by the Attorney General’s or counsel’s direction, as the case may be, and the entry shall then be made, at which time the proceedings shall be stayed accordingly and any undertaking or release order relating to the proceedings is vacated.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Proceedings stayed in accordance with subsection (1) may be recommenced, without laying a new information or preferring a new indictment, as the case may be, by the Attorney General or counsel instructed by him for that purpose giving notice of the recommencement to the clerk of the court in which the stay of the proceedings was entered, but where no such notice is given within one year after the entry of the stay of proceedings, or before the expiration of the time within which the proceedings could have been commenced, whichever is the earlier, the proceedings shall be deemed never to have been commenced.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: When Attorney General does not stay proceedings
sectiontext: If the Attorney General intervenes in proceedings and does not stay them under section 579, he or she may, without conducting the proceedings, call witnesses, examine and cross-examine witnesses, present evidence and make submissions.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Intervention by Attorney General of Canada or Director of Public Prosecutions
subsectiontext: Sections 579 and 579.01 apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to proceedings in which the Attorney General of Canada or the Director of Public Prosecutions intervenes under this section.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Intervention by Attorney General of Canada or Director of Public Prosecutions
subsectiontext: The Attorney General of Canada or the Director of Public Prosecutions appointed under subsection 3(1) of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, or counsel instructed by him or her for that purpose, may intervene in proceedings in the following circumstances:
paragraphText: the proceedings are in respect of an offence for which he or she has the power to commence or to conduct a proceeding;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Intervention by Attorney General of Canada or Director of Public Prosecutions
subsectiontext: The Attorney General of Canada or the Director of Public Prosecutions appointed under subsection 3(1) of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, or counsel instructed by him or her for that purpose, may intervene in proceedings in the following circumstances:
paragraphText: the proceedings have not been instituted by an Attorney General;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Intervention by Attorney General of Canada or Director of Public Prosecutions
subsectiontext: The Attorney General of Canada or the Director of Public Prosecutions appointed under subsection 3(1) of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, or counsel instructed by him or her for that purpose, may intervene in proceedings in the following circumstances:
paragraphText: judgment has not been rendered; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Intervention by Attorney General of Canada or Director of Public Prosecutions
subsectiontext: The Attorney General of Canada or the Director of Public Prosecutions appointed under subsection 3(1) of the Director of Public Prosecutions Act, or counsel instructed by him or her for that purpose, may intervene in proceedings in the following circumstances:
paragraphText: the Attorney General of the province in which the proceedings are taken has not intervened.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: An indictment is sufficient if it is on paper and is in Form 4.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: [Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 113]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Each count in an indictment shall in general apply to a single transaction and shall contain in substance a statement that the accused or defendant committed an offence therein specified.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The statement referred to in subsection (1) may be
paragraphText: in popular language without technical averments or allegations of matters that are not essential to be proved;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The statement referred to in subsection (1) may be
paragraphText: in the words of the enactment that describes the offence or declares the matters charged to be an indictable offence; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The statement referred to in subsection (1) may be
paragraphText: in words that are sufficient to give to the accused notice of the offence with which he is charged.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A count shall contain sufficient detail of the circumstances of the alleged offence to give to the accused reasonable information with respect to the act or omission to be proved against him and to identify the transaction referred to, but otherwise the absence or insufficiency of details does not vitiate the count.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If an accused is charged with an offence under section 47 or sections 50 to 53, every overt act that is to be relied on shall be stated in the indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A count may refer to any section, subsection, paragraph or subparagraph of the enactment that creates the offence charged, and for the purpose of determining whether a count is sufficient, consideration shall be given to any such reference.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Nothing in this Part relating to matters that do not render a count insufficient shall be deemed to restrict or limit the application of this section.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: High treason and first degree murder
sectiontext: No person shall be convicted for the offence of high treason or first degree murder unless in the indictment charging the offence he is specifically charged with that offence.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Certain omissions not grounds for objection
sectiontext: No count in an indictment is insufficient by reason of the absence of details where, in the opinion of the court, the count otherwise fulfils the requirements of section 581 and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, no count in an indictment is insufficient by reason only that

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: No count for publishing a seditious or defamatory libel, or for selling or exhibiting an obscene book, pamphlet, newspaper or other written matter, is insufficient by reason only that it does not set out the words that are alleged to be libellous or the writing that is alleged to be obscene.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A count for publishing a libel may charge that the published matter was written in a sense that by innuendo made the publication thereof criminal, and may specify that sense without any introductory assertion to show how the matter was written in that sense.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: It is sufficient, on the trial of a count for publishing a libel, to prove that the matter published was libellous, with or without innuendo.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Sufficiency of count charging perjury, etc.
sectiontext: No count that charges

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Sufficiency of count relating to fraud
sectiontext: No count that alleges false pretences, fraud or any attempt or conspiracy by fraudulent means is insufficient by reason only that it does not set out in detail the nature of the false pretence, fraud or fraudulent means.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: of what is relied on in support of a charge of perjury, the making of a false oath or a false statement, fabricating evidence or counselling the commission of any of those offences;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: of any false pretence or fraud that is alleged;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: of any alleged attempt or conspiracy by fraudulent means;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: setting out the passages in a book, pamphlet, newspaper or other printing or writing that are relied on in support of a charge of selling or exhibiting an obscene book, pamphlet, newspaper, printing or writing;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: further describing any writing or words that are the subject of a charge;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: further describing the means by which an offence is alleged to have been committed; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may, where it is satisfied that it is necessary for a fair trial, order the prosecutor to furnish particulars and, without restricting the generality of the foregoing, may order the prosecutor to furnish particulars
paragraphText: further describing a person, place or thing referred to in an indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: For the purpose of determining whether or not a particular is required, the court may give consideration to any evidence that has been taken.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where a particular is delivered pursuant to this section,
paragraphText: a copy shall be given without charge to the accused or his counsel;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where a particular is delivered pursuant to this section,
paragraphText: the particular shall be entered in the record; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where a particular is delivered pursuant to this section,
paragraphText: the trial shall proceed in all respects as if the indictment had been amended to conform with the particular.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: The real and personal property of which a person has, by law, the management, control or custody shall, for the purposes of an indictment or proceeding against any other person for an offence committed on or in respect of the property, be deemed to be the property of the person who has the management, control or custody of it.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: No count that charges an indictable offence other than murder shall be joined in an indictment to a count that charges murder unless

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Offences may be charged in the alternative
subsectiontext: A count is not objectionable by reason only that
paragraphText: it charges in the alternative several different matters, acts or omissions that are stated in the alternative in an enactment that describes as an indictable offence the matters, acts or omissions charged in the count; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Offences may be charged in the alternative
subsectiontext: A count is not objectionable by reason only that
paragraphText: it is double or multifarious.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Offences may be charged in the alternative
subsectiontext: An accused may at any stage of his trial apply to the court to amend or to divide a count that
marginalnotetext_y: Application to amend or divide counts
paragraphText: charges in the alternative different matters, acts or omissions that are stated in the alternative in the enactment that describes the offence or declares that the matters, acts or omissions charged are an indictable offence, or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Offences may be charged in the alternative
subsectiontext: An accused may at any stage of his trial apply to the court to amend or to divide a count that
marginalnotetext_y: Application to amend or divide counts
paragraphText: is double or multifarious,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Offences may be charged in the alternative
subsectiontext: The court may, where it is satisfied that the ends of justice require it, order that a count be amended or divided into two or more counts, and thereupon a formal commencement may be inserted before each of the counts into which it is divided.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to section 589, any number of counts for any number of offences may be joined in the same indictment, but the counts shall be distinguished in the manner shown in Form 4.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where there is more than one count in an indictment, each count may be treated as a separate indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court may, where it is satisfied that the interests of justice so require, order
paragraphText: that the accused or defendant be tried separately on one or more of the counts; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court may, where it is satisfied that the interests of justice so require, order
paragraphText: where there is more than one accused or defendant, that one or more of them be tried separately on one or more of the counts.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An order under subsection (3) may be made before or during the trial but, if the order is made during the trial, the jury shall be discharged from giving a verdict on the counts
paragraphText: on which the trial does not proceed; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An order under subsection (3) may be made before or during the trial but, if the order is made during the trial, the jury shall be discharged from giving a verdict on the counts
paragraphText: in respect of the accused or defendant who has been granted a separate trial.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court may make an order under subsection (3) that takes effect either at a specified later date or on the occurrence of a specified event if, taking into account, among other considerations, the need to ensure consistent decisions, it is satisfied that it is in the interests of justice to do so.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Unless the court is satisfied that it would not be in the interests of justice, the decisions relating to the disclosure or admissibility of evidence or the Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms that are made before any order issued under subsection (3) takes effect continue to bind the parties if the decisions are made — or could have been made — before the stage at which the evidence on the merits is presented.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The counts in respect of which a jury is discharged pursuant to paragraph (4)(a) may subsequently be proceeded on in all respects as if they were contained in a separate indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an order is made in respect of an accused or defendant under paragraph (3)(b), the accused or defendant may be tried separately on the counts in relation to which the order was made as if they were contained in a separate indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Joinder of Accused in Certain Cases
sectiontext: Any one who is charged with being an accessory after the fact to any offence may be indicted, whether or not the principal or any other party to the offence has been indicted or convicted or is or is not amenable to justice.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Joinder of Accused in Certain Cases
subsectiontext: Any number of persons may be charged in the same indictment with an offence under section 354 or 355.4 or paragraph 356(1)(b), even though
paragraphText: the property was had in possession at different times; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Joinder of Accused in Certain Cases
subsectiontext: Any number of persons may be charged in the same indictment with an offence under section 354 or 355.4 or paragraph 356(1)(b), even though
paragraphText: the person by whom the property was obtained
subparagraphText: is not indicted with them, or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Joinder of Accused in Certain Cases
subsectiontext: Any number of persons may be charged in the same indictment with an offence under section 354 or 355.4 or paragraph 356(1)(b), even though
paragraphText: the person by whom the property was obtained
subparagraphText: is not in custody or is not amenable to justice.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Joinder of Accused in Certain Cases
subsectiontext: Where, pursuant to subsection (1), two or more persons are charged in the same indictment with an offence referred to in that subsection, any one or more of those persons who separately committed the offence in respect of the property or any part of it may be convicted.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Joinder of Accused in Certain Cases
sectiontext: [Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 120]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: If an accused is arrested under a warrant issued under subsection (1), a judge of the court that issued the warrant may make a release order referred to in section 515.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: Where an indictment has been preferred against a person who is at large, and that person does not appear or remain in attendance for his trial, the court before which the accused should have appeared or remained in attendance may issue a warrant in Form 7 for his arrest.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: A warrant issued under subsection (1) may be executed anywhere in Canada.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: A judge who issues a warrant may specify in the warrant the period before which the warrant shall not be executed, to allow the accused to appear voluntarily before a judge having jurisdiction in the territorial division in which the warrant was issued.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: Where the accused appears voluntarily for the offence in respect of which the accused is charged, the warrant is deemed to be executed.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding anything in this Act, where a person to whom subsection 597(1) applies has elected or is deemed to have elected to be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury and, at the time he failed to appear or to remain in attendance for his trial, he had not re-elected to be tried by a court composed of a judge without a jury or a provincial court judge without a jury, he shall not be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury unless
paragraphText: he establishes to the satisfaction of a judge of the court in which he is indicted that there was a legitimate excuse for his failure to appear or remain in attendance for his trial; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding anything in this Act, where a person to whom subsection 597(1) applies has elected or is deemed to have elected to be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury and, at the time he failed to appear or to remain in attendance for his trial, he had not re-elected to be tried by a court composed of a judge without a jury or a provincial court judge without a jury, he shall not be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury unless
paragraphText: the Attorney General requires pursuant to section 568 or 569 that the accused be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
heading2titletext: Proceedings when Person Indicted is at Large
subsectiontext: An accused who, under subsection (1), may not be tried by a court composed of a judge and jury is deemed to have elected under section 536 or 536.1 to be tried without a jury by a judge of the court where the accused was indicted and section 561 or 561.1, as the case may be, does not apply in respect of the accused.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court before which an accused is or may be indicted, at any term or sittings thereof, or a judge who may hold or sit in that court, may at any time before or after an indictment is found, on the application of the prosecutor or the accused, order the trial to be held in a territorial division in the same province other than that in which the offence would otherwise be tried if
paragraphText: it appears expedient to the ends of justice, including
subparagraphText: to promote a fair and efficient trial, and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court before which an accused is or may be indicted, at any term or sittings thereof, or a judge who may hold or sit in that court, may at any time before or after an indictment is found, on the application of the prosecutor or the accused, order the trial to be held in a territorial division in the same province other than that in which the offence would otherwise be tried if
paragraphText: it appears expedient to the ends of justice, including
subparagraphText: to ensure the safety and security of a victim or witness or to protect their interests and those of society; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court before which an accused is or may be indicted, at any term or sittings thereof, or a judge who may hold or sit in that court, may at any time before or after an indictment is found, on the application of the prosecutor or the accused, order the trial to be held in a territorial division in the same province other than that in which the offence would otherwise be tried if
paragraphText: a competent authority has directed that a jury is not to be summoned at the time appointed in a territorial division where the trial would otherwise by law be held.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: [Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 1 (4th Supp.), s. 16]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court or judge may, in an order made on an application by the prosecutor under subsection (1), prescribe conditions that he thinks proper with respect to the payment of additional expenses caused to the accused as a result of the change of venue.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an order is made under subsection (1), the officer who has custody of the indictment, if any, and the writings and exhibits relating to the prosecution, shall transmit them forthwith to the clerk of the court before which the trial is ordered to be held, and all proceedings in the case shall be held or, if previously commenced, shall be continued in that court.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where the writings and exhibits referred to in subsection (4) have not been returned to the court in which the trial was to be held at the time an order is made to change the place of trial, the person who obtains the order shall serve a true copy thereof on the person in whose custody they are and that person shall thereupon transmit them to the clerk of the court before which the trial is to be held.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Order is authority to remove prisoner
sectiontext: An order that is made under section 599 is sufficient warrant, justification and authority to all sheriffs, keepers of prisons and peace officers for the removal, disposal and reception of an accused in accordance with the terms of the order, and the sheriff may appoint and authorize any peace officer to convey the accused to a prison in the territorial division in which the trial is ordered to be held.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An objection to an indictment preferred under this Part or to a count in an indictment, for a defect apparent on its face, shall be taken by motion to quash the indictment or count before the accused enters a plea, and, after the accused has entered a plea, only by leave of the court before which the proceedings take place. The court before which an objection is taken under this section may, if it considers it necessary, order the indictment or count to be amended to cure the defect.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court may, on the trial of an indictment, amend the indictment or a count therein or a particular that is furnished under section 587, to make the indictment, count or particular conform to the evidence, where there is a variance between the evidence and
paragraphText: a count in the indictment as preferred; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court may, on the trial of an indictment, amend the indictment or a count therein or a particular that is furnished under section 587, to make the indictment, count or particular conform to the evidence, where there is a variance between the evidence and
paragraphText: a count in the indictment
subparagraphText: as amended, or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court may, on the trial of an indictment, amend the indictment or a count therein or a particular that is furnished under section 587, to make the indictment, count or particular conform to the evidence, where there is a variance between the evidence and
paragraphText: a count in the indictment
subparagraphText: as it would have been if it had been amended in conformity with any particular that has been furnished pursuant to section 587.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court shall, at any stage of the proceedings, amend the indictment or a count therein as may be necessary where it appears
paragraphText: that the indictment has been preferred under a particular Act of Parliament instead of another Act of Parliament;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court shall, at any stage of the proceedings, amend the indictment or a count therein as may be necessary where it appears
paragraphText: that the indictment or a count thereof
subparagraphText: fails to state or states defectively anything that is requisite to constitute the offence,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court shall, at any stage of the proceedings, amend the indictment or a count therein as may be necessary where it appears
paragraphText: that the indictment or a count thereof
subparagraphText: does not negative an exception that should be negatived,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court shall, at any stage of the proceedings, amend the indictment or a count therein as may be necessary where it appears
paragraphText: that the indictment or a count thereof
subparagraphText: is in any way defective in substance,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to this section, a court shall, at any stage of the proceedings, amend the indictment or a count therein as may be necessary where it appears
paragraphText: that the indictment or a count thereof is in any way defective in form.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court shall, in considering whether or not an amendment should be made to the indictment or a count in it, consider
marginalnotetext_y: Matters to be considered by the court
paragraphText: the matters disclosed by the evidence taken on the preliminary inquiry;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court shall, in considering whether or not an amendment should be made to the indictment or a count in it, consider
marginalnotetext_y: Matters to be considered by the court
paragraphText: the evidence taken on the trial, if any;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court shall, in considering whether or not an amendment should be made to the indictment or a count in it, consider
marginalnotetext_y: Matters to be considered by the court
paragraphText: the circumstances of the case;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court shall, in considering whether or not an amendment should be made to the indictment or a count in it, consider
marginalnotetext_y: Matters to be considered by the court
paragraphText: whether the accused has been misled or prejudiced in his defence by any variance, error or omission mentioned in subsection (2) or (3); and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court shall, in considering whether or not an amendment should be made to the indictment or a count in it, consider
marginalnotetext_y: Matters to be considered by the court
paragraphText: whether, having regard to the merits of the case, the proposed amendment can be made without injustice being done.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A variance between the indictment or a count therein and the evidence taken is not material with respect to
paragraphText: the time when the offence is alleged to have been committed, if it is proved that the indictment was preferred within the prescribed period of limitation, if any; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A variance between the indictment or a count therein and the evidence taken is not material with respect to
paragraphText: the place where the subject-matter of the proceedings is alleged to have arisen, if it is proved that it arose within the territorial jurisdiction of the court.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where, in the opinion of the court, the accused has been misled or prejudiced in his defence by a variance, error or omission in an indictment or a count therein, the court may, if it is of the opinion that the misleading or prejudice may be removed by an adjournment, adjourn the proceedings to a specified day or sittings of the court and may make such an order with respect to the payment of costs resulting from the necessity for amendment as it considers desirable.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The question whether an order to amend an indictment or a count thereof should be granted or refused is a question of law.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An order to amend an indictment or a count therein shall be endorsed on the indictment as part of the record and the proceedings shall continue as if the indictment or count had been originally preferred as amended.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A mistake in the heading of an indictment shall be corrected as soon as it is discovered but, whether corrected or not, is not material.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The authority of a court to amend indictments does not authorize the court to add to the overt acts stated in an indictment for high treason or treason or for an offence against any provision in sections 50, 51 and 53.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: In this section, court means a court, judge, justice or provincial court judge acting in summary conviction proceedings or in proceedings on indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: This section applies to all proceedings, including preliminary inquiries, with such modifications as the circumstances require.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: [Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 124]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: An accused is entitled, after he has been ordered to stand trial or at his trial,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A judge of a superior court of criminal jurisdiction or a court of criminal jurisdiction may, on summary application on behalf of the accused or the prosecutor, after three days notice to the accused or prosecutor, as the case may be, order the release of any exhibit for the purpose of a scientific or other test or examination, subject to such terms as appear to be necessary or desirable to ensure the safeguarding of the exhibit and its preservation for use at the trial.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Every one who fails to comply with the terms of an order made under subsection (1) is guilty of contempt of court and may be dealt with summarily by the judge or provincial court judge who made the order or before whom the trial of the accused takes place.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: [Repealed, 1997, c. 18, s. 69]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused who is called on to plead may plead guilty or not guilty, or the special pleas authorized by this Part and no others.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may accept a plea of guilty only if it is satisfied that
paragraphText: the accused is making the plea voluntarily;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may accept a plea of guilty only if it is satisfied that
paragraphText: the facts support the charge.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may accept a plea of guilty only if it is satisfied that
paragraphText: the accused understands
subparagraphText: that the court is not bound by any agreement made between the accused and the prosecutor; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may accept a plea of guilty only if it is satisfied that
paragraphText: the accused understands
subparagraphText: that the plea is an admission of the essential elements of the offence,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A court may accept a plea of guilty only if it is satisfied that
paragraphText: the accused understands
subparagraphText: the nature and consequences of the plea, and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The failure of the court to fully inquire whether the conditions set out in subsection (1.1) are met does not affect the validity of the plea.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an accused refuses to plead or does not answer directly, the court shall order the clerk of the court to enter a plea of not guilty.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused is not entitled as of right to have his trial postponed but the court may, if it considers that the accused should be allowed further time to plead, move to quash or prepare for his defence or for any other reason, adjourn the trial to a later time in the session or sittings of the court, or to the next of any subsequent session or sittings of the court, on such terms as the court considers proper.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any other provision of this Act, where an accused or defendant pleads not guilty of the offence charged but guilty of any other offence arising out of the same transaction, whether or not it is an included offence, the court may, with the consent of the prosecutor, accept that plea of guilty and, if the plea is accepted, the court shall find the accused or defendant not guilty of the offence charged and find him guilty of the offence in respect of which the plea of guilty was accepted and enter those findings in the record of the court.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If the accused is charged with a serious personal injury offence, as that expression is defined in section 752, or with the offence of murder, and the accused and the prosecutor have entered into an agreement under which the accused will enter a plea of guilty of the offence charged  —  or a plea of not guilty of the offence charged but guilty of any other offence arising out of the same transaction, whether or not it is an included offence  —  the court shall, after accepting the plea of guilty, inquire of the prosecutor if reasonable steps were taken to inform the victims of the agreement.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If the accused is charged with an offence, as defined in section 2 of the Canadian Victims Bill of Rights, that is an indictable offence for which the maximum punishment is imprisonment for five years or more, and that is not an offence referred to in subsection (4.1), and the accused and the prosecutor have entered into an agreement referred to in subsection (4.1), the court shall, after accepting the plea of guilty, inquire of the prosecutor whether any of the victims had advised the prosecutor of their desire to be informed if such an agreement were entered into, and, if so, whether reasonable steps were taken to inform that victim of the agreement.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If subsection (4.1) or (4.2) applies, and any victim was not informed of the agreement before the plea of guilty was accepted, the prosecutor shall, as soon as feasible, take reasonable steps to inform the victim of the agreement and the acceptance of the plea.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Neither the failure of the court to inquire of the prosecutor, nor the failure of the prosecutor to take reasonable steps to inform the victims of the agreement, affects the validity of the plea.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: For greater certainty, subsections 650(1.1) and (1.2) apply, with any modifications that the circumstances require, to pleas under this section if the accused has agreed to use a means referred to in those subsections.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused may plead the special pleas of
paragraphText: autrefois acquit;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused may plead the special pleas of
paragraphText: autrefois convict;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused may plead the special pleas of
paragraphText: pardon; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused may plead the special pleas of
paragraphText: an expungement order under the Expungement of Historically Unjust Convictions Act.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused who is charged with defamatory libel may plead in accordance with sections 611 and 612.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The pleas of autrefois acquit, autrefois convict, pardon and an expungement order under the Expungement of Historically Unjust Convictions Act shall be disposed of by the judge without a jury before the accused is called on to plead further.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: When the pleas referred to in subsection (3) are disposed of against the accused, he may plead guilty or not guilty.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an accused pleads autrefois acquit or autrefois convict, it is sufficient if he
paragraphText: states that he has been lawfully acquitted, convicted or discharged under subsection 730(1), as the case may be, of the offence charged in the count to which the plea relates; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an accused pleads autrefois acquit or autrefois convict, it is sufficient if he
paragraphText: indicates the time and place of the acquittal, conviction or discharge under subsection 730(1).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A person who is alleged to have committed an act or omission outside Canada that is an offence in Canada by virtue of any of subsections 7(2) to (3.1) or (3.7), or an offence under the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act, and in respect of which the person has been tried and convicted outside Canada, may not plead autrefois convict with respect to a count that charges that offence if
paragraphText: at the trial outside Canada the person was not present and was not represented by counsel acting under the person’s instructions, and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A person who is alleged to have committed an act or omission outside Canada that is an offence in Canada by virtue of any of subsections 7(2) to (3.1) or (3.7), or an offence under the Crimes Against Humanity and War Crimes Act, and in respect of which the person has been tried and convicted outside Canada, may not plead autrefois convict with respect to a count that charges that offence if
paragraphText: the person was not punished in accordance with the sentence imposed on conviction in respect of the act or omission,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Where an issue on a plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict is tried, the evidence and adjudication and the notes of the judge and official stenographer on the former trial and the record transmitted to the court pursuant to section 551 on the charge that is pending before that court are admissible in evidence to prove or to disprove the identity of the charges.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an issue on a plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict to a count is tried and it appears
paragraphText: that the matter on which the accused was given in charge on the former trial is the same in whole or in part as that on which it is proposed to give him in charge, and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an issue on a plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict to a count is tried and it appears
paragraphText: that on the former trial, if all proper amendments had been made that might then have been made, he might have been convicted of all the offences of which he may be convicted on the count to which the plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict is pleaded,

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The following provisions apply where an issue on a plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict is tried:
marginalnotetext_y: Allowance of special plea in part
paragraphText: where it appears that the accused might on the former trial have been convicted of an offence of which he may be convicted on the count in issue, the judge shall direct that the accused shall not be found guilty of any offence of which he might have been convicted on the former trial; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The following provisions apply where an issue on a plea of autrefois acquit or autrefois convict is tried:
marginalnotetext_y: Allowance of special plea in part
paragraphText: where it appears that the accused may be convicted on the count in issue of an offence of which he could not have been convicted on the former trial, the accused shall plead guilty or not guilty with respect to that offence.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where an indictment charges substantially the same offence as that charged in an indictment on which an accused was previously convicted or acquitted, but adds a statement of intention or circumstances of aggravation tending, if proved, to increase the punishment, the previous conviction or acquittal bars the subsequent indictment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A conviction or an acquittal on an indictment for murder bars a subsequent indictment for the same homicide charging it as manslaughter or infanticide, and a conviction or acquittal on an indictment for manslaughter or infanticide bars a subsequent indictment for the same homicide charging it as murder.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A conviction or an acquittal on an indictment for first degree murder bars a subsequent indictment for the same homicide charging it as second degree murder, and a conviction or acquittal on an indictment for second degree murder bars a subsequent indictment for the same homicide charging it as first degree murder.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A conviction or an acquittal on an indictment for infanticide bars a subsequent indictment for the same homicide charging it as manslaughter, and a conviction or acquittal on an indictment for manslaughter bars a subsequent indictment for the same homicide charging it as infanticide.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: An accused who is charged with publishing a defamatory libel may plead that the defamatory matter published by him was true, and that it was for the public benefit that the matter should have been published in the manner in which and at the time when it was published.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A plea that is made under subsection (1) may justify the defamatory matter in any sense in which it is specified in the count, or in the sense that the defamatory matter bears without being specified, or separate pleas justifying the defamatory matter in each sense may be pleaded separately to each count as if two libels had been charged in separate counts.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A plea that is made under subsection (1) shall be in writing and shall set out the particular facts by reason of which it is alleged to have been for the public good that the matter should have been published.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The prosecutor may in his reply deny generally the truth of a plea that is made under this section.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The truth of the matters charged in an alleged libel shall not be inquired into in the absence of a plea of justification under section 611 unless the accused is charged with publishing the libel knowing it to be false, in which case evidence of the truth may be given to negative the allegation that the accused knew that the libel was false.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The accused may, in addition to a plea that is made under section 611, plead not guilty and the pleas shall be inquired into together.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Where a plea of justification is pleaded and the accused is convicted, the court may, in pronouncing sentence, consider whether the guilt of the accused is aggravated or mitigated by the plea.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Any ground of defence for which a special plea is not provided by this Act may be relied on under the plea of not guilty.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: [ Repealed, 1991, c. 43, s. 3]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Every organization against which an indictment is filed shall appear and plead by counsel or agent.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The clerk of the court or the prosecutor may, where an indictment is filed against an organization, cause a notice of the indictment to be served on the organization.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A notice of an indictment referred to in subsection (1) shall set out the nature and purport of the indictment and advise that, unless the organization appears on the date set out in the notice or the date fixed under subsection 548(2.1), and enters a plea, a plea of not guilty will be entered for the accused by the court, and that the trial of the indictment will be proceeded with as though the organization had appeared and pleaded.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Where an organization does not appear in accordance with the notice referred to in section 621, the presiding judge may, on proof of service of the notice, order the clerk of the court to enter a plea of not guilty on behalf of the organization, and the plea has the same force and effect as if the organization had appeared by its counsel or agent and pleaded that plea.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Where an organization appears and pleads to an indictment or a plea of not guilty is entered by order of the court under section 622, the court shall proceed with the trial of the indictment and, where the organization is convicted, section 735 applies.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: It is sufficient, in making up the record of a conviction or acquittal on an indictment, to copy the indictment and the plea that was pleaded, without a formal caption or heading.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court shall keep a record of every arraignment and of proceedings subsequent to arraignment.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Form of record in case of amendment
sectiontext: Where it is necessary to draw up a formal record in proceedings in which the indictment has been amended, the record shall be drawn up in the form in which the indictment remained after the amendment, without reference to the fact that the indictment was amended.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subject to subsection (2), on application by the prosecutor or the accused or on its own motion, the court, or a judge of the court, before which, or the judge, provincial court judge or justice before whom, any proceedings are to be held may order that a conference between the prosecutor and the accused or counsel for the accused, to be presided over by the court, judge, provincial court judge or justice, be held prior to the proceedings to consider the matters that, to promote a fair and expeditious hearing, would be better decided before the start of the proceedings, and other similar matters, and to make arrangements for decisions on those matters.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: In any case to be tried with a jury, a judge of the court before which the accused is to be tried shall, before the trial, order that a conference between the prosecutor and the accused or counsel for the accused, to be presided over by a judge of that court, be held in accordance with the rules of court made under sections 482 and 482.1 to consider any matters that would promote a fair and expeditious trial.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A person who is qualified as a juror according to, and summoned as a juror in accordance with, the laws of a province is qualified to serve as a juror in criminal proceedings in that province.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Notwithstanding any law of a province referred to in subsection (1), no person may be disqualified, exempted or excused from serving as a juror in criminal proceedings on the grounds of his or her sex.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: The judge before whom an accused is tried may be either the judge who presided over matters pertaining to the selection of a jury before the commencement of a trial or another judge of the same court.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
marginalnotetext_x: Support for juror with physical disability
sectiontext: The judge may permit a juror with a physical disability who is otherwise qualified to serve as a juror to have technical, personal, interpretative or other support services.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The accused or the prosecutor may challenge the jury panel only on the ground of partiality, fraud or wilful misconduct on the part of the sheriff or other officer by whom the panel was returned.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A challenge under subsection (1) shall be in writing and shall state that the person who returned the panel was partial or fraudulent or that he wilfully misconducted himself, as the case may be.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A challenge under this section may be in Form 40.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: Where a challenge is made under section 629, the judge shall determine whether the alleged ground of challenge is true or not, and where he is satisfied that the alleged ground of challenge is true, he shall direct a new panel to be returned.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: [Repealed, R.S., 1985, c. 27 (1st Supp.), s. 129]

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: The judge may direct a juror who has been called under subsection 631(3) or (3.1) to stand by for reasons of personal hardship, maintaining public confidence in the administration of justice or any other reasonable cause.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If a challenge is made on a ground mentioned in section 638, the judge shall determine whether the alleged ground is true or not and, if the judge is satisfied that it is true, the juror shall not be sworn.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: On the application of the accused or prosecutor or on the judge’s own motion, the judge may order the exclusion of all jurors, sworn and unsworn, from the court room until it is determined whether the ground of challenge is true if the judge is of the opinion that the order is necessary to preserve the impartiality of the jurors.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The name of each juror on a panel of jurors that has been returned, his number on the panel and his address shall be written on a separate card, and all the cards shall, as far as possible, be of equal size.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The sheriff or other officer who returns the panel shall deliver the cards referred to in subsection (1) to the clerk of the court who shall cause them to be placed together in a box to be provided for the purpose and to be thoroughly shaken together.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If the judge considers it advisable in the interests of justice to have one or two alternate jurors, the judge shall so order before the clerk of the court draws out the cards under subsection (3) or (3.1).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If the judge considers it advisable in the interests of justice, he or she may order that 13 or 14 jurors, instead of 12, be sworn in accordance with this Part before the clerk of the court draws out the cards under subsection (3) or (3.1).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If the array of jurors is not challenged or the array of jurors is challenged but the judge does not direct a new panel to be returned, the clerk of the court shall, in open court, draw out one after another the cards referred to in subsection (1), call out the number on each card as it is drawn and confirm with the person who responds that he or she is the person whose name appears on the card drawn, until the number of persons who have answered is, in the opinion of the judge, sufficient to provide a full jury and any alternate jurors ordered by the judge after allowing for orders to excuse, challenges and directions to stand by.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The court, or a judge of the court, before which the jury trial is to be held may, if the court or judge is satisfied that it is necessary for the proper administration of justice, order the clerk of the court to call out the name and the number on each card.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The clerk of the court shall swear each member of the jury, and any alternate jurors, in the order in which his or her card was drawn and shall swear any other person providing technical, personal, interpretative or other support services to a juror with a physical disability.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: If the number of persons who answer under subsection (3) or (3.1) is not sufficient to provide a full jury and the number of alternate jurors ordered by the judge, the clerk of the court shall proceed in accordance with subsections (3), (3.1) and (4) until 12 jurors — or 13 or 14 jurors, as the case may be, if the judge makes an order under subsection (2.2) — and any alternate jurors are sworn.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: On application by the prosecutor or on its own motion, the court or judge before which a jury trial is to be held may, if the court or judge is satisfied that such an order is necessary for the proper administration of justice, make an order
marginalnotetext_y: Ban on publication, limitation to access or use of information
paragraphText: directing that the identity of a juror or any information that could disclose their identity shall not be published in any document or broadcast or transmitted in any way; or

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: On application by the prosecutor or on its own motion, the court or judge before which a jury trial is to be held may, if the court or judge is satisfied that such an order is necessary for the proper administration of justice, make an order
marginalnotetext_y: Ban on publication, limitation to access or use of information
paragraphText: limiting access to or the use of that information.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
sectiontext: The judge may, at any time before the commencement of a trial, order that any juror be excused from jury service, whether or not the juror has been called pursuant to subsection 631(3) or (3.1) or any challenge has been made in relation to the juror, for reasons of

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: The accused shall be called on before the prosecutor is called on to declare whether the accused challenges the first juror for cause, and after that the prosecutor and the accused shall be called on alternately, in respect of each of the remaining jurors, to first make such a declaration.

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subsection (1) applies where two or more accused are to be tried together, but all of the accused shall exercise the challenges of the defence in turn, in the order in which their names appear in the indictment or in any other order agreed on by them,
paragraphText: in respect of the first juror, before the prosecutor; and

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: Subsection (1) applies where two or more accused are to be tried together, but all of the accused shall exercise the challenges of the defence in turn, in the order in which their names appear in the indictment or in any other order agreed on by them,
paragraphText: in respect of each of the remaining jurors, either before or after the prosecutor, in accordance with subsection (1).

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
subsectiontext: A prosecutor or an accused is entitled to any number of challenges on the ground that
paragraphText: a juror is not impartial;

heading1titletext: Procedure in Jury Trials and General Provisions
